questions.text: After an episode of viral hepatitis, which of the following mechanisms is most likely responsible for the regeneration of the lost hepatocytes?

choices.text: Decreased apoptosis at G1-M part of cell cycle
Hepatocyte recruitment from G0 to enter cell cycle
Hepatocytes undergoing terminal differentiation as they exit the cell cycle

questions.solution:
Liver parenchyma is an example of stable tissue. It is made up of cells that are normally in the G0 phase (quiescent) of the cell cycle and are not proliferating. However, they are capable of entering the cell cycle and proliferating in response to injury.

Different tissues have different intrinsic proliferative capacity, which determines their ability to repair themselves. 

Labile tissues - cells are constantly being lost and must be continually replaced by new cells that are derived from tissue stem cells (option C). These tissues can readily regenerate after injury as long as the pool of stem cells is preserved.

  • Hematopoietic cells in the bone marrow
  • Basal layers of many surface epithelia, such as squamous epithelia of the skin, oral cavity
  • Cuboidal epithelia of the ducts draining exocrine organs e.g., salivary glands, biliary tract
  • Columnar epithelium of the gastrointestinal tract, uterus, and fallopian tubes
  • Transitional epithelium of the urinary tract

Stable tissues - made up of cells that are normally in the G0 stage of the cell cycle and hence not proliferating, but they are capable of dividing in response to injury.

  • Parenchyma of most solid organs, such as liver, kidney, and pancreas
  • Endothelial cells, fibroblasts, and smooth muscle cells

Permanent tissues - The cells in these tissues are considered to be terminally differentiated and nonproliferative in postnatal life. Injury to these tissues is irreversible and results in a scar, because the cells cannot regenerate.

  • Majority of neurons
  • Cardiac muscle cells

Other options:

Option A: Decreased apoptosis would not lead to the regeneration of the lost hepatocytes.

Option D: Hepatocytes do not undergo terminal differentiation as they exit the cell cycle since they are stable tissue.

questions.text: A patient shows FEV1/FVC <0.7 and FEV1 ≥30% but <50% predicted, under what category would he be classified based on GOLD criteria?
questions.solution:
FEV1/FVC <0.7 and FEV1 ≥30% but <50% predicted is classified as severe COPD under GOLD classification.

The severity of COPD is assessed by Global Initiative for Lung Disease (GOLD) classification:

  GOLD Stage   Severity   Spirometry
I Mild FEV1/FVC <0.7 and FEV1 ≥80% predicted
II Moderate FEV1/FVC <0.7 and FEV1 ≥50% but <80% predicted
III Severe FEV1/FVC <0.7 and FEV1 ≥30% but <50% predicted
IV Very severe FEV1/FVC <0.7 and FEV1 <30% predicted

questions.text: A boy presents with a hard woody nose. Biopsy of the tissue shows large foam cells containing causative bacilli and homogenous eosinophilic inclusion bodies in plasma cells. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Clinical feature of ‘hard woody nose’ with biopsy showing large foam cells containing causative bacilli (Mikulicz cells) and homogenous eosinophilic inclusion bodies in plasma (Russel bodies) point towards the diagnosis of Rhinoscleroma.

Rhinoscleroma is the granulomatous disease of nose casused by gram negative cocobacillus Klebsiella rhinoscleromatis. Biopsy shows infiltration of submucosa with plasma cells, lymphocytes, eosinophils, Mikulicz cells and Russell bodies.

The latter two are diagnostic features of the disease.

  • Mikulicz cells are large foam cells with a central nucleus and vacuolated cytoplasm containing causative bacilli.
  • Russell bodies are homogenous eosinophilic inclusion bodies found in the plasma cells. They occur due to accumulation of immunoglobulins secreted by the plasma cells.

The causative organisms can be cultured from the biopsy material.

Image below shows Mikulicz cells

Image below shows Russell bodies 

A patient with a rhinoscleroma is seen below.

Other options : 

Option B) Rhinosporidiosis is a chronic granulomatous disease caused by Rhinosporidium seeberi. The rhinoscopic examination will reveal papular or nodular, smooth-surfaced lesions that become pedunculated and acquire a papillomatous or proliferative appearance. The lesions are pink, red, or purple in color. Histopathology shows several sporangia, oval, or round in shape and filled with spores.

A patient with rhinosporidiosis is shown below.

Option C) Lupus vulgaris is a low-grade tuberculosis infection characterised by chronic vestibulitis and perforation of the nasal septum. Biopsy shows tuberculous granuloma and caseous necrosis.

Option D) Wegener's granulomatosis is a chronic granulomatous disorder presenting with crusting, granulation and saddle nose deformity. Biopsy shows necrosis and ulceration of mucosa, epithelioid granuloma and necrotizing vasculitis of the vessels.

questions.text: A 20-year-old female patient presented with firm papules with a rough surface on the genitalia. Histopathology of the tissues from the lesion is shown below. These findings are seen in _____.
questions.solution:
The given clinical features and the image showing koilocytes are seen in papilloma virus infection.

Koilocytes are squamous epithelial cells with perinuclear cavitation, nuclear enlargement, coarse chromatin, and irregular nuclear membranes. A rim of condensed cytoplasm around the perinuclear cavitation gives the cell a halo or cleared-out appearance. Koilocytes are often seen in cervical cancer, premalignant lesions of the cervix, genital warts, and anal and oral cancers. 

Genital warts or condyloma acuminata are verrucous growths caused by human papillomavirus, that affect the skin of the labia majora, perineum, perianal region, and vulva. The lesions may be discrete or merge to form cauliflower-like growth. The disease is sexually transmitted. 

The following image shows pap staining showing koilocytes.

Other options:

Option A: Polyomavirus infections are associated with the presence of decoy cells in histopathology. Decoy cells are epithelial cells with intranuclear viral inclusion bodies characterized by large, homogenous, amorphous ground-glass-like intranuclear inclusion bodies and a condensed rim of chromatin.

Option C: Molluscum contagiosum is a viral infection that appears as discrete, pearly, umbilicated papules. It is characterized by the presence of intracytoplasmic eosinophilic inclusion bodies called Henderson-Patterson bodies or molluscum bodies.

Option D: Granuloma inguinale infection usually presents as genital ulcers. It is characterized by large mononuclear cells, whose cytoplasm contains numerous organisms that show bipolar staining with a safety‐pin appearance, called Donovan bodies.

questions.text:
An elderly alcoholic had a trivial fall and was presented with a shaft of femur fracture. On the third day of admission, he develops severe restlessness and altered sensorium and says there are many squirrels on his bed. Which of the following describes the next best step of management for this patient?

NCCT - Non contrast computed tomography

choices.text: Arrange for a NCCT of head

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of altered sensorium with visual and tactile hallucinations following alcohol withdrawal is suggestive of delirium tremens. Chlordiazepoxide, a long-acting benzodiazepine administered regularly to patients at risk for or experiencing complicated withdrawal (e.g., delirium tremens) 

Benzodiazepines (GABA-A receptor agonists) are utilized in the supportive management of delirium tremens to mitigate the psychomotor agitation linked to withdrawal symptoms and avert the exacerbation of withdrawal-related manifestations.

Other options:

Option A: Antipsychotics like Clozapine are avoided in the management of delirium tremens as they lower the seizure threshold, placing the patient at a greater risk for developing alcohol-withdrawal seizures.

Option C: A chest X-ray would be useful to aid in the diagnosis of fat embolism syndrome. Fat embolism is common after a traumatic femur fracture. However, the patients present with hypoxia and petechial rash in addition to altered sensorium which is not seen in this patient.

Option D: This patient’s clinical history is consistent with a diagnosis of delirium tremens, which therefore does not necessitate an NCCT of the head.

questions.text: A sample of water is being tested to assess fecal contamination. Which of the following organisms is correctly paired with the parameter that it indicates?
questions.solution:
The presence of fecal streptococci indicates recent fecal contamination of water. 

Fecal streptococci (Enterococcus) are found in feces but in much smaller numbers than E.coli. Only in doubtful cases, the finding of fecal streptococci in water is regarded as important confirmatory evidence of recent fecal pollution of water. Streptococci are useful for routine control testing after laying new pipelines or repairs in distribution systems and to detect groundwater contamination.

Fecal contamination of water- Parameters  Organism
Definitive fecal contamination E.coli
Recent fecal contamination Fecal streptococci (Enterococci)
Remote fecal contamination Spores of Clostridium perfringens


Other options:

Option A: If Escherichia coli is detected, it is definitive proof of fecal contamination. However, it is non-specific for suggesting the duration of the contamination. 

Option C: The presence of spores of Clostridium perfringens in natural water suggests remote fecal contamination has occurred. The spores are capable of surviving in water for a long time, and they usually resist chlorination. Their presence in filtered supplies indicates a defective filtration process.

Option D: Bacteroides species are present in feces but do not play a significant role in testing and sampling for fecal pollution of water.

questions.text:
A 50-year-old male patient who has been on antitubercular therapy for the past 2 months presents with fatigue, weakness, and irritability for a few weeks. Physical examination revealed chronic malnutrition. Findings on peripheral smear and iron studies are given below. What could be seen on bone marrow aspiration?

Hemoglobin - Reduced
Mean corpuscular hemoglobin (MCH) - Reduced
Mean corpuscular volume (MCV) - Reduced
Serum ferritin - Raised
Serum iron - Raised
Total iron-binding capacity (TIBC) - Normal 
Transferrin saturation- Raised

choices.text: Stainable iron is absent from macrophages
Nucleated red cells with iron deposition

questions.solution:
The given scenario with a peripheral smear showing microcytic hypochromic anemia and iron studies showing increased serum ferritin with normal TIBC is suggestive of sideroblastic anemia. Bone marrow aspirate will show nucleated red cells with iron deposition.

Sideroblastic anemia is a group of disorders characterized by the presence of sideroblasts. Sideroblasts are nucleated red cells (normoblasts) containing non-heme siderotic granules and stain Prussian blue positive. Sideroblastic anemia is classified into two types.

Hereditary sideroblastic anemia: It is an X-linked disorder caused due to defect in the activity of ALA synthetase required for heme synthesis. 

Acquired sideroblastic anemia: This is further divided into - 

  •  Primary acquired/idiopathic/refractory - It is regarded as a myelodysplastic disorder in the FAB classification. It occurs in middle-aged and elderly individuals of both sexes. This occurs due to the reduced activity of the ALA synthetase enzyme.
  •  Secondary Acquired - may occur secondary to -
    • Drugs, chemicals, and toxins - isoniazid (as in this case), alcohol, and lead.
    • Hematological disorders - myelofibrosis, acute leukemia, lymphoma, and hemolytic anemia.
    • Miscellaneous - inflammatory diseases such as rheumatoid arthritis and systemic lupus erythematosus.

Peripheral smear in sideroblastic anemia shows hypochromic microcytic (sometimes normocytic) anemia. MCH and MCV are reduced in the hereditary type, and MCV may be raised in the acquired type. Serum ferritin and serum iron are raised and TIBC is normal. Bone marrow examination shows erythroid hyperplasia with pathognomonic ring sideroblasts as shown below.


Pyridoxine for 2-3 months is administered routinely to all cases of sideroblastic anemia. Blood transfusion and other supportive therapy may be required. In cases of secondary sideroblastic anemia, the primary focus is the removal of the offending agent. 

Note: In case of anemia of chronic disease iron studies will show high serum ferritin and low total iron binding capacity.

Other options:

Option A: Stainable iron is absent from macrophages in bone marrow aspiration is seen in iron deficiency anemia.

Option B: Aspirates often yield minimal material (i.e dry tap) is seen in aplastic anemia.

Option C: Aspirates showing megaloblastic change is seen in vitamin B12 deficiency.

questions.text: What is the correct statement regarding the wound indicated by the red arrow in the given image of the skull?

choices.text: It is an entry wound because the outer table appears bevelled
It is an Exit wound because the inner table appears bevelled
It is an Exit wound because the outer table appears bevelled
It is an entry wound because the inner table appears bevelled

questions.solution:
In the given image, bevelling is seen on the outer table and a punched out hole is seen on the inner table. So, it is an exit wound.

Entry wound: The initial contact of the missile punches a clean hole through the outer table of the skull. Where the bullet emerges internally, the inner table is then unsupported and a cone-shaped plug is detached, forming a crater that is appreciably larger than the external hole.

  • Bevelling: inner table
  • Punched out hole: outer table

Exit wound: If the bullet traverses the cranium and penetrates the opposite side, the same pattern occurs, this time with the small hole on the inner table and the crater on the outside.

  • Bevelling: outer table
  • Punched out hole: inner table

A 'rat-hole' appearance of the entry wound of a shotgun can be seen from 30 cm to 5 meters of range:

  • Circular rat-hole wound without peripheral satellite pellet holes is seen in 30cm-1m range.
  • Central rat-hole wound with peripheral satellite pellet holes is seen in 1m-5m range.

Ricochet: This is when the bullet hits an intervening object before hitting the desired target. Due to this, it tumbles towards the target and enters it obliquely, rather than head-on.

questions.text: A 33-year-old man comes to the psychiatric outpatient department after a nervous breakdown. He says that he got divorced about a week ago, and has been feeling depressed since then. He has also started hearing voices for the past few days, saying he is useless and telling him to kill himself. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A brief psychotic disorder is the best answer in this scenario, as the symptoms are present for less than 30 days.

The diagnosis of brief psychotic disorder in DSM-5 is based on the presence of one or more of the following psychotic symptoms for a period of at least 1 day but less than 1 month:

  • Delusions
  • Hallucinations
  • Thought disorder as evidenced by disorganized speech
  • Disorganized or catatonic behavior.

DSM-5 specifies that one of the first three symptoms must be present for the diagnosis to be made.

Other options: 

Option D: Major Depressive Disorder is diagnosed by the presence of depressive symptoms for at least two weeks, including persistent feelings of sadness, anhedonia, changes in appetite or weight, sleep disturbances, fatigue, feelings of worthlessness or guilt, difficulty concentrating, and thoughts of death or suicide. Patients experiencing a major depressive episode may exhibit delusions and hallucinations, which is known as psychotic depression. These delusions and hallucinations are usually mood-congruent and often revolve around themes of guilt and self-deprecation.

questions.text: Which of the following is not indicated in the management of Clostridium difficile associated diarrhea?
questions.solution:
Clindamycin is a broad spectrum lincosamide antibiotic. It is one of the most common antibiotics implicated in Clostridium difficile associated bacterial infections. Therefore, clindamycin is a causative agent for Clostridium difficile associated diarrhea and not used in the management.

First choice treatment of C. difficile Colitis :

*Metronidazole now reserved for non-severe infections in settings where access to first-line drugs is limited or cost is an issue.

questions.text:
Which of the following are correct regarding Burkitt lymphoma?

1. Associated with translocation of RET gene at chromosome 9
2. Starry appearance on HPE is due to macrophages
3. Tumor cells have a low Ki-67 index
4. Endemic type presents with mandibular mass
questions.solution:
The correct statements regarding Burkitt lymphoma are that the starry appearance on histopathological examination (HPE) is due to macrophages (statement 2) and endemic type presents with mandibular mass (statement 4).

Burkitt's lymphoma is an aggressive type of non-Hodgkin lymphoma (NHL) characterized by the translocation of the MYC gene on chromosome 8 (statement 1). The main translocations include t(8;14),t(8;22) and t(2;8). It is commonly seen in children and young adults and most tumors manifest at extranodal sites.

It can occur in 3 forms mainly presenting in children or young adults

  • African (endemic) Burkitt lymphoma - it often presents as a mass involving the mandible. It may also involve the abdominal viscera, particularly the kidneys, ovaries, and adrenal glands. 
  • Sporadic (non-endemic) Burkitt lymphoma - it most often appears as a mass involving the ileocecum and peritoneum.
  • Aggressive lymphoma or acute leukemia - it is seen in immunocompromised (HIV) individuals.

Histopathology shows tumor cells with multiple small nucleoli, minimal cytoplasm, and a high mitotic index. Lymphoma cells are closely opposed to each other forming a dark blue background (sky) and the macrophages get stuffed in between along with cellular debris to form a starry appearance. Ki-67 stains for 100% of cells (due to rapid proliferation) (statement 3).

The image below shows the starry-sky appearance on histopathology:

Related Pearl: Burkitt's Lymphoma

Burkitt's lymphoma is the most common non-Hodgkin's lymphoma in children < 15 years.

questions.text: An infant presents with high fever, seizures, and coma, suggestive of cerebral malaria. Which of the following is most likely responsible for  Plasmodium falciparum's ability to sequester in brain capillaries, contributing to neurological symptoms?

choices.text: Inflammation of blood-brain barrier by hemozoin
Infected RBCs activating the coagulation cascade

questions.solution:
Expression of Plasmodium falciparum erythrocyte membrane protein (PfEMP1) which has affinity for the brain endothelial cells causing sequestration is the most likely mechanism. 

PfEMP1 is a highly variable protein expressed on the surface of P. falciparum-infected erythrocytes. Specific variants of PfEMP1 have a strong affinity for ICAM-1 (Intracellular Adhesion Molecule-1), which is highly expressed on endothelial cells in the brain. This adhesion leads to sequestration of infected erythrocytes in the brain capillaries, impeding blood flow and contributing to cerebral hypoxia and neurological symptoms

Other options: 

Option B: While hemozoin can contribute to inflammation, it does not directly lead to parasite sequestration.

Option C. Merozoite release occurs during erythrocyte invasion, not during sequestration.

Option D: Activation of the inflammation and the resultant coagulation cascade is not an established mechanism by which the infected RBCs sequester.

questions.text: Which of the following represents functional residual capacity in the below given graph?
questions.solution:
The zero pressure (point 3) in the pressure-volume curve indicates the functional residual capacity.

The pressure-volume relationship is basic to the understanding of the fundamental relationship between the compliance of the lungs and the chest wall. It is measured by a spirometer.

The functional residual capacity is the volume of the air that remains in the lungs after normal expiration. The normal value is about 2.5 litres.

The below image shows pressure–volume curves of the total respiratory system, the lungs, and the chest are plotted together with standard volumes for functional residual capacity and tidal volume. 

Related Pearl: Lung Compliance

Compliance is the change in lung volume per unit change in the surrounding pressure.

It is represented by the formula:

Compliance = ΔV/ΔP

Factors Affecting Compliance

  • Lung volume: smaller the lungs, smaller is the compliance
  • For a given lung size, the compliance becomes less at extremes of lung volume
  • Compliance is slightly greater when measured during deflation than during inflation
  • If the surface tension is more, compliance is less
  • Compliance measured with saline is more than compliance measured with air.

Compliance is decreased in conditions such as:

  • Pulmonary fibrosis: Due to increased fibrous tissue in the lung, making it less elastic, and thus less expandable.
  • Alveolar edema, which prevents the expansion of some alveoli.
  • If lung remains unventilated for a long time, in a low volume lung, due to atelectasis (collapse) of lung units or increased surface tension.
  • Increased pulmonary venous pressure.

Compliance is increased in conditions such as:

  • Pulmonary emphysema
  • Normal aging lung

questions.text: A middle-aged obese man presents with a history of chest pain during exertion which lasted for around 5 minutes. He further describes his chest pain as a squeezing type of pain located in the substernal region and the pain was relieved by rest. At present, he does not have any such symptoms. The ECG obtained is given below. What will be the expected levels of his blood cardiac markers?

choices.text: Both CPK-MB and troponin-I will be elevated
Both CPK-MB and troponin-I will be normal

questions.solution:
The above scenario is suggestive of stable angina, and the assessment of blood cardiac markers is expected to show normal levels of both CPK-MB and troponin-I. The ECG given is also normal because the patient does not have any symptoms at the time of presentation and is at rest.  

Characteristic features of pain in stable angina:

  • Squeezing, central, substernal discomfort
  • Crescendo-decrescendo in nature
  • Typically lasts 2 to 5 min
  • Can radiate occasionally to the neck, jaw, epigastrium, shoulders, and left arm

Angina is rarely localized below the umbilicus or above the mandible. Myocardial ischemic discomfort does not radiate to the trapezius muscles; this radiation pattern is more typical of pericarditis.

questions.text: A scuba diver was inadvertently present at a site near an underwater blast. He was completely submerged underwater at the time of the blast. Which of the following structures is most likely to be injured in this scenario?
questions.solution:
The most commonly injured organ in underwater blast injuries when completely submerged in water is the gastrointestinal tract.

Underwater blast injuries are the direct result of a primary blast or overpressure. At moderate distances from the charge, the increased viscosity almost completely eliminates the possibility of injury from fragments (also known as secondary injuries). Injuries are more common in air containing viscus. Although there are occasionally lesions in the liver, injuries are most commonly seen in the intestinal tracts followed by lungs as a result of epithelium and microvasculature bursting into air spaces.

Blast injuries in land areas causes shock waves known as air-blast. The shock waves pass through the body and generally the homogeneous tissues like liver and muscle are not damaged. Blast injury of lungs is seen if the victim is within a few metres of explosion. The tympanic membrane most commonly ruptures in blast injuries with haemorrhage in the ear.

Blast injuries are multisystem life-threatening injuries that are caused by explosions. These injuries can be classified into the following types,

  • Primary blast injuries: They result from the rapid overpressure or shock waves produced by an explosion. These injuries result from the dramatic changes in barometric pressure projected from the point of detonation. Primary blast injuries predominantly cause damage to air-filled hollow organs of the body from rapid pressure change (barotraumas). Damage to air-filled organs includes the tympanic membrane, lungs, and GIT.
  • Secondary blast injury: It refers to the effect of fragments that are accelerated away from the device following detonation. Sources of fragments include the casing of the device or purposefully placed fragments within the device(such as nails, and bolts) or nearby objects including glass and stones.
  • Tertiary Blast Injury: Injuries resulting from the victims being thrown by the high winds produced by the blast waves.
  • Quaternary blast injury refers to a miscellaneous group of injuries that do not fall within other categories. examples include burns and inhalational injuries.
  • Quinary injury is a more novel concept, referring to injury caused by the intentional addition of either biologically or radioactively active material to an explosive device.

  • When the explosion is in the water the pressure changes are called underwater blast. Intestinal damage is very common in underwater blast injuries.
  • Solid blast refers to the wave of energy that spreads through the rigid structure when an explosive is detonated near it and people in contact with its structure can be injured.
  • Caecum is most sensitive to intestinal blast injury.

questions.text: A 29-year-old  woman who is on oral warfarin therapy following mitral valve replacement has come with complaints of amenorrhoea for 8 weeks. A urine pregnancy test was done and was found to be positive. What should she be advised?

choices.text: Continue oral warfarin until 12 weeks of pregnancy, then switch to heparin up to 36 weeks of pregnancy
Continue oral warfarin until 12 weeks of pregnancy, then switch to heparin till 7 days postpartum
Switch to heparin until 12 weeks of pregnancy, then continue warfarin till 7 days postpartum
Switch to heparin until 12 weeks of pregnancy, then continue warfarin up to 36 weeks of pregnancy

questions.solution:
Switch to heparin until 12 weeks of pregnancy, then continue warfarin up to 36 weeks of pregnancy. 

Warfarin, although safe for the mother, can lead to warfarin embryopathy, miscarriage, IUGR, and stillbirth. Hence, it must be avoided in the first trimester. Heparin is safe for the fetus as it does not cross the placenta but is less effective than warfarin. Low molecular weight heparin (LMWH) or unfractionated heparin (UFH) is used. For patients taking LMWH, Factor Xa levels should be monitored weekly. 

Heparin is restarted at 36 weeks of gestation. It should be discontinued just before (at least 6 hours before) delivery. If delivery occurs before discontinuation and there is extensive bleed­ing, then intravenous protamine sulfate can be given. Heparin anticoagulation is restarted after 6 hours of vaginal delivery and is continued up to 7 days postpartum. Later, warfarin is to be continued.

Warfarin, LMWH, and UFH do not accumulate in breast milk and do not have an anticoagulant effect in the newborn. They are compatible with breastfeeding.

questions.text: A 30-year-old hepatitis B positive patient presenting with severe abdominal pain is taken for an exploratory laparotomy, and an infarcted small bowel is resected. Tests are negative for p- ANCA. Arterial biopsy from the resected specimen reveals the following. What is the likely diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
This patient's clinical features and the histopathological image showing fibrinoid necrosis of an artery with a mixed inflammatory infiltrate containing neutrophils, eosinophils, and mononuclear cells along with negative p-ANCA are suggestive of polyarteritis nodosa (PAN). 

PAN is a systemic vasculitis of small or medium-sized muscular arteries. It typically involves the renal (most commonly involved) and visceral vessels. It has no association with ANCA, but about 30% of patients have chronic hepatitis B. It is the most common vasculitis associated with mononeuritis multiplex. Impaired perfusion with ulcerations, infarcts, ischemic atrophy, or hemorrhages may be the first sign of disease. It characteristically spares the pulmonary circulation.

The patients may present with rapidly accelerating hypertension due to renal artery involvement or abdominal pain and bloody stools caused by gastrointestinal vessel involvement.

Other options:

Option A: Microscopic Polyangiitis is a necrotizing vasculitis that affects capillaries, small arterioles, and venules. It is associated with MPO-ANCA. It is also called leukocytoclastic vasculitis because of apoptotic neutrophils. All lesions of microscopic polyangiitis tend to be of the same age in any given patient, unlike polyarteritis nodosa where all stages of activity from early to late may coexist in different vessels or even within the same vessel.

The image below shows small vessel vasculitis with granulomatous inflammation with fibrinoid necrosis:


Option B: Behcet disease is a neutrophilic vasculitis affecting small- to medium-sized vessels that classically presents as a clinical triad of recurrent oral aphthous ulcers, genital ulcers, and uveitis. There can also be gastrointestinal and pulmonary manifestations, with disease mortality related to severe neurologic involvement or rupture of vascular aneurysms.

Option C: Giant cell arteritis is an inflammatory vasculitis of large vessels. It shows medial granulomatous inflammation which usually involves the temporal artery. It is commonly seen in females over 50 years of age who present with fever, anemia, and headache and may have tenderness over the affected artery, scalp pain, jaw, and tongue claudication. Untreated patients may develop ischemic optic neuropathy.

questions.text: A 64-year-old male patient with Crohn’s disease presents with red tender swellings  on the anterior surface of lower legs, ankles, thighs, and arms as shown in the image. What is the most likely diagnosis ?
questions.solution:
The given image and the clinical features of red tender swellings in a patient with Crohn’s disease are suggestive of erythema nodosum.

The most common infectious cause of erythema nodosum is group A beta-hemolytic streptococcus infection.

Aetiological factors in erythema nodosum:

  • Infections: Group A β-hemolytic streptococcus infection, leprosy, Brucella, toxoplasmosis, Mycoplasma pneumoniae, CMV, E. coli, Yersinia, tuberculosis
  • Idiopathic, pregnancy
  • Drugs including oral contraceptives, hormonal replacement therapy, sulphonamides, and penicillin
  • Sarcoidosis, SLE, RA, Reiter's syndrome
  • Ulcerative colitis, Crohn's disease, Behcet's disease
  • Malignancy

It is the result of a non-specific cutaneous reaction to various antigens. It is postulated to be a type IV delayed hypersensitivity reaction to various antigens. The prodromal phase includes fever, joint, and muscle pains, and an alteration in general health. It is followed by the development of painful, tender, nodules on the extensor surfaces of the legs, knees and forearms. It usually resolves spontaneously in about 10 days. Treatment is mostly supportive.

The image below shows erythema nodosum.

Dermatologic manifestations of IBD are as follows:

Option A) Pyoderma gangrenosum: UC > CD, runs a course independent from bowel disease activity. Begins as a pustule, ulcerates circumferentially, is seen commonly on the dorsal surface of feet and legs, and may occur on arms, chest, and face.
Option C) Sweet’s syndrome: acute febrile neutrophilic dermatosis, seen in UC.
Option D) Ecthyma gangrenosum is a skin infection caused by Pseudomonas aeruginosa. It is often seen in immunocompromised patients such as those with neutropenia. It presents as a round/oval lesion, 1 to 15 cm in diameter, with a halo of erythema and a necrotic center.

questions.text: A study was conducted on 200 individuals. 100 of them had a history of occupational exposure to asbestos and 100 of them did not. From the data in their past investigations, the incidence of asbestosis was derived. In addition to this, the study population was followed up for a period of 20 years to find out the incidence of malignant mesothelioma in the study population. The study is a typical example of:
questions.solution:
It is a combination of both retrospective and prospective cohort studies (i.e., ambispective cohort study).

In the above study, the incidence of asbestosis is arrived at using the retrospective component of the cohort study and the incidence of malignant mesothelioma is arrived at from the prospective component of the cohort study.

In case-control studies often called “retrospective studies”, the progression is from effect to cause. In such cases the outcome has already occurred. It is a common first approach to test the causal hypothesis (this is not the case in the study in question).

Related Pearl: Cohort Study

  • A cohort study progresses from cause (exposure) to effect (disease).
  • It is also known as forward-looking study, incidence study, prospective study, and longitudinal study.
  • Design of a cohort study:
    • Types of cohort study:
      • Prospective (concurrent) cohort studies
      • Retrospective (historical) cohort studies
      • Combination cohort studies
    • Steps of cohort study:
      • Selection of study subjects
      • Obtaining data on exposure
      • Selection of comparison groups
      • Follow-up
      • Analysis in terms of incidence rates and estimation of risk
    • Advantages of cohort study:
      • Incidence can be calculated
      • Several possible outcomes related to exposure can be studied at the same time
      • Provides direct estimate of relative risk
      • Calculation of dose-response ratio
      • Minimization of certain biases
    • Disadvantages of cohort study:
      • Cannot use for uncommon diseases
      • Expensive, requires a large population and longer time
      • Many common administrative and ethical problems
      • High attrition and selection of subjects is difficult
      • Dynamism of diagnostics is difficult to incorporate
      • Tends to alter the behaviour of subjects known as Hawthorne effect.

Related Pearl: Case Control Study

In a case-control study, progression is from effect (disease) to cause (exposure) as the outcome or disease has already occurred. It is also called a retrospective study.

Design of case-control study:

 

  • Steps of case control study:
    • Selection of cases and controls
    • Matching
    • Measurement of exposure
    • Analysis in the form of exposure rates, risk ratio, and odds ratio
  • Advantages of case control study:
    • Easy to carry out, rapid and inexpensive
    • Requires few subjects, no risk to subjects
    • Used to investigate rare diseases
    • Different etiological factors can be studied and risk factors can be identified
    • No attrition problems, minimal ethical problems
  • Disadvantages of case control study:
    • Relies on memory or past records giving rise to bias
    • Selection of appropriate control groups is difficult
    • Incidence cannot be measured
    • Does not distinguish between causes and associated factors
    • Not suited for evaluation of therapy or prophylaxis
    • Representativeness of the cases and controls is often inadequate

questions.text: The dose-response curves of isoprenaline for cardiac stimulation and bronchodilation are separated from each other owing to which of the following?
questions.solution:
The significant separation between the two curves on the dose-response curve (DRC) indicates that the dosage needed to elicit one effect is considerably greater than the other. This occurs because of selectivity at different doses.

The graph shown below depicts that at lower doses, the selective response is bronchodilation. While at higher doses the selective response is cardiac stimulation.


Dose response curve depicts potency, efficacy of a drug which is used to compare different drugs on the basis of their efficacy and potency. For example : Pethidine is less potent but equally efficacious as morphine and furosemide is less potent but more efficacious diuretic than metolazone.

A drug can produce more than one action, the DRCs for different effects of a drug may be different. The extent of separation of DRCs of a drug for different effects is a measure of its selectivity at different doses. For example : Isoprenaline has similar DRCs for bronchodilation and cardiac stimulation, making it less selective. In contrast, salbutamol has widely separated DRCs for these effects, making it a more selective bronchodilator.

questions.text: A 38-year-old female has been diagnosed with cervical cancer. Her doctor thinks that a hysterectomy would be the best option. However, the patient expresses her wishes to preserve fertility. An alternative conservative surgery called vaginal radical trachelectomy was decided. What could have been the possible stage of her cancer?
questions.solution:
The possible stage of cervical cancer in this scenario is likely stage IIA1. Vaginal radical trachelectomy is a conservative surgical option recommended for women with stage IA1 to IIA1 cervical cancer who desire fertility preservation.

Stage IIA1 cervical cancer involves tumor invasion into the upper two-thirds of the vagina without parametrial involvement, with the greatest dimension of the tumor being < 4 cm. Vaginal radical trachelectomy with pelvic lymphadenectomy (PLND) is an option for those who wish to preserve fertility. Other treatment options for this stage include radical hysterectomy with PLND for those who do not wish to preserve fertility or chemoradiation.

Carcinoma cervix is the fourth most common gynecological cancer worldwide, with human papillomavirus infection being the most important risk factor. Treatment modalities include surgery, chemoradiation, or palliative care depending on the stage and fertility concerns.

Surgeries include hysterectomy or radical trachelectomy. Vaginal radical trachelectomy is done if the tumor is < 2 cm in its greatest dimension. An abdominal radical trachelectomy is done for larger tumors (> 2 cm).

Surgery in carcinoma cervix is not done for stages IIB to IV (Option A). Bulky tumors (Option B and D) in stages IB3 to IIA2 also make operative removal difficult. Hence, chemoradiation or palliative care is indicated in these scenarios.

Related Pearl: Staging of Carcinoma Cervix

Stage I - limited to the cervix

  • A: Microscopic lesion
    • A1 - stromal invasion <3mm depth
    • A2 - a stromal invasion of ≥3 and <5mm depth
  • B: Macroscopic lesion
    • B1 - stromal invasion ≥5mm depth & tumor size <2cm 
    • B2 - tumor size ≥2cm to <4cm 
    • B3 - tumor size ≥4cm 

Stage II - involves upper 2/3 of vagina

  • A: Extends to the upper two-thirds of the vagina without parametrial involvement
    • A1 - tumor size <4cm 
    • A2 - tumor size ≥4cm 
  • B: Extends to parametrium but not upto the pelvic wall.

Stage III - spreads to lower 1/3 of vagina

  • A: Extends to lower 1/3 of the vagina
  • B: Extends to the pelvic wall (hydronephrosis/non-functioning kidney)
  • C: Involvement of the pelvic and/or para-aortic lymph nodes, irrespective of the tumor size and extent
    • C1: pelvic lymph node involved
    • C2: para-aortic lymph node involved

Stage IV - metastasis

  • A: Bladder/bowel involvement (adjacent pelvic organs)
  • B: Distant metastasis

Note: The involvement of vascular/lymphatic spaces does not change the staging. The lateral extent of the lesion is no longer considered.

Stage IIIB is the most common stage of presentation.

questions.text:
A young child has recently been diagnosed with type I diabetes mellitus. Which of the following components is implicated in the hypersensitivity observed in this condition?

NK - Natural killer
questions.solution:
Type I diabetes mellitus is an example of a type IV hypersensitivity reaction which is mediated by the T-cells.

Type IV hypersensitivity, also known as cell-mediated hypersensitivity, is mediated by CD4+ and CD8+ T-cells. Effector CD4+ T-cells recognize antigens and release cytokines causing inflammation. CD8+ cytotoxic T-cells kill targeted cells. Classic examples of this type of hypersensitivity include contact dermatitis, the tuberculin test, type I diabetes, and some subtypes of transplant rejection reactions. 

Type 1 diabetes is an auto-immune condition where there is T-cell mediated inflammation and destruction of islet cells by cytotoxic CD8+ T-cell. There is progressive destruction of β cells causing absolute insulin deficiency and decreased glucose uptake in the tissues. The underlying pathophysiology involves a combination of genetic susceptibility and environmental triggers (often associated with previous viral infections).

Islet cell autoantibodies (ICAs) are several antibodies that are directed against pancreatic islet molecules. Most patients with type 1 diabetes mellitus are positive for one of these antibodies. These include:

  • anti-GAD65 (glutamic acid decarboxylase 65)
  • anti-insulin
  • anti-ZnT-8 (zinc transporter 8)
  • anti-islet cell

The presence of ICAs also indicates a risk of developing type 1 diabetes mellitus in the future, if the patient does not have the overt disease at the moment. However, the ICAs themselves are not responsible for the destruction of beta cells. Beta cell destruction is mediated by CD8+ T cells.

questions.text:
In the neonatal ward, you perform the reflex examination as shown below. Which of the conditions would you include in your differential diagnosis if the reflex is absent in the neonate?



HIE- Hypoxic Ischemic Encephalopathy
questions.solution:
The reflex demonstrated in the given image is Moro’s reflex. The reflex is absent is Kernicterus.

Absent Moro reflex is seen in conditions in which there is a generalized disturbance of the central nervous system(CNS) like stage III -hypoxic ischemic encephalopathy (HIE) and kernicterus. Kernicterus is characterized by the deposition of unconjugated bilirubin in the basal ganglia and brain stem thereby causing generalized dysfunction of the CNS.

Moro’s reflex is a primitive reflex which is very sensitive to the infant's level of alertness. It can be elicited by supporting the infant in the semi erect position and allowing the infant’s head to fall backwards onto the examiner’s hand. Normal response to Moro's reflex - symmetrical extension and abduction of the upper extremities, followed by flexion of the upper extremities. The Moro reflex disappears by 6 months of age in normal infants.

Asymmetric Moro reflex: feature of root, plexus, or nerve disease

  • Fractured clavicle
  • Brachial plexus injury (Erb's palsy)
  • Hemiparesis

Brisk Moro reflex is seen in:

  • Neonatal hypoglycemia
  • Can also be a normal variant in healthy infants
  • Stage I HIE

questions.text: A patient diagnosed with a fistula-in-ano was managed with the following technique. Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding this technique?

choices.text: It maintains drainage and induces fibrosis
Should be left in place for 3 months

questions.solution:
The given image shows the seton technique. The seton should be non-absorbable, non-degenerative, and comfortable.

The Seton technique is used in the management of fistula-in-ano. A seton is a drain placed through a fistula to maintain drainage and/or induce fibrosis. Setons can be classified as draining or cutting. 

In loose/draining seton method, the seton is placed to maintain drainage and create scar tissue around the sphincter so that its edges do not retract after cutting.It is left in place for 3 months. Seton's technique induces fibrosis and has very good evidence of healing. 

For fistulas that involve more than 30% of the sphincter or those which are distal to the dentate line, loose placement of seton through the track helps to facilitate drainage of any sepsis and to preserve the sphincter.

Cutting seton has been used as a staged fistulectomy, especially in high trans-sphincteric fistulas. This is achieved by gradually tightening at regular intervals to promote fibrosis and to slowly cut through the involved sphincter muscle, thus helping in eliminating the fistula while maintaining the continuity of the sphincter.

The other techniques used in the management of anal fistulas are:

  • Fistulotomy involves opening the fistula tract and possibly dividing the sphincter muscle. It is very effective for simple fistulas with minimal sphincter involvement. 
  • Fistulectomy involves completely cutting out the fistulous tracts.
  • Endorectal advancement flap- involves closure of the internal opening of the tract, debridement of the tract, and mobilization of anorectal mucosa to cover the defect. It is usually done for complex fistulas. 
  • LIFT- Ligation of the intersphincteric fistula tract involves identification of the internal opening with suture ligation of the intersphincteric portion of the fistula. The tract and infected gland are then excised and the wound is debrided with curettage. It can be done for both simple and complex fistulas.

questions.text:
A 70-year-old man with a mature cataract was planned for phacoemulsification surgery. What is the correct sequence of the surgical steps in this surgery?

1. Irrigation - Aspiration 
2. Hydrodelineation
3. Hydrodissection
4. Continuous curvilinear capsulorhexis
questions.solution:
The correct sequence of the surgical steps in phacoemulsification surgery includes clear corneal incision → continuous curvilinear capsulorhexis→ hydrodissection→ hydrodelineation→ irrigation-aspiration→ implantation

The preferred method for cataract surgery involves phacoemulsification-assisted extracapsular cataract extraction combined with foldable posterior chamber intraocular lens implantation in a bag. The steps for phacoemulsification are given below along with the image:

Step 1 - small clear corneal incision 
Step 2 - continuous curvilinear capsulorhexis
Step 3 - hydro dissection, which also facilitates rotation and manipulation of the nucleus during emulsification of the lens
Step 4 - hydro delineation is done in some cases. This is done by injecting fluid between the nucleus and epinuclear lens substance. It aids in the separation of the cortex from the nucleus
Steps 5 and 6 - indicate the divide and conquer technique for the removal of the nucleus after phacoemulsification
Step 7 - removal of the cortical lens matter using an irrigation-aspiration technique
Step 8 - implantation of a foldable lens

Related Pearl: Different extracapsular cataract extraction (ECCE) techniques

Conventional ECCE

  • Incision: 10 to 2 o'clock
  • Anterior capsulotomy
    • Can opener’s technique
    • Envelope technique
    • Continuous circular capsulorrhexis

Manual SICS

  • Incision: 4-6 mm
  • A self-sealing sclerocorneal tunnel incision is made.

Phacoemulsification

  • Incision:1.5–2.4 mm
  • Phacoprobe and foldable IOL is used
  • Sutureless surgery is possible with self-sealing sclerocorneal tunnel or clear corneal incision.

Related Pearl: Complications of cataract surgery

Early postoperative complications

Occurs within the first few days to 4 weeks.

  • Endophthalmitis
  • Retained lens matter
  • Corneal edema
  • Wound leak and dehiscence
  • Toxic anterior segment syndrome

Late postoperative complications

Occurs within months to years.

  • Posterior capsule opacification (most common)
  • Cystoid macular edema
  • Secondary glaucoma
  • Retinal detachment
  • Intraocular lens malpositions:
    • Windshield wiper syndrome— intraocular lens haptic rubs on the endothelium
    • Sunset syndrome—inferior subluxation
    • Sunrise syndrome—superior subluxation
    • Complete dislocation of the intraocular lens.

questions.text: A child with attention deficit hyperactive disorder was prescribed amphetamine in order to increase the attention span and improve behavioral performance. This drug belongs to which category?
questions.solution:
Amphetamine is a CNS stimulant and belongs to schedule X drugs requiring a special license for manufacturing and sales.

They have high abuse liability and are to be sold with a valid prescription only. The chemist must maintain a prescription in duplicate, separate license requirements, meticulous storage, and dispensing records.

The Drugs and Cosmetics Rules, 1945 are the set of rules under The Drugs and Cosmetics Act,1940 which contains provisions for the classification of drugs under given schedules and there are guidelines for the storage, sale, display, and prescription of each schedule.

Any stereoisomeric form of the substance, any salt of the substance, or the preparations containing the substances specified in this schedule is covered by schedule X.

These drugs include

  • Amobarbital
  • Glutethimide
  • Pentobarbital
  • Ketamine hydrochloride
  • Amphetamine
  • Meprobamate
  • Phencyclidine
  • Barbital
  • Methamphetamine
  • Phenmetrazine
  • Cyclobarbital
  • Dexamphetamine
  • Methylphenidate

questions.text: An immunocompromised patient is diagnosed with an opportunistic infection that affects the gastrointestinal system. Biopsy reveals the oocytes as shown below. Identify the stain most likely used for the diagnosis of this parasite.
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of opportuistic infection in an immunocompromised patient due to a parasite infection that affects the gastrointestinal system is suggestive of Cryptosporidium parvum infection. This is further confirmed by the image which shows uniformly acid-fast oocysts 4-5 μm in size. Ziehl Neelsen staining is used to stain acid-fast parasites like Cryptosporidium parvum.

Staining techniques can be classified into:

  • Simple stains which provide color contrast to all bacteria uniformly (eg. methylene blue or basic fuchsia),
  • Negative stains that provide a uniformly coloured background against which the unstained bacteria stand out (Indian ink, nigrosin etc) and
  • Differential stains which stain bacteria differently depending on the characteristics of the organism (gram stain, acid fast stain).

Other options:

Option A: Nigrosin is a negative staining technique used for identification of bacterial capsules which do not take simple stains, or very slender bacteria like spirochetes.

Option B: Albert's stain is a special stain used to identify the granules of Corynebacterium diphtheriae that take up a bluish purple colour.

Option C: Gomori’s methenamine silver stain is used to identify Pneumocystis jirovecii, which classically appear as crushed ping-pong balls. 

Related Pearl: Various stains and their applications in microbiology

A. Simple stains: Provides color contrast but gives same color to all bacteria and cells.

Type of stain Applications
Acidic stains

These include eosin, acid fuchsin, rose bengal, congo red, etc.

Used to stain pathological specimens
Basic stains.

Loeffler’s methylene blue stain is used in Quellung reaction. 

Polychrome methylene blue is used in McFadyean’s reaction.
Neutral stains

Wright and Giemsa stains are Romanowsky stains used to stain peripheral blood and bone marrow smears.  

Giemsa stain is used for histopathological diagnosis of malaria and other protozoan blood parasites.  

 

B. Differential stains: Imparts different colors to different bacteria. (These contain more than one stain).

Type of stain Applications
Gram stain: To differentiate between gram positive (stain purple/violet) and gram negative bacteria (stain pink or red).
Acid-fast stain:  Used in Ziehl–Neelsen staining technique for identification of acid–fast microorganisms such as M. tuberculosis, M. leprae, and Nocardia.
Fluorochrome staining: Auramine-rhodamine is used in fluorochrome staining for screening for tuberculosis.

C. Special stains:

Type of stain Applications
Staining volutin-containing organisms Corynebacterium diphtheriae stained by Albert’s stain. Green colored bacilli showing "chinese-letter" pattern, containing bluish-black metachromatic granules of cells.
Flagella stain Salmonella typhimurium stained by modified Ryu stain to show peritrichous flagella
Endospore stain Used in Schaeffer and Fulton staining technique to stain the endospores, where the primary stain is malachite green, and the counterstain is safranin.
Capsule stain Used in negative staining (Cryptococcus neoformans), McFadyean’s reaction, Polychrome methylene blue (anthrax bacilli).
Silver impregnation Fontana’s silver impregnation method used for staining treponeme and leptospire.
Silver staining Used in Grocott’s – Gomori’s methenamine silver stain. GMS stain is used to identify Pneumocystis jirovecii, which classically appear as crushed ping-pong balls.   Warthin–starry silver stain for spirochetes.
Calcofluor white staining The cell walls of fungi will bind the stain calcofluor white. It is especially useful for the identification of mucor and the causative agents of zygomycosis.  It is also used in staining acanthamoeba
Chance's staining For cell wall demonstration

questions.text: A first-year medical student was asked to demonstrate ESR estimation using the Westergren method. Which vaccutainer should he choose for collecting the blood sample?
questions.solution:
A light blue vacutainer with sodium citrate is used for ESR estimation using the Westergren method. It is also used for coagulation studies.

Other options:

Option A: Grey vacutainers are used for the estimation of blood glucose. It contains sodium fluoride which inhibits glycolysis.

Option C: Red vacutainers contain no additives. They are used for serum chemistry tests, serology tests, and in blood banks, where serum is required for cross-matching.

Option D: Dark green vacutainers contain heparin. It is mainly used for arterial blood gas estimation and osmotic fragility testing.

Related Pearl: Anticoagulants in Vacutainers and their Uses

questions.text: A 64-year-old male patient who is admitted to the intensive care unit for pneumonia suddenly develops breathing difficulty and tachycardia. On auscultation, there are decreased breath sounds on the right side. A portable chest X-ray was taken in the supine position, and it showed the deep sulcus sign.  What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical vignette, sudden deterioration in pre-existing pneumonia with reduced breath sounds suggests secondary spontaneous pneumothorax and the presence of the deep sulcus sign on the chest X-ray confirms the diagnosis. 

A deep sulcus sign is a supine radiograph finding indicative of pneumothorax. The costophrenic angle is abnormally deepened when the pleural air collects laterally, producing the deep sulcus sign. In a supine film (common in the ICU), it may be the only indication of pneumothorax because air collects anteriorly and basally within the nondependent portions of the pleural space.

In chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) patients there may be the presence of deepened costophrenic angles due to hyperinflation of the lungs which can cause a false deep sulcus sign.

The image below shows the deep sulcus sign seen on a chest radiograph:

Pneumothorax is the accumulation of air within the pleural space. It may occur as a result of trauma, surgery, needle aspiration, central line insertion, increased pressure from mechanical ventilation, lung diseases or other conditions.

Other chest radiograph findings in pneumothorax:  

  • Visceral pleural edge appears as a very thin, sharp white line and no lung markings are seen peripheral to this line.
  • The peripheral space is radiolucent when compared to the adjacent lung.
  • The lung may completely collapse.
  • The mediastinum should not shift away from the pneumothorax unless there is the presence of a tension pneumothorax.
  • Subcutaneous emphysema and pneumomediastinum may also be present.

questions.text: Identify the true statement about the method of contraception shown in the image below.

choices.text: It cannot be used in the puerperal period
It is impermeable to cytomegalovirus, hepatitis B and HIV.
Male partner should use a condom to increase the efficacy
Should be fitted and removed only by a medical professional

questions.solution:
The image shows a female condom and it is impermeable to HIV, Hepatitis B, and cytomegalovirus.

The female condom, also known as femidom or femshield is a pre-lubricated polyurethane cylindrical sheath with a flexible ring at both ends. The outer open ring remains outside the vagina and the inner closed ring is fitted beneath the cervix. 

 

 

It can be fitted by the patient hours before intercourse, and easily removed soon after. It covers the cervix, vagina, and external genitalia and is protective against sexually transmitted diseases. It can also be worn in the puerperal period, unlike the cervical diaphragm.

The female condom should not be used along with a male condom because if worn together they may slip, tear, or become displaced.

Other barrier methods of contraception include:

  • Male condom
  • Cervical cap
  • Cervical diaphragm - used with or without a spermicidal agent
  • Vaginal sponge

questions.text: A middle-aged man came to the casualty with history of pelvic trauma following road traffic accident. You are asked to apply a pelvic binder to this patient. At what level is the pelvic binder applied ?
questions.solution:
The pelvic binder should be applied at the level of greater trochanters of the hip.(Option A)

The pelvic binder is routinely used as initial management of pelvic injuries especially if associated with polytrauma, external bleeding or hemodynamic instability. The use of an pelvic binder has almost eliminated the use of external fixators on the pelvis.

The pelvic binder acts by closing the pelvis volume and thereby providing temporary hemodynamic stability to the patient. Nonetheless further assessment through radiological investigations such x-ray pelvis AP view and CT pelvis 3-D reconstruction is important for further definitive management of pelvic injuries.

Ideally binders should not be left for more than 24 hours in view of pressure sores , but if there is no availability of emergency facility to stabilize the hemodynamic compromise then it can be momentarily released to check for pressure sores and then reapplied if necessary.During radiological assessments like X-ray or CT scan, the pelvic binder is released after positioning the patient in order to assess the extent of pelvic injury as the pelvic binder might falsely underestimate the severity of the injury.

questions.text: A patient presents with the complaints of a painless ulcer on his penis. The complement fixation test is found to be positive. All of the following immunoglobulins are involved in this reaction, except:
questions.solution:
All the given immunoglobulins are involved in complement fixation except IgG4.

A painless ulcer over the penis with a positive complement fixation test is suggestive of the diagnosis of syphilis.

Complement cannot bind to the free antigen or antibodies directly. It can bind to those antibodies that have combined with their antigen. The ability of these antigen-antibody complexes to bind or fix complement is utilized in the complement fixation test. The test is performed in two steps and involves five reagents: antigen, antibody, complement, sheep erythrocytes, and an amboceptor (rabbit antibody to sheep RBCs). 

Compliment fixation involves the immunoglobulins IgM, IgG3, IgG1, and IgG2 (in this order).

Related Pearl: Serological tests in microbiology

Precipitation test:

  • Ascoli's thermoprecipitin test: Anthrax
  • Streptococci grouping: Lancefield technique
  • VDRL test for syphilis (slide flocculation test)
  • Kahn test for syphilis (tube flocculation test)
  • Elek gel precipitation test for C.diphtheria

Agglutination test:

  • Widal test- typhoid
  • Weil- Felix reaction- Typhus fever
  • Streptococcus MG agglutination test- Mycoplasma pneumoniae
  • Paul Bunnel test- Infectious mononucleiosis
  • Coombs test
  • Rose Waaler test- Rheumatoid arthritis
  • Microscopic Agglutination test- Leptospirosis
  • Anti streptolysin O test

Complement fixation test:

  • Wasserman reaction(syphilis)
  • Treponema pallidum immobilization test

Neutralization test:

  • Schik test for diptheria
  • Anti streptolysin O test
  • Nagler's reaction (clostridium perfringens)

questions.text:
To control bleeding in a hepatectomy, the surgical team puts a temporary clamp near the origin of the common hepatic artery. In which of the following vessels will the blood flow get affected?
  1. Right gastric
  2. Right gastroepiploic
  3. Replaced right hepatic
  4. Left gastroepiploic
  5. Left hepatic
questions.solution:
If a surgeon puts a clamp near the origin of common hepatic artery, blood flow in the right gastric, right gastroepiploic and left hepatic vessels will get affected.

The coeliac trunk is the first branch of the aorta arising from its anterior surface and supplying the embryological foregut. The branches of the celiac trunk are :

  • Left gastric artery - Supplies the lesser curvature of the stomach
  • Splenic artery - This further divides into :
    • Short gastric arteries- Supplies the fundus of the stomach
    • Left gastroepiploic artery- Supplies the greater curvature of the stomach and anastomoses with the right gastroepiploic artery
  • Common hepatic artery, which gives the following branches
    • Right gastric artery- Supplies the lesser curvature of the stomach, anastomoses with the left gastric artery
    • Gastroduodenal artery, which further divides into :
      • Right gastroepiploic artery - supplies the greater curvature of the stomach
      • Superior pancreaticoduodenal artery - supplies duodenum and head of pancreas and anastomoses with the inferior pancreaticoduodenal branch of the SMA

Common hepatic continues as proper hepatic artery which gives right and left hepatic arteries. Cystic artery arises from the right hepatic artery.

The replaced right hepatic artery arises from the superior mesenteric artery (SMA), also referred to as "replaced to the SMA". 

Other options:

Blood flow will not be affected in left gastroepiploic and replaced right hepatic artery. The left gastroepiploic originates from splenic artery.

questions.text: An 18-year-old girl who was diagnosed with SLE at 13 years of age is now refractory to standard treatment. She is prescribed a monoclonal antibody which is an anti-B-cell activator. Which of the following drugs is she prescribed?
questions.solution:
Belimumab is a monoclonal antibody that is an anti-B-cell activator. It is used in the management of lupus refractory to standard treatment. 

Belimumab inhibits the soluble form of a B cell survival factor (known as BLyS or BAFF) which promotes the formation of memory B cells and autoantibodies. It is used in combination with either cyclophosphamide or MMF in patients with lupus nephritis who do not show a response to initial therapy with steroids.

Other options:

Option A: Rozanolixizumab is a humanized IgG4 monoclonal antibody that has been recently FDA-approved for the treatment of myasthenia gravis.

Option C: Daclizumab is an IL2R antagonist that binds to CD25 and is used in the relapsing type of multiple sclerosis.

Option D: Adalimumab is an anti-TNF alpha agent used in the treatment of rheumatoid arthritis.

questions.text: A chronic alcoholic who presents with disturbed sleep and slurred speech is found to have hyperammonemia. Which of the following enzymes-cell pair would metabolize the excess ammonia in the brain?
questions.solution:
Glutamine synthetase present in the astrocytes is responsible for metabolizing ammonia in the brain. It combines ammonia with glutamate to form glutamine. It requires the hydrolysis of ATP.

By converting glutamate (which is an excitatory neurotransmitter) into glutamine this enzyme can protect the brain from excitotoxic injury. The deficiency of glutamine synthetase in neonates results in severe brain damage, multiorgan failure, and death.

Excess ammonia can cause damage to the brain in two ways : 

  • It can freely cross the blood brain barrier
  • It reacts with α-ketoglutarate to form glutamate. The resulting depletion of α-ketoglutarate then impairs function of the tricarboxylic acid (TCA) cycle in neurons.

This effect by ammonia along with the excitotoxic injury by glutamate leads to brain damage and the resultant symptoms of encephalopathy.

Other options : 

All the other 3 enzymes are not involved in ammonia detoxification in the brain:

  • Glutamate dehydrogenase converts glutamate into alpha-ketoglutarate
  • L-asparaginase hydolyzes the amino acid L-asparagine into L-aspartate and ammonia
  • Glutaminase converts glutamine into glutamate (reversal of glutamine synthase)

Related Pearl: Transport of ammonia in blood (Cahill and Cori cycle)

questions.text: Which of the following fungi shows the phenomenon shown below?
questions.solution:
The image shows germ tube formation (also known as the Reynolds Braude phenomenon), which is seen in Candida albicans.

If a few colonies of Candida albicans are inoculated in serum, the yeast cells start to form elongations called germ tubes within 2 hours, when kept at 37 °C.

It is also positive for a relatively new characterized species, Candida dubliniensis.

It is negative in Candida glabrata.

Candida is the most common cause of opportunistic mycoses in the world. Morphologically, they are yeast-like fungi. They exist as yeast and pseudohyphae (buds do not separate from parent cells) and true hyphae forms.

Candida appears as budding gram-positive cells on wet films and smears. Mycelial forms suggest colonization. On Sabouraud dextrose agar, they appear as off-white pasty colonies. Candida albicans, the most commonly implicated pathogenic species form chlamydospores on corn meal agar.

The image below shows candidal hyphae and chlamydospores.

After incubation on CHROMagar for 1–4 days, colonies are seen: Candida albicans colonies appear green, as shown below; Candida glabrata colonies appear dark purple; Candida parapsilosis colonies have a pinkish hue.

The most common species implicated in candidal infections are C. albicans, C. parapsilosis, and C. glabrata. Vaginal mucosal invasion by the organism causes vulvovaginitis, marked by pruritus and vaginal discharge. A white pseudomembranous patchy lesion called thrush can occur on the tongue, lips, or gums.

The image given below shows oral thrush.

Immunocompromised individuals are at an increased risk of systemic candidiasis, which includes candidal endocarditis and urinary tract infections.

Mucocutaneous manifestations are managed with topical nystatin or oral ketoconazole.

Related Pearl: Classification of fungus based on morphology

Fungi are classified into 4 types based on their morphology:

  • Yeast
  • Yeast-like
  • Molds
  • Dimorphic fungi

Yeast:

  • Unicellular fungi
  • Reproduces by budding
  • Oval to round forms
  • Example: Cryptococcus, Saccharomyces.

 

Yeast like:

  • Unicellular fungi
  • Reproduces by budding or binary fission
  • Spherical or oval forms
  • Pseudohyphae may be seen.
  • Example: Candida, Malassezia furfur.

 

Molds/filamentous fungi:

  • Have hyphae which may be septate or aseptate
  • Aseptate or coenocytic hyphae – Rhizopus, mucor, Lichtheimia.
  • Septate hyphae – Penicillium, Dermatophytes, Aspergillus, fusarium.

 

Dimorphic fungi

  • Filamentous forms in the culture at 220C – 250C and in the environment.
  • Yeast form in the culture at 370C and in tissues.
  • Examples – Histoplasma capsulatum, Blastomyces dermatitidis, Coccidioides immitis, Paracoccidioides brasiliensis, Talaromyces marneffei, Sporothrix schenckii.

questions.text: A young boy is being evaluated for hematuria and unilateral abdominal mass. Further history and examination reveal learning difficulties at school and ambiguous genitalia. The following eye-finding was noted as well. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The findings of hematuria and abdominal mass are suggestive of a renal tumor. This, along with aniridia (seen in the above image), abnormal genitalia, and mental retardation is suggestive of WAGR syndrome. 

WAGR syndrome has the following components:

  • Wilms tumour (W)
  • Aniridia (A)
  • Genitourinary anomalies (G)
  • Mental retardation (R)

WAGR syndrome is a contiguous gene deletion syndrome with a 50% risk of developing a Wilms tumour. It is caused due to the deletion of WT1 and PAX 6 genes on chromosome 11. 

Wilms tumour or nephroblastoma is the most common primary malignant renal tumour of childhood. It is the second most common malignant abdominal tumour in childhood after neuroblastoma. Loss of function mutation of the WT1 gene on chromosome 11p13 is commonly seen in Wilms tumor.

The other congenital syndromes associated with Wilms tumour are - 

  • Denys-Drash syndrome- Wilms tumour, early-onset renal failure, gonadal dysgenesis (male pseudohermaphroditism)
  • Beckwith-Weidemann syndrome- Wilms tumor, hemihypertrophy, organomegaly, macroglossia

Histologically, Wilms tumour is made of blastemal, stromal, and epithelial cells. The diagnosis can be confirmed by radiological investigations like CT, abdominal ultrasound, and biopsy.

Treatment depends on the stage of the disease and includes surgery, and chemotherapy, with or without radiotherapy.

Ehlers–Danlos syndrome is an autosomal dominant inherited disease of impaired collagen formation. The manifestations of this condition include blue sclera, skin and joint hypermobility, atrophic scars, and easy bruising. 

Related Pearl: Syndromic Associations of Wilms Tumor

Syndrome Mutation Features
WAGR Syndrome
  • WT1 and PAX6 deletion on Chr11p
  • Genetic basis- two-hit hypothesis
  • Wilms tumor
  • Aniridia
  • Genital anomalies
  • Mental retardation
Denys–Drash Syndrome
  • Dominant-negative missense mutation of WT1 protein
  • Genetic basis- two-hit hypothesis
  • Gonadal dysgenesis (male pseudo hermaphroditism)
  • Early-onset nephropathy
  • Gonadoblastoma
Beckwith– Wiedemann Syndrome
  • IGF-2 overexpression onWT2 region
  • Genetic basis- genomic imprinting
  • Organomegaly
  • Macroglossia
  • Hemihypertrophy
  • Omphalocele
  • Adrenal cytomegaly
  • Hepatoblastoma
  • Pancreato-blastoma
  • Adrenocortical tumors
  • Rhabdomyosarcoma

Note: Wilms tumor 1 (WT1) protein is a transcriptional activator of genes involved in normal renal and gonadal development. Therefore, genitourinary abnormalities are commonly associated with WT1 gene mutations.

questions.text: A post-op patient develops purulent discharge from the incision site. The culture report shows Staphylococcus aureus resistant to an antibiotic that binds to the terminal  D ala-D ala sequence. Which of the following antibiotics can be used to treat this infection?
questions.solution:
Daptomycin is the drug of choice for vancomycin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (VRSA).

Daptomycin acts by first binding to the cytoplasmic membrane and then forming complexes in a calcium-dependent manner. Complex formation causes a rapid loss of cellular potassium, possibly by pore formation, and membrane depolarization. This is followed by the arrest of DNA, RNA, and protein synthesis resulting in cell death.    

The given scenario is that of a skin infection secondary to VRSA. Vancomycin is the antibiotic that binds to the terminal D ala-D ala sequence of peptidoglycan units needed for bacterial cell wall synthesis.

Other options:

Option A: Ceftazidime is a third-generation cephalosporin that is ineffective in VRSA infections.

Option B: Gentamicin is an aminoglycoside which is ineffective in VRSA infections

Option C: As the culture reports already show resistance to vancomycin, this is not the answer. However, vancomycin is the drug of choice for methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA).

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman who was recently diagnosed with placenta increta comes to the clinic to discuss management options. She has an obstetric score of G2P1 and a previous history of C-section. Which of the following is associated with a favourable pregnancy outcome?

choices.text: Use of methotrexate post delivery to enhance placental autolysis

questions.solution:
Cesarean hysterectomy is indicated in cases of morbidly adherent placenta/placenta accreta spectrum. 

The placenta accreta spectrum is characterized by abnormally implanted, invasive, or adhered placenta. This occurs due to partial or complete absence of the decidua basalis and imperfect development of the Nitabuch layer. Risk factors include associated placenta previa and previous cesarean delivery as seen in this patient. 

There are three variants of this condition based on the depth of trophoblastic growth.

  • Placenta accreta, the villi are attached to the myometrium.
  • Placenta increta, the villi invade into the myometrium.
  • Placenta percreta, the villi penetrate the myometrium into the serosa.

It can be diagnosed in the antepartum period by ultrasound which will reveal loss of normal hypoechoic retroplacental zone between the placenta and uterus, placental vascular lacunae, bridging vessels, and placental bulging leading to distortion of the contour of the uterus. MRI can be performed when the ultrasound is inconclusive. However, ultrasound remains the modality of choice for diagnosis.

Management of this condition involves the following

  • Appropriate surgical, anesthesia, intensive care, and blood banking capabilities
  • Recommended scheduled delivery between 34 0/7 to 35 6/7 weeks (American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists)
  • Cesarean hysterectomy to reduce risk of maternal bleeding with placenta left in situ after delivery
  • Manual removal of the placenta should not be attempted due to the increased risk of blood loss.
  • Evidence regarding use of methotrexate in resorption of placenta is lacking.

questions.text: As an intern, you see a patient with hyperkalemia in the emergency room. Which of the following drugs would NOT be implicated in this case?
questions.solution:
β2 agonists (terbutaline) cause an intracellular shift of potassium leading to a transient decrease in potassium levels (hypokalemia). Therefore, it is used in the management of hyperkalemia.

Causes and mechanisms of drug-induced hyperkalemia

Medication Mechanism

β-blockers

 Interferes with beta-2 mediated intracellular potassium uptake.
ACE inhibitors Inhibition of angiotensin II formation with a decrease in aldosterone secretion.
Angiotensin II receptor blockers (ARBs) Blocks AT1 receptor decreasing aldosterone secretion.
Trimethoprim Blocks epithelial sodium channel in the collecting duct.

Digitalis

 Inhibition of Na+/K+/ATPase pump.

Cyclosporine

 Blocks aldosterone activity.

Succinylcholine

 Causes extracellular leakage of potassium through acetylcholine receptors.

NSAIDs

 Decreases renal perfusion resulting in decreased K+ delivery to the collecting ducts.

questions.text: A middle-aged-man presents with right hypochondriac pain and yellowish discoloration of eyes. His ultrasound is as shown in the image below. Which of the following is true about the causative agent of his condition?

choices.text: Sheep is the ideal definitive host
The larval stage is found in dogs
Mode of infection is by skin penetration

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the USG showing a cyst with detached membranes (water lily sign) are suggestive of a hydatid cyst. Hydatid disease or echinococcosis is caused by the Echinococcus species of flatworms. Humans are accidental hosts in its life cycle.

The life cycle of Echinococcus consists of dog (optimal host) and wolf as the definitive hosts, sheep and cattle as intermediate hosts. Sheep is the ideal intermediate host because transmission occurs when hydatid cysts from sheep carcass are eaten by dogs in slaughterhouses. The mode of infection is by the feco-oral route. Humans get infected following the ingestion of food items contaminated with dog feces containing the eggs of Echinococcus. Man acts as an accidental intermediate host (dead end).

The larval stage of the parasite is passed in intermediate hosts, including man, giving rise to hydatid cyst which usually develops three weeks after the infection.

The life cycle of Echinococcus granulosus is as shown in the image below:

The hydatid cyst wall consists of 3 layers:

Pericyst- the outer dense fibrous capsule that is formed as a result of host inflammatory response.
Ectocyst- the intermediate layer consisting of acellular, chitinous, laminated hyaline material.
Endocyst- the inner germinal layer that is cellular and consists of a number of nuclei embedded in protoplasmic mass and is extremely thin. It is the vital layer of the cyst and it is the site of asexual reproduction giving rise to brood capsules with scolices.

questions.text: A health care worker who had an accidental needle stick injury from a HIV positive and asymptomatic patient 36 hours ago, has come for receiving post exposure prophylaxis. Which of the following is the preferred regimen?
questions.solution:
Recommended Post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP) is a three drug regimen which includes Lamivudine 300mg, Tenofovir 300mg and Dolutegravir 50mg. A regimen for post - exposure prophylaxis for HIV with two anti retroviral (ARV) drugs is effective, but three drugs are preferred. The PEP must be initiated ideally within 2 hours and certainly within 72 hours. WHO recommended PEP regimen :

        Drugs combination   Recommendation for PEP         Duration
Tenofovir (TDF) 300 mg + Lamivudine(3TC) 300 mg + Dolutegravir (DTG) 50mg          Once daily          4 weeks

DTG is recommended as the preferred third drug for HIV post-exposure prophylaxis.
