questions.text:
A 30-year-old woman is being evaluated for ovulation function. Which of the following is seen after the ovulation has occurred?

LH- Luteinizing hormone

choices.text: Growth of ovarian follicles seen on USG

questions.solution:
An increase in basal body temperature is seen after ovulation has occurred.

The basal body temperature (BBT) decreases by around 1/2°F at the time of ovulation and then increases by 1/2-1°F during the progestational half of the cycle. This occurs due to the thermogenic action of the hormone progesterone. When this is represented graphically, a biphasic pattern is observed and is strongly predictive of ovulation, as shown in the image below.

 

However, this method cannot accurately predict ovulation. It provides a retrospective diagnosis of ovulation and is not useful therapeutically.

Other options:

Option A:  Urinary LH peak (increase in LH) is usually seen 1 day prior to ovulation and is used to predict the time of ovulation. It is detected by daily monitoring of urinary LH levels and spans for about 48-50 hours.

Option C: Growth of ovarian follicles is seen on USG prior to ovulation. The follicle is observed to grow at the rate of 1-2 mm per day before follicular rupture, and ovulation occurs when it is 20 mm or more in size. This is a reliable and safe method of predicting ovulation.

Option D: The appearance of a fern pattern is seen before ovulation. After ovulation, the progesterone thickens the cervical mucus, leading to the loss of fern pattern.

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman who had a cardiac arrest was successfully resuscitated and is being monitored in the ICU. She is comatose and has been intubated. Her current vitals are HR- 62 bpm, BP- 100/60 mm Hg, SpO2- 95%, RR- 12/min, and temperature- 36.5°C. Her present ECG is shown below. Which of the following is not part of her critical care management?

choices.text: Use of waveform capnography to monitor endotracheal tube placement
Achieving target mean arterial pressure of >65mm Hg
Coronary angiography once the patient is out of coma
Achieve a core body temperature of 32-36 degree Celsius for at least 24 hours

questions.solution:
In a post-cardiac arrest patient with features of STEMI, coronary angiography must be performed on an emergency basis, irrespective of whether the patient is awake or comatose. 

Post cardiac-arrest care is the fifth link in the chain of survival, in cardiac arrest. It involves several components aimed at improving the likelihood of patient survival after the return of spontaneous circulation (ROSC) has been achieved. This patient seems to have suffered an arrest due to an anterior wall myocardial infarction as evidenced by the ECG showing ST elevation in leads V1 to V4 and hence needs immediate angiography to treat the cause of the arrest. Any delay predisposes her to rearrest, which is accompanied by a poor prognosis.

Other options:

Option A: The use of waveform capnography is advocated to be the most reliable way to monitor endotracheal tube placement.

Option B: The goal of hemodynamic stability is to achieve a systolic BP>90 mm Hg or mean arterial pressure of >65mm Hg.

Option D: Targeted temperature management(TTM) is the only intervention demonstrated to improve neurological recovery after cardiac arrest and involves maintaining core body temperature between 32-36°C for at least 24 hours.

questions.text: A 2 day-old neonate is admitted to the NICU with complaints of poor feeding and lethargy. On examination, the baby is tachypneic. On examination , upper limb pulses were well felt and lower limb pulses were weak. Oxygen saturation in the right upper limb is 96% whereas in the lower limb it is 55%. Chest X ray shows cardiomegaly. What is the next step in the management of this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a neonate presenting with respiratory distress, differential cyanosis (difference in oxygen saturation in upper limb and lower limb or visible pink upper limbs and blue lower limbs) and weak lower limb pulses is suggestive of coarctation of aorta (CoA). The next step in the management of this condition is to maintain the patency of the ductus arteriosus with the help of prostaglandin E1 infusion.

After confirmation of the diagnosis and the neonate is stabilised, surgical repair should be performed.

Coarctation refers to a constriction or narrowing in the aorta, which can be proximal or distal to the ductus arteriosus. CoA usually presents either in infancy or in later childhood.

In infancy , once the ductus arteriosus starts to close , the infant presents as lower body hypoperfusion , respiratory distress due to congestive heart failure since blood flow through the aorta is restricted by the coarctation. 

When the ductus arteriosus is open in an infant with severe coarctation, the left-to-right shunt established during birth across the ductus arteriosus during birth is reversed to right-to-left shunt as there is the presence of coarctation above the ductus in aorta. This leads to deoxygenated blood flow to the lower limbs and no change in pulse in the lower limbs.

As the ductus arteriosus closes, there is pooling of blood in the heart leading to congestive heart failure, further leading to increased pulmonary vascular resistance as well as lack of blood flow to lower limbs (presenting as weak pulses in the lower extremities).

Treatment includes re-establishing patency of the ductus arteriosus by prostaglandin E1 infusion and heart failure medical management followed by definitive surgical management such as coarctectomy and end to end anastomosis or patch aortoplasty. Restenosis of CoA areas later in childhood are common and are treated by balloon angioplasty.

Coarctation of the aorta in older children or adolescents presents as incidental upper limb hypertension and disparity of pulses in upper limb and lower limb as radio-femoral delay. Other complaints include weakness or pain/claudication in the legs after exercise. Treatment includes symptomatic management and rarely surgical management of choice is stent angioplasty.

Other options - 

Option A - Inhaled nitric oxide (iNO) is a powerful inhaled pulmonary vasodilator. It is used in conditions such as improve pulmonary blood flow and V/Q (ventilation - perfusion)mismatch in patients with diseases that elevate pulmonary vascular resistance, such as occurs in persistent pulmonary hypertension of the newborn, primary pulmonary hypertension, and secondary pulmonary hypertension as a result of chronic excess pulmonary blood flow (e.g., ventriculoseptal defect, collagen vascular diseases).

Option B - Indomethacin is effective in closing the patent ductus arteriosus (PDA) in preterm infants before the age of 2 weeks. It is usually not effective in term neonates with PDA, hence surgical ligation is preferred in such cases. Other uses of indomethacin include prophylaxis for pulmonary hemorrhage in extremely low birth weight infants.

Option D - Diclofenac is not used in treatment of congenital heart diseases.

questions.text: A man notices multiple nicks and cuts over the angle of his jaw. Apart from a recent history of shaving, history and physical examination is non contributory. What is the most likely cause for the patient's presentation?

choices.text: Tumor involving C2-3 spinal nerve root

questions.solution:
A man notices multiple nicks and cuts over the angle of his jaw after shaving signifying absent sensory innervation at the angle of mandible. This area is supplied by great auricular nerve which originates from the cervical plexus (C2, C3). A tumor involving the cervical plexus would most likely lead to this clinical scenario.

Greater auricular nerve supplies most of the medial surface of pinna, only posterior part of the lateral surface and the angle of jaw.

Other options : 

Option B ) Pleomorphic adenoma of parotid may cause facial nerve palsy. Facial nerve is distributed within the fibres of auricular branch of the vagus which supplies the concha, retroauricular groove of pinna, posterior meatus and the outer surface of tympanic membrane. 

Option C) Meckel's cave is a dural recess of the trigeminal ganglion near the apex of the petrous portion of the temporal bone. It provides sensory supply of the face except angle of jaw. Meningioma over Meckel's cave will cause the trigeminal nerve involvement.

Option D) Glomus jugulare are slowgrowing, hypervascular tumors that arise from the dome of jugular bulb. They spread to involve hypotympanum and jugular bulb causing IXth, Xth and XIth cranial nerves palsies. It will result in dysphagia, horsness, unilateral paralysis of soft palate, pharynx(IX CN) and vocal cords (Xth CN), weakness of trapezius and sternocleidomastoid (XIth CN) and atrophy of half of the tongue (XIIth CN)

questions.text: A 48-year-old male patient presents with complaints of foggy vision. He mentions that he cannot read newspapers. He is a heavy tobacco smoker for the past 30 years. Examination revealed a centrocecal scotoma. What is the most important step in the management of this case?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of tobacco-induced optic neuropathy. Complete abstinence from smoking is the most important step in management in this case.

Tobacco-induced optic neuropathy (previously termed toxic amblyopia) is caused by excessive use of tobacco by smoking and chewing. The toxic agent involved is cyanide found in tobacco.

The illustration given below shows the pathogenesis of tobacco-induced optic neuropathy.

It is characterized by bilateral gradually progressive impairment of central vision, and a centrocecal scotoma - a type of central scotoma involving both the blind spot and macula. Fundus examination may be normal or slight temporal pallor of the disc may be seen.

Treatment includes

  • Complete cessation of tobacco and alcohol consumption.
  • Improvement may be hastened by hydroxocobalamin 1000 μg intramuscular injections weekly for 10 weeks. Though intramuscular vitamin B12 injection may hasten the recovery, eliminating the causative factor i.e. tobacco cessation should be the mainstay of treatment. 
  • Nutritional supplements.

Causes of central/centrocecal scotoma

  • Optic neuritis
  • Compressive lesion eg. pituitary adenoma
  • Optic neuropathy due to
    • Poor nutrition
    • Tobacco
    • Alcohol
  • Drug-induced optic neuropathy
  • Toxin-induced optic neuropathy
  • Hereditary optic atrophy
  • Sarcoidosis
  • Leukemia

questions.text:
Rituximab is approved for the treatment of which of the following conditions?
  1. Hodgkin’s lymphoma 
  2. Chronic lymphocytic leukemia 
  3. Rheumatoid arthritis 
  4. Granulomatosis with polyangiitis 
  5. Takayasu arteritis
questions.solution:
Rituximab is approved for use in the treatment of non-Hodgkin's lymphoma, not in Hodgkin's lymphoma. Takayasu arteritis is also not an approved indication for rituximab usage. 

FDA-approved indications for rituximab: 

  1. Chronic lymphocytic leukemia
  2. Non-Hodgkin lymphoma
  3. Microscopic polyangiitis
  4. Granulomatous polyangitis
  5. Rheumatoid arthritis
  6. Pemphigus vulgaris (moderate to severe)

Rituximab is a chimeric monoclonal antibody targeted against the CD20 receptor that is present on the surface of B lymphocytes.

Ofatumumab and obinutuzumab are the other monoclonal antibodies directed against CD20 receptors. They are also approved for use in CLL.

questions.text: A primigravida at 32 weeks of gestation presents with headache and dizziness. During the assessment, she develops a seizure. Her vitals are HR- 100 bpm, BP- 170/100 mmHg, and SpO2- 96%. She had edema of bilateral lower limbs up to her thighs. Which of the following is incorrect about further management?

choices.text: Give the full loading dose of MgSO4 irrespective of renal function status
IV furosemide 40 mg to reduce the edema and blood pressure
Prompt delivery after maternal stabilisation and single dose corticosteroid
10 U oxytocin IM or IV should be given following the delivery of baby

questions.solution:
IV furosemide 40mg to reduce edema and blood pressure. Diuretics are not given to reducing BP or edema in a patient with eclampsia.

The clinical scenario is suggestive of eclampsia, which is seizures in a pregnant female with preeclampsia. It is a condition where intravascular fluid volume is already diminished due to leaky capillaries and administration of diuretics worsens the intravascular volume deficit and causes placental hypoperfusion. Hence diuretics are not used to treat raised BP in eclampsia; they are given only if pulmonary edema is present.

Option A: Loading dose of MgSO4 is given irrespective of kidney function status. It is important to administer the standard loading dose and not to reduce it. A loading dose achieves the desired therapeutic level, and the infusion maintains the steady-state level. Only the maintenance infusion rate should be altered for those with a diminished GFR. 


Option C: The definitive management of eclampsia is the delivery of the baby as soon as possible. For gestation period <34 weeks, the baby should be delivered after a single dose of corticosteroid for lung maturation, without waiting for the second dose


Option D: 10U of oxytocin is given as usual as part of active management of the third stage of labour to prevent postpartum hemorrhage. However, syntometrine and ergometrine are avoided as they may further raise blood pressure.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man has received complete immunization against tetanus 10 years back. Now, he presents with a clean wound without any lacerations from an injury he sustained 2.5 hours ago. Which of the following should he be given now?

choices.text: Human Tetanus  globulin and single dose of toxoid

questions.solution:
In the given clinical scneario, the patient should be given a single dose of tetanus toxoid.

The patient has presented with a clean wound without any lacerations from an injury sustained 2.5 hours ago. He has already received complete immunization against tetanus 10 years ago. The patient falls under category C with a clean wound and hence the optimal treatment would be wound care with a single dose of tetanus toxoid.

The best method to prevent tetanus is by active immunization with tetanus toxoid. It stimulates the production of antitoxin in the body. The protective level of antitoxin is 0.01 IU/ml serum.

Passive immunization can be provided by human tetanus immunoglobulin or anti tetanus serum. The difference between tetanus immunoglobulin and anti tetanus serum is as tabulated below:

HUMAN TETANUS IMMUNOGLOBULIN ANTI TETANUS SERUM
The dose for all ages is 250 IU. The standard dose is 1500 IU.
It generally does not cause allergic reactions. It is prepared from equine blood and can hence cause allergic reactions.
It offers protection for up to 30 days. It offers protection for up to 7-10 days.

Human tetanus immunoglobulin is the best prophlyactic that can be used for passive immunization.

Related Pearl: Post exposure prophylaxis for tetanus

Prophylaxis is given based on patient category:

A. Full immunization or a booster dose within the past 5 years.

B. Full immunization or a booster dose > 5 years ago but < 10 years.

C. Full immunization or a booster dose > 10 years ago.

D. Unknown or never taken immunization

Category Clean wound Unclean wound
A Only wound care Only wound care
B Wound care + TT single dose Wound care + TT single dose
C Wound care + TT single dose Wound care + TT single dose + Human tetanus immunoglobulin 
D Wound care + TT complete course Wound care + TT complete course + Human tetanus immunoglobulin

questions.text:
Which of the following are examples of positive feedback?

1. Intrinsic blood coagulation
2. Parturition reflex
3. Baroreceptor reflex
4. Tendon reflex
5. Luteinizing hormone prior to ovulation
questions.solution:
Among the given examples, intrinsic blood coagulation, the parturition reflex, and luteinizing hormone prior to ovulation are examples of positive feedback mechanisms. (Option C)

Positive feedback is a type of feedback in which the initial stimulus triggers a response that deviates further from the original state.Positive feedback is seen in conditions where a physiological process has to propagate itself. These include:

  • Parturition reflex and childbirth
  • Blood clotting
  • LH surge prior to ovulation
  • Action potential

Positive feedback may sometimes lead to vicious cycles, eg. shock.

Other options: 

Statement 3: The baroreceptor reflex provides negative feedback in response to an increase in blood pressure. Increased baroreceptor discharge inhibits the tonic discharge of sympathetic nerves and excites the vagal innervation of the heart, which leads to a net decrease in heart rate and blood pressure. 

Statement 4: The tendon reflex is mediated by the Golgi Tendon organ. It responds to increased tension in the muscle by sending signals via the spinal cord to cause muscle relaxation. Thus, this is an example of negative feedback.

questions.text:
A patient sustained an injury to the spinal cord and has lost sensations of 2-point discrimination, joint position, and fine touch. However, he was able to feel pain and temperature. Which of the following statements are true regarding the tract affected in this patient?
  1. Medial lemniscus contains the decussated fibers
  2. The patient might also have a loss of vibration sensation
  3. Fibers from the spinal cord synapse in the cuneate and gracile nuclei
  4. The fibres decussate in the spinal cord
  5. Third-order neurons terminate in the thalamus
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, the patient has loss of 2-point discrimination, proprioception, and fine touch. This suggests that there is an injury to the dorsal column pathway. Statements 1, 2, and 3 are correct regarding this pathway.

The dorsal column-medial lemniscal pathway transmits the sensations of fine touch, 2-point discrimination, vibration, and proprioception. The sensations from the skin are carried through the dorsal root of the spinal nerve and dorsal root ganglion. 

  • These first-order neurons ascend in the spinal cord and synapse in the cuneate and gracile nuclei in the medulla. 
  • The second-order neurons then decussate opposite to the brainstem and travel through the medial lemniscus. Therefore, these leminisci contain decussated fibers. These neurons terminate in the ventrobasal thalamus.
  • The third-order neurons then project into the postcentral gyrus of the cerebral cortex called somatic sensory area I and the lateral parietal cortex called somatic sensory area 2.

Clinical significance: Brown-Sequard syndrome is the transection of the spinal cord on one side. Below the level of transection, there is,

  • Loss of proprioception, vibration sensation, light touch, and two-point discrimination on the same half of the body
  • Loss of motor function on the same side of the body
  • Loss of pain, heat, and cold on the opposite half of the body

questions.text: Which of the following prostacyclin analogues can be used in the management of pulmonary artery hypertension?
questions.solution:
Iloprost is a prostacyclin analogue indicated in the management of pulmonary artery hypertension. It mimics endogenous prostacyclin. It is an inhaled formulation which causes vasodilation of pulmonary vasculature. 

Side effect includes throat irritation, cough and bronchospasm. Contraindicated in cases of severe hypotension, pulmonary edema due to its vasodilatory properties.

Other prostacyclin analogues are : 

Epoprostenol is also used as a first line drug for severe pulmonary hypertension. It is administration by continuous IV infusion. Major side effects includes jaw pain, hypotension, myalgia, flushing, nausea, vomiting and dizziness. It has a short half-life (3-6 mins)  which requires immediate medical attention to pump failure. 

Treprostinil is used as first-line therapy for pulmonary hypertension due to interstitial lung disease. It is available as IV, SC, inhaled, and oral preparations. It has longer half-life (4 hours) than epoprostenol with same side effects. There's increased risk of bleeding because it inhibit platelet aggregation.

Selexipag is selective PGI2 receptor agonist. It is given as oral formulation. Side effects include headache, jaw pain, nausea, diarrhe. Drug interactions with CYP2C8 inducers/inhibitors. Dose reduction is required in moderate or severe hepatic impairment.

Other option :

Option B : Sildenafil is a PDE-5 inhibitor. It is used to treat errectile dysfunction and pulmonary hypertension.

Option C : Misoprostol is a synthetic PGE1 analog. It is used in NSAIDs induced gastric ulcer, medical abortion, induction of labour, atonic post partum hemorrhage (PPH), cervical ripening.

Option D : Dinoprost is a natural PGF2-alpha preparation. It is used in atonic PPH and induction of 2nd trimester abortion.

NOTE: Dinoprost is natural PGF2-alpha preparation, not to be confused with dinoprostone which is a synthetic analogue of PGE2.

questions.text: After 12 hours of water deprivation, which segment of the nephron would likely have a fluid osmolarity of 110 mOsm/L?

choices.text: Early part of distal convoluted tubule

questions.solution:
The early part of distal convoluted tubule (DCT) is relatively impermeable to water, so the tubular fluid is hypotonic (110 mOsm/L) in this segment of the nephron (<300 mOsm/L).

Water deprivation results in the release of antidiuretic hormone (ADH). This hormone stimulates water reabsorption from the principal cells of the renal collecting ducts. After sustained water deprivation, the tubular fluid osmolarity follows the following pattern:

  • Water and electrolyte absorption occurs in the proximal tubule. As a result, the tubular fluid is isotonic with the plasma (300 mOsm/L) irrespective of whether the final urine is concentrated or diluted (option B).
  • Free water is absorbed in the descending loop of Henle because of the hypertonic medullary interstitium. As a result, the tubular fluid becomes hypertonic ( >300 mOsm/L, even attaining 1200 mOm/L when ADH levels are high) (option C).
  • Solute absorption occurs in the thick and thin ascending limbs of the loop of Henle. They are also impermeable to water. As a result dilution of the tubular fluid occurs resulting in hypotonic fluid by the time urine reaches the DCT (<300 mOsm/L).
  • Reabsorption of solutes continues to occur in the distal convoluted tubule (DCT) which is also relatively impermeable to water. Thus, fluid in the DCT is further diluted (lowest osmolarity, even as low as 100 mOsm/L).
  • In the presence of ADH, water reabsorption occurs in the collecting ducts. Hypertonic urine is therefore formed (up to 1200 mOsm/L) (option D).

questions.text: A 22-year-old man has a history of diarrhea, stools sticking to the toilet pane, and weight loss for the past 2 years. The patient now presents with skin lesions as shown in the image. Which of the following is the best initial test to order for this patient?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of malabsorption with an image showing multiple, erythematous macules and papules over the abdomen (dermatitis herpetiformis) is suggestive of celiac disease. The best initial test to order in a patient with suspected celiac disease is anti-tissue transglutaminase antibodies (tTG).

Celiac disease is a disorder characterized by an immunological response to gluten causing damage to the proximal intestinal mucosa, and malabsorption of nutrients. The typical symptoms include weight loss, anorexia, chronic diarrhea, abdominal distension, and growth retardation. The celiac disease–specific antibodies are anti-tissue transglutaminase antibodies, endomysial antibodies (EMA), and antibodies against deamidated forms of gliadin peptides. HLA-DQ2 or DQ8 are present in most patients with celiac disease.

Complications of the disease include deficiencies of iron (most common), thiamine, vitamin B12, calcium, and vitamin D. Apart from this patients can also present with osteoporosis which can be reversed by a gluten-free diet, short stature, arthritis, and arthralgia. Extraintestinal manifestations include cardiomyopathy, erythema nodosum, dermatitis herpetiformis, peripheral neuropathies, irritability, and cerebellar ataxia. 

Endoscopy with small bowel biopsy is used as a confirmatory test to diagnose celiac disease and not as an initial test in suspected cases.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male presents with a resting tremor in his right hand, stiffness in his arms, and slow movements. On examination, he exhibits a shuffling gait and reduced arm swing while walking. Which of the following pathways is primarily affected in this patient?
questions.solution:
This is a clinical vignette of parkinsonism, characterized by a resting tremor, bradykinesia, rigidity, and postural instability, primarily results from degeneration of dopaminergic neurons in the substantia nigra pars compacta, leading to dysfunction of the nigrostriatal pathway. (Option A)

This pathway plays a crucial role in regulating voluntary movement by modulating the activity of the basal ganglia. Dysfunction of the nigrostriatal pathway disrupts the balance between dopamine and acetylcholine, contributing to the characteristic motor symptoms observed in Parkinson's disease.

The other dopaminergic pathways are - 

   Pathway    Anatomy Function
Tuberoinfundibular Cell bodies in the hypothalamus to the pituitary stalk Inhibitory control over prolactin secretion
Nigrostriatal  Cell bodies in the substantia nigra and projects to the basal ganglia Regulating voluntary motor activity
Mesolimbic  Ventral tegmentum -  project diffusely to the nucleus accumbens, amygdala, hippocampus,medial dorsal nucleus of the thalamus, and cingulate gyrus Modulates emotional expression, learning and reinforcement, and pleasure capacity.
Mesocortical  Ventral tegmentum to orbitofrontal and the prefrontal cortical regions Regulate motivation, concentration, and initiation of goal-directed and complex executive cognitive tasks.

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman presents with complaints of burning micturition for the past 6 months that does not improve with antibiotics. Her urine microscopy and culture results have been inconclusive. On examination, she has a dry vagina and pouting urethral meatus. What is the best management plan for her?
questions.solution:
Estrogen pessary/ointment/cream is the treatment of choice for senile vaginitis.

The history of burning micturition unresponsive to antibiotics and urine tests being normal, in a postmenopausal female, should prompt one to consider the diagnosis of senile vaginitis.

Senile/atrophic vaginitis is seen in post menopausal females as a result of estrogen deficiency, due to which the vaginal epithelium becomes thin and atrophic.Urinary features in the form of increased frequency and dysuria are common. Other features include dry vagina, dyspareunia and pouting urethral meatus showing low grade chronic urethritis. It is treated with topical formulations of estrogen.

Option A: Clotrimazole vaginal pessary for 7 days is the treatment of choice for vaginal candidiasis.

Option B: A 3-day course of nitrofurantoin is the treatment for urinary tract infection.

Option C: A 3 day course of nitrofurantoin, followed by a prolonged prophylactic course is the treatment for recurrent urinary tract infection.

questions.text: A liver biopsy sample is obtained from a patient with jaundice. A masson trichrome stained picture of the slide is shown below. Which cells are responsible for the deposition of the structure marked as  ‘A’?
questions.solution:
Structure marked as ‘A’ is thickened collagenous bands which stain blue with masson trichrome stain. The stellate cells or cells of Ito are primarily responsible for collagen production in liver injury.

Ito cells or hepatic stellate cells are present in the space of Disse and are mesenchymal in origin. These cells have 2 states:

  • Dormant state (common state) - They store the fat-soluble vitamin A in their lipid droplets and are a signiﬁcant source of growth factors involved in liver homeostasis and regeneration.
  • Active state - they get activated as a result of liver injury. They differentiate into myofibroblasts and are responsible for the replacement of damaged hepatocytes with collagenous scar tissue.

Other options : 

Option A) Cholangiocytes are the epithelial cells which line the bile ducts. They are normally quiescent in the liver, but they respond to injury or stress by enhanced proliferation. Responses to liver injury include biliary hyperplasia, ductular reaction, and ductopenia.

Option C) Kupffer cells are hepatic macrophages, which are responsible for removing cellular and microbial debris from the circulation, and also for secreting cytokines involved in defense.

Option D) Live sinusoidal endothelial cells (LSECs) in the liver acts as a barrier between sinusoids and the parenchyma. LSECs have anti-inflammatory and anti-fibrogenic properties as they prevent Kupffer and hepatic stellate cell activation.

questions.text: Which vitamin can particularly prevent early death in abetalipoproteinemia?
questions.solution:
In Abetalipoproteinemia, early death can be prevented by the administration of large doses of fat-soluble vitamins, particularly vitamin E.

Abetalipoproteinemia is due to loss of function mutation in the gene encoding Microsomal triglyceride transfer protein (MTP). MTP transfers lipids to nascent chylomicrons and VLDLs in the intestine and liver, respectively.

Therefore, when the MTP gene is mutated, chylomicrons, VLDL, and LDL are not produced.

Acanthocytes or spur cells are spiculated red cells with a few projections of varying size and surface distribution which are seen in abetalipoproteinemia.

Other options : 

The reason why vitamin E is used is that it helps in restoring and producing lipoproteins in the body. Other vitamins given in the options will not play such a role and hence have no beneficial effects in abetalipoproteinemia.

questions.text: Which of the following would lead to a decrease in the power of a study?

choices.text: Increasing sampling size of the study
Increasing difference between study mean and population mean

questions.solution:
Changing p value from 0.1 to 0.05 would lead to a decrease in the power of the study.

The ability to reject a false null hypothesis is called the power of a study. It is calculated by the formula 1-β where β is called Type II error. Type II error refers to rejecting the alternative (or experimental) hypothesis when it is true in reality i.e. false-negative error. 

Factors that increase the power of a study:

  • Increasing p value or probability value (from 0.05 to 0.1). This increases the chance obtaining a statistically significant result (rejecting the null hypothesis) when the null hypothesis is actually false. So, it reduces the risk of a type II error (false negative error). However, this would also result in an increase in the type I error (alpha error or false-positive error).
  • A larger size of the difference between the sample mean and the hypothesized population mean (this is known as the effect size). For example, a difference between a hypothesized population mean IQ of 135 and a sample mean IQ of 100 would be detected much more easily (and hence the null hypothesis would be rejected more easily - power of study) than a difference between a hypothesized IQ of 135 and a sample mean IQ of 128. 
  • Decreasing sampling error. The precision with which the data are measured also influences statistical power. Power can often be improved by reducing the measurement error in the data.
  • Increasing sample size. Increasing sample size is another way of boosting power of a test. This occurs because the effect size is easier to detect as the sample size increases. A large-scale study is more likely to detect a false null hypothesis (particularly if the effect size is small) than is a small-scale study. For example, if a coin is tossed 1,000 times, resulting in 600 heads and 400 tails (effect size 200), it is much easier to reject the null hypothesis (that the coin is a fair one) than if the coin is tossed 10 times and 6 heads and 4 tails are obtained (effect size 2).

questions.text:
A patient has hypercalcemia, lytic lesions on the skull, and renal failure. Urinalysis shows the presence of Bence Jones protein. What is the likely cause of this patient's hypercalcemia?

IL-1: Interleukin 1
TNF: Tumor necrosis factor

choices.text: Increased parathyroid hormone related protein production (PTHrP)
Increased osteoclastic activity mediated by IL-1 and TNF

questions.solution:
A patient with hypercalcemia, lytic lesions on the skull, renal failure, and whose urinalysis shows the presence of Bence Jones protein likely has multiple myeloma. In multiple myeloma, there is increased osteoclast activity, which is mediated by several cytokines, including interleukin-1 (IL-1) and tumor necrosis factor (TNF). This leads to increased bone turnover and the release of calcium into the bloodstream, resulting in hypercalcemia.

Multiple myeloma is a malignant plasma cell dyscrasia with the proliferation of plasma cells derived from a single clone. Myeloma cell size varies from small, differentiated cells to large immature, and undifferentiated cells.

Bone pain is the most common symptom of multiple myeloma. Tumor cells release osteoclast activating factors (OAFs), which increase osteoclast activity and accelerate bone destruction. Lysis of the bone leads to hypercalcemia. Patients with multiple myeloma also have an increased susceptibility to infections because of diffuse hypogammaglobulinemia (decreased production and increased destruction) of normal antibodies. 

Other important features of multiple myeloma include the CRAB criteria: 

  • HyperCalcemia
  • Renal dysfunction
  • Anemia
  • Bone lesions

Serum protein electrophoresis shows the presence of monoclonal protein (M spike). Urinalysis shows free kappa and lambda light chains (Bence-Jones proteins).

Other options:

Option A: Hypercalcemia due to increased PTHrP production may be seen as a paraneoplastic manifestation in various cancers e.g. squamous cell carcinoma of the lungs. 

Option B: Hypercalcemia due to unregulated 1,25-dihydroxycholecalciferol production is seen in granulomatous diseases such as sarcoidosis, and tuberculosis.

Option D: Mild hypercalcemia due to increased renal reabsorption of calcium may be seen in familial hypocalciuric hypercalcemia (FHH) a rare disorder with mutations in the calcium-sensing receptor (CASR) gene.

Related Pearl: Pathological Cells/Bodies in Multiple Myeloma

Russell bodies - They are globular intracellular accumulations of immunoglobulins (Ig). Russell bodies are distended endoplasmic reticulum. Plasma cells filled with multiple Russell bodies are called Mott cells.

  • Flame cells - Plasma cells with fiery red cytoplasm due to vermillion-staining, glycogen-rich IgA in cytoplasmic projections

questions.text: As a resident, you are learning to perform colposcopy. In which of the following conditions is colposcopy avoided?
questions.solution:
Upper reproductive tract infection is a relative contraindication to perform colposcopy.

Colposcopy is an outpatient procedure primarily used to monitor carcinoma in situ that has been treated or not, assess abnormal results from cervical cancer screening tests, and look for symptoms or indicators of the disease.

Clinical goals include giving a closer look at the cervix and vagina, cervical squamocolumnar junction identification, finding lesions that could be neoplastic, and direct biopsy of lesions.

Clinical indications include:

  • Abnormal or recurrent inadequate cervical cancer screening result
  • Grossly visible cervical lesion
  • Unexplained lower genital tract bleeding
  • Unexplained vaginal discharge

Relative contraindications include upper or lower reproductive tract infection, uncontrolled severe hypertension, and uncooperative or overly anxious patients.

questions.text: Identify the area of insertion of the deep fibers of the gluteus maximus muscle in the image shown below.
questions.solution:
The gluteus maximus muscle, which is the chief extensor of the thigh at the hip joint, has superficial and deep fibers. The deep fibers insert into the gluteal tuberosity which is the area labeled as 4 in the given image. The superficial fibers insert into the iliotibial tract. 

The other areas labeled in the image are:

1 - Greater trochanter- Insertion of gluteus medius and gluteus minimus

2 - Intertrochanteric crest 

3 - Lesser trochanter- Insertion of psoas major, iliacus

 

Gluteus maximus muscle is supplied by the inferior gluteal nerve (L5, S1, S2). It is an antigravity muscle and it plays a key role in standing up from a sitting position and maintaining an erect posture. Its other actions include lateral rotation and abduction of the thigh and knee stabilization in conjunction with tensor fasciae latae muscle. 

In this patient with Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD), gluteus maximus paralysis impairs his ability to stand up from a sitting position. This leads to a characteristic sign wherein, to stand up, the patient initially takes supports by placing his hands on his legs and then on his thighs, rising up using this support. This is known as the Gower sign. It is seen in conditions causing weakness of the pelvic girdle and/or proximal muscles of the lower limbs such as DMD, Becker muscular dystrophy, spinal muscular dystrophy, polymyositis, etc.

questions.text: An elderly man is diagnosed with a slow-growing tumor in the deep perineal pouch. Which of the following structure would be most likely affected?
questions.solution:
A tumor in the deep perineal space is most likely to affect the bulbourethral glands as they are present in the deep perineal pouch.

Contents of deep perineal pouch:

  • Membranous urethra
  • Muscles: Sphincter urethrae and deep transverse perinei muscles
  • Nerves: Dorsal nerve of penis and muscular branches of the perineal nerve
  • Vessels: Artery of penis
  • Glands: Bulbourethral glands in males

Contents of superficial perineal pouch: 

  • Corpora cavernosa and corpus spongiosum
  • Three muscles – the ischiocavernosus, bulbospongiosus and superficial transverse perineal
  • The greater vestibular glands (Bartholin’s glands) in females and duct of bulbourethral glands in males.
  • Arteries: Branches of the perineal artery (posterior scrotal and transverse perineal arteries) and branches of artery of the penis (artery to the bulb, urethral artery, deep artery of the penis and dorsal artery of the penis)
  • Nerves: Long perineal nerve, branches of the perineal nerve (posterior scrotal, nerve to bulb and muscular branches)
  • Clitoris in female
  • Urethra in male

questions.text: Pimavanserin is used to treat symptoms of psychosis in patients with Parkinson’s disease. Which of the following curves in the graph below represents the effect of this drug on its receptor?
questions.solution:
Pimavanserin is a selective inverse agonist at 5HT2A, Graph 4 represents an inverse agonist.

Graph 1 represents the agonist: An agonist is an agent which initiates the normal physiological response when combined with a receptor.
Example: Salbutamol is a beta-2 receptor agonist.
 
Graph 2 represents a partial agonist: An agent which produces a submaximal or partial effect when combined with a receptor.
Example: Buprenorphine and butorphanol are partial agonists at opioid receptors.
 
Graph 3 represents the competitive antagonist: An agent which blocks or reduces the action of an agonist on a receptor, but does not have any effect of its own.
Example: Naltrexone and naloxone are antagonists at opioid receptors
 
Graph 4 represents an inverse agonist: An agent which activates a receptor to produce an effect in the opposite direction to that of the agonist.
Example: Pimavanserin is an inverse agonist at 5HT2A and  β-Carboline is an inverse agonist at benzodiazepine site of GABA-A receptor.

questions.text: As an epidemiologist, you are studying the association between the incidence of COVID-19 pneumonia and a history of chronic lung disease by gathering history of chronic lung disease from patients hospitalized for COVID-19 pneumonia. However, no association is found as many patients with COVID-19 pneumonia had died as a result of the illness or had been discharged due to a lack of beds. This kind of bias is known as:
questions.solution:
The given scenario is suggestive of Neyman's bias.(Option D)

A Bias is a systemic error in the determination of an association between an exposure and a disease. Neyman’s or prevalence-incidence bias occurs in case-control studies when exposure affects both the disease and the disease-induced mortality. In the given question, the cases are interviewed about whether or not they had a prior history of lung disease to establish an association between the probable risk factor and the disease, however, due to the high mortality rate of COVID-19 pneumonia you would receive a skewed data because of loss of data from those who had fatal disease or accumulation of data only from those with mild to moderate to severe disease. Also, it has been shown that Neyman's bias occurs only in fatal diseases.

Other options:

Option A: Hawthorne bias occurs due to a change in attitude or actions of the subjects when they are aware they are under observation.

Option B: Berkesonian bias applies to hospital-based case-control studies. Occurs due to differential hospital admission rates of the cases and the controls.

Option C: The interviewer's bias occurs when the person conducting the case-control study knows the hypothesis and who the cases are. This may lead to the interviewer questioning the cases more thoroughly than the controls regarding the history of the causal factor.

Related Pearl: Bias in Epidemiological Studies

Type of Bias Definition Methods to reduce it
Observer bias Differential ability to observe. A subjective bias.  
Interviewer's bias Interviewer asking leading questions to the subjects. Or interviewing cases thoroughly than the controls.  Double blinding
Memory/ Recall bias Differential ability of cases and controls to recall a certain detail. An objective bias. Decrease time from exposure to follow-up
Surveillance bias Active surveillance leads to an increased chance of identifying the event.  
Reporting/ notification bias Diseases associated with stigma are reported less.  
Berkesonian bias Hospital-based case-control studies. Occurs due to differential hospital admission rates.

Randomization or Matching 
Selection bias A sampling bias. Non-random allocation of subjects that do not represent the population Randomization or Matching
Hawthorne bias Change in attitude/ actions of the subjects under observation Use placebo group
Confounding bias Factors related to both exposure and outcome distort the effect of exposure on outcome Matching, cross-over studies, randomization, or stratification
Attrition bias Participants lost to follow-up have a different prognosis than those who complete the study. Randomization
Pygmalion bias Researcher's high expectations in the efficacy of the treatment change the outcome of that treatment. Blinding
Neyman's/ Prevalence-Incidence bias  Occurs due to the selective survival in prevalent cases usually seen in fatal diseases. Very sick patients are automatically excluded because of their early death.  

Neyman’s bias or prevalence-incidence bias example: a case-control study is carried out to study the relationship between tobacco smoking and acute myocardial infarction (AMI). The cases are interviewed one week after the coronary attack. If smoker patients with AMI die more frequently, the living cases will show a lower frequency of smoking, undervaluing the association between smoking and AMI. It has been shown that the bias occurs only if the risk factor influences mortality from the disease being studied.

Ecological fallacy results when characteristics of the group are assigned inappropriately to individuals.

questions.text: What is the use of the following instrument used in orthopaedic surgeries ?

choices.text: To to cut bone while performing an osteotomy
To scrape tissue from a cavity or nidus
To hold the plate intact with the bone

questions.solution:
The instrument depicted is a bone curette and it is used for curettage or scraping a cavity in the bone or removing fibrous tissue from the ends of a fracture. It is used in the management of enchondroma, GCT, and osteomyelitis.

Other options -

Option A - An osteotome is used for cutting bone in surgeries such as corrective osteotomies and they are bevelled at both sides.

Option C -A periosteal elevator is used to elevate the periosteum, as nerves and vessels are generally on this plane, and once elevated there is a safer plane for surgery.

Option D: A bone and plate holding forceps is used to hold the plate and bone together in alignment during screw fixation.

questions.text: Which of the following is a serotonin partial agonist–reuptake inhibitor (SPARI)?
questions.solution:
Vilazodone is a novel antidepressant that is considered a serotonin partial agonist–reuptake inhibitor (SPARI).

The antidepressant effect of vilazodone is due to its enhancement of serotonergic activity in the CNS through selective inhibition of serotonin reuptake. It binds with high affinity to the serotonin reuptake site but not to the norepinephrine or dopamine reuptake site. As a result, vilazodone potently and selectively inhibits the reuptake of serotonin.

Vilazodone is also a partial agonist at serotonergic 5-HT1A receptors. The result of this activity on serotonergic transmission also plays a role in its antidepressant effect.

Thus it offers a novel combination of selective serotonin reuptake inhibition (SSRI) and serotonergic (5-HT1A) receptor partial agonist activity. Because of these characteristics, vilazodone has been termed a serotonin partial agonist–reuptake inhibitor (SPARI).

Vilazodone is never combined with a monoamine oxidase (MAO) inhibitor or given within 14 days of discontinuing or initiating MAO inhibitor therapy due to the serious risk of serotonin toxicity.

Other options:

Option A: Lurasidone is a second-generation antipsychotic that is a 5-HT2A and D2 receptor antagonist. it is used in the treatment of schizophrenia and bipolar depression (as monotherapy or as an adjunct).

Option C: Asenapine is a second-generation antipsychotic which is also a 5-HT2A and D2 receptor antagonist, used in the management of schizophrenia and acute mania.

Option D: Blonanserin is a second-generation antipsychotic, which acts as an antagonist at D2, D3, and 5-HT2A receptors. Blonanserin has a low affinity for 5-HT2C, adrenergic α1, histamine H1, and muscarinic M1 receptors, but displays a relatively high affinity for 5-HT6 receptors. It is used in the management of schizophrenia.

questions.text: A 55-year-old diabetic man presents with acute fever, chills, flank pain, and nausea. Imaging reveals a 6 cm solitary renal abscess in the upper pole of the right kidney. What is the most appropriate management for this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with clinical features of a 6 cm right renal abscess which should be managed by percutaneous aspiration and drainage. Percutaneous aspiration or drainage is indicated in abscesses >5 cm and in patients not responding to antibiotics.

A renal abscess typically arises from an ascending urinary tract infection, often associated with obstructive uropathy. Common uropathogens, such as E. coli, typically cause it. Renal abscesses may extend, perforating the renal capsule to form a perirenal abscess or conglomerate into a solitary suppurative lesion called a renal carbuncle. 

Clinical presentation is often insidious, with non-specific symptoms, but patients commonly exhibit persistent fever, back pain, abdominal pain, and costovertebral tenderness. Urine examination may be normal if the abscess does not communicate with the collecting system. Contrast-enhanced computed tomography (CECT) is the preferred diagnostic tool for establishing the diagnosis.

Other options:

Option B: Laparoscopy is not needed as it can very well be drained by percutaneous aspiration.

Option C: Open surgical drainage is indicated when percutaneous drainage is not adequate.

Option D: Intrarenal antibiotic injections is not a standard treatment for renal abscesses. Also one can bear in mind that treatment with broad spectrum antibiotics without drainage may be indicated in patients with small abscesses (<3 cm) or in stable patients (up to 5 cm).

questions.text: A 60 year old alcoholic male has been diagnosed with ischemic stroke. Which of the following situations would be considered relatively safe for the administration of IV alteplase?

choices.text: History of ischemic stroke 2 months ago
History of variceal bleed 2 weeks ago

questions.solution:
The correct answer is A, sustained BP of 170/100 mm Hg. The target BP considered safe for the administration of iv alteplase is 185/110 mm Hg.

The other options are contraindications for the administration of IV alteplase as they are associated with an increased risk of cerebral hemorrhage.

The indications for iv alteplase are as follows:

  • Clinical diagnosis of stroke
  • Onset of symptoms to time of drug administration ≤4.5 hr
  • CT scan showing no hemorrhage or edema of >1/3 of the MCA territory 
  • Age ≥18 years 

The contraindications for the use of iv alteplase are:

  • Sustained BP >185/110 mmHg despite treatment 
  • Bleeding diathesis (platelet count <1,00,000/mm3, concomitant use of anticoagulants)
  • Recent head injury or intracerebral hemorrhage 
  • Major surgery in preceding 14 days 
  • Gastrointestinal bleeding in preceding 21 days 
  • Recent myocardial infarction
  • Ischemic stroke within 3 months

questions.text: You suspect psoriatic erythroderma in a patient who presented with superficial scaling of the skin and redness. Which of the following is the drug of choice in this case?
questions.solution:
The treatment of choice for erythrodermic psoriasis is methotrexate. It is a folate antagonist that acts by the inhibition of dihydrofolate reductase. It inhibits lymphocyte proliferation and is thereby used in the management of generalized pustular psoriasis, psoriatic erythroderma and debilitating arthritis. 

Depending on the type of psoriasis, various therapeutic options are available: 

  • Topical agents - for psoriasis of limited extent
    • Coal tar
    • Dithranol
    • Tazarotene
    • Calcipotriol
    • Steroids
  • Systemic agents - for moderate to severe psoriasis
    • Methotrexate
    • Acitretin
    • Cyclosporin
  • Phototherapy
  • Biologicals
    • TNF-alpha inhibitors: Infliximab, Etanercept, Adalimumab
    • IL 12 / 23 inhibitor: Ustekinumab
    • Selective IL-23 inhibitor: Tildrakizumab
    • IL-17 inhibitors: Secukinumab, Brodalumab
    • Phosphodiesterase-4 inhibitors: Apremilast

The only indication of systemic steroids is generalized pustular psoriasis in pregnancy (impetigo herpetiformis).

Erythrodermic psoriasis can be precipitated by the irritant effect of topical therapy, withdrawal of steroids, systemic illness, alcoholism and ultraviolet radiation. The clinical characteristics of psoriasis are often lost. There is generalized involvement of the skin with severe itching and redness. It may be associated with hypo or hyperthermia, hypoalbuminemia, anemia, dehydration and high output cardiac failure.

questions.text: An athlete slipped off the pavement while running and twisted his right ankle. He could not walk properly and developed swelling in the right ankle region. What is the most probable ligament injured?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario suggests an ankle sprain. The most probable ligament injured is the anterior talofibular ligament (marked as 1).

Ankle sprains are common in pedestrians and country walkers who stumble on stairways, pavements, and potholes. In the majority of the cases, it is the lateral ligament complex that is injured, in particular the anterior talofibular followed by the calcaneofibular ligaments(marked as 2). Medial ligament injuries are usually associated with a fracture or joint injury.

The anterior talo-fibular ligament (ATFL) during plantarflexion, changes its orientation from horizontal to vertical with respect to the floor. Thus the ligament gets stretched and vulnerable to injury. On slipping off a pavement or into a pothole the foot gets plantar-flexed and inverted predisposing the ATFL to injury.

The lateral collateral ligaments consist of the anterior talofibular, the posterior talofibular, and (between them) the calcaneofibular ligaments. The calcaneofibular ligament runs from the tip of the lateral malleolus to the posterolateral part of the calcaneum and, therefore helps to stabilize the subtalar joint. The posterior talofibular ligament runs from the posterior border of the lateral malleolus to the posterior part of the talus.

The medial collateral (deltoid) ligament consists of superficial and deep portions. The superficial fibers spread like a fan from the medial malleolus anteriorly to the navicular and inferiorly to the calcaneum and talus. Its chief function is to resist the eversion of the hindfoot. 

The deep portion is intra-articular, running directly from the medial malleolus to the medial surface of the talus. Its principal effect is to prevent external rotation of the talus. The deltoid ligament is the major stabilizer of the ankle joint.  


Management of ankle sprains includes protection (crutches, splints, or braces), rest, ice, compression, elevation, and rehabilitation (summarized as PRICER). Analgesics such as NSAIDs can be used topically as a gel or in oral formulations for pain relief.

Markings 3 and 4 are anterior inferior tibiofibular and posterior inferior tibiofibular ligaments respectively.

questions.text: A patient comes with acute left lower limb pain associated with mild sensory loss and mild muscle weakness. He has a past history of ischemic stroke. He has an elevated D-dimer level. On doppler examination of the leg, the venous signal is seen but the arterial signal is absent. What would be the most appropriate plan of management?
questions.solution:
The presence of acute lower limb pain associated with mild sensorimotor abnormality suggests acute limb ischemia Grade IIb (Rutherford’s classification) with a history of ischemic stroke pointing towards a thromboembolic etiology. Surgical intervention like thrombectomy would be the most appropriate management.

Acute lower limb ischemia is caused by occlusion of the supplying arteries, and the severity depends on the degree of occlusion. This patient has mild sensory as well as motor loss which means the situation is immediately limb-threatening and can be salvageable provided immediate revascularisation (Grade IIb). Thus, immediate surgical removal of the thrombus is the ideal management.

Option C : Intravenous anticoagulation are contraindicated in Grade IIb acute limb ischemia which requires immediate revascularisation because anticoagulation usually takes 12-24 hours to work. Either way, surgical approach should be the most appropriate management in case of Grade IIb acute limb ischaemia.

questions.text: A child presents with severe abdominal pain and neuropsychiatric symptoms. Her urine is dark red and she has no photosensitivity. You suspect a type of porphyria. Which of the following enzymes would be deficient in this case ?
questions.solution:
The child has severe abdominal pain and neuropsychiatric symptoms with the presence of dark-red urine. This points towards porphyria. Since there is no photosensitivity, the child most probably has acute intermittent porphyria (AIP).

AIP is due to deficiency of hydroxymethylbilane synthase, an enzyme involved in heme biosynthesis. In general, individuals with an enzyme defect prior to the synthesis of the tetrapyrroles manifest abdominal and neuropsychiatric signs without any photosensitivity, whereas those with
enzyme defects leading to the accumulation of tetrapyrrole intermediates show photosensitivity along with other symptoms.

Deficiency of hydroxymethylbilane synthase leads to accumulation of delta-aminolevulinic acid and porphobilinogen (i.e., before the tetrapyrrole synthesis step), which will cause abdominal pain and neuropsychiatric symptoms but not photosensitivity.

Other options : 

Option A) Protoporphyrinogen oxidase deficiency : variegate porphyria

Option B) Uroporphyrinogen decarboxylase deficiency : porphyria cutanea tarda

Option C) Uroporphyrinogen III synthase deficiency : congenital erythropoietic porphyria

Deficiency of these 3 enzymes leads to accumulation of tetrapyrrole byproducts, which will cause photosensitivity.

Related Pearl: Types of porphyria

Clinically porphyrias can be classified into:

  • Hepatic porphyria: The overproduction of heme pathway intermediates occurs primarily in the liver.
  • Erythropoietic porphyria: The overproduction of heme pathway intermediates occurs primarily in bone marrow erythroid cells.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs used in the management of HIV can be used in the prevention of diseases caused by herpesviruses?
questions.solution:
Tenofovir can also be used in the prophylaxis of diseases caused by herpesviruses. Tenofovir has in vitro activity against herpes simplex virus type 2 (HSV-2).

Tenofovir is a reverse transcriptase inhibitor that prevents the conversion of viral RNA into proviral DNA. It helps to prevent infection of susceptible cells but does not eradicate the virus from cells that are integrated with proviral DNA. It is also active against HIV 1, 2, and hepatitis B virus.

Other options : 

Option B and D : Lamivudine and emtricitabine are human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) treatment drugs that have shown efficacy against HBV infection in both hepatitis B e antigen (HBeAg)-positive and HBeAg-negative patients. However, this combination is associated with a greater incidence of resistance in co-infected patients.

Because of the rapid emergence of lamivudine-resistant HBV, we avoid HIV ART regimens that employ lamivudine or emtricitabine monotherapy for the treatment of HBV (e.g., one that uses abacavir-lamivudine as the nucleoside combination or a two-drug regimen such as dolutegravir-lamivudine).

Option C : Dolutegravir has activity against both HIV-1 and HIV-2. Dolutegravir is used for post exposure prophylaxis along with Lamivudine and Tenofovir for 4 weeks.

If a HIV patient is coinfected with HBV or becomes infected during treatment, abrupt withdrawal of any dolutegravir combination with lamivudine or tenofovir may result in rebound HBV replication and acute liver damage.

questions.text: During your ward rounds, you were asked to name a calcium sensitizer used in the management of a patient with acute decompensated heart failure. Which of the following drugs would you mention?
questions.solution:
Levosimendan is a myofilament calcium sensitizer used in the short-term management of acute decompensated heart failure.

It increases the sensitivity of contractile myofilaments to Calcium by binding and inducing a conformational change in thin-filament regulatory protein troponin-C.

It increases cardiac output and decreases vascular resistance (ionodilator). Other actions like inhibition of phosphodiesterases, opening of potassium channels, and inhibition of pro-inflammatory cytokines are observed.

Other options :

Option B and C: Milrinone and enoximone are PDE-3 inhibitors indicated in acute decompensated heart failure

Option D: Cinacalcet is a calcium sensitizer that increases the sensitivity of calcium sensing receptor to extracellular calcium in parathyroid glands. It is used to reduce serum calcium levels primary and secondary hyperparathyroidism.

4. Ciliary body

questions.text: A patient working in the dye industry presents with shortness of breath and persistent hypoxia despite oxygen therapy. Pulse oximetry shows saturation of 80% and CO-oximetry is diagnostic. Which of the following is not true about this condition ?

choices.text: Methylene blue can improve the condition
Iron in RBCs predominates in ferrous form
Sulfa drugs can precipitate the condition

questions.solution:
This patient likely has methemoglobinemia, as suggested by lack of improvement with oxygen and CO-oximetry being diagnostic investigation.  In methemoglobinemia, the iron in the RBC's is predominantly in the ferric form due to defective cytochrome b5 reductase enzyme.

Normally the iron in hemoglobin is stored in ferrous (Fe2+) state. When this iron is in oxidized form (Fe3+), the hemoglobin is called methemoglobin. Methemoglobin does not bind to oxygen readily, and is not able to deliver the oxygen to the peripheral tissues. This causes tissue hypoxia and leftward shifting of the oxygen-hemoglobin dissociation curve.

Acquired methemoglobinemia can occur due to a number of drugs, such as nitrites, dapsone (sulfa durgs, option D), local anesthetics such as benzocaine, and antimalarials such as chloroquine and primaquine. Exposure to analine dyes(Option C) can also lead to methemoglobinemia. It presents as cyanosis that does not respond to oxygen administration. 

Pulse oximetry in methemoglobinemia shows a plateau of 80% to 85% irrespective of the arterial oxygen saturation and irrespective of the methemoglobin levels. CO-oximeters that can differentiate methemoglobin from carboxyhemoglobin, oxyhemoglobin, and deoxyhemoglobin are thus preferred for the diagnosis of methemoglobinemia.

Treatment of methemoglobinemia involves supportive care, cessation of offending drug, and reduction of methemoglobin to hemoglobin by intravenous methylene blue (1–2 mg/kg) (Option A).

questions.text: The given X ray of left knee joint suggests
questions.solution:
The given X ray of left knee joint shows immature skeleton with expansile multi-cystic lytic lesions in the metaphysis of tibia. It is the classical presentation of a aneurysmal bone cyst (ABC). 

Aneurysmal bone cysts (ABCs) are benign, expansile lesions of bone composed of blood-filled cystic spaces. They predominantly affect children and teenagers with an equal sex distribution. ABCs are most commonly seen in the metaphyses of long bones, particularly the femur, tibia and humerus. In the spine , they usually affect the posterior elements. Patients typically present with pain and swelling. When affecting the spine, presentation can be with nerve root impingement and neurological impairment. 

ABCs appear as a subperiosteal, poorly defined osteolytic lesion, and progressively elevating and eroding the cortex. MRI shows typically cysts with multiple intralesional septations and fluid levels. Histologically, ABCs are composed of blood-filled, cystic spaces separated by fibrous septae which may comprise woven bone in chronic lesions. An ABC can appear as a solid lesion, which resembles a giant-cell lesion but in immature skeleton.

ABC-like areas can be seen in other benign tumours and occasionally malignant lesions where there has been haemorrhage within the tumour (secondary ABC). Curettage of the lesion at the time of biopsy ,debriding the cystic cavity wall, is often effective though recurrence can occur in up to 20% of cases. Radiation is effective in stimulating cyst calcification but risk of secondary tumors due to radiation and growth arrest due to epiphyseal damage in present.

Other options -

Option A - Simple bone cyst(SBC) also presents in the first 2 decades of life in the immature bone most commonly in the metaphysis of humerus followed by proximal femur and proximal tibia. They are solitary, usually unilocular cystic bone cavity lined by a fibrous membrane and filled with serous or serosanguinous fluid. Males are more frequently affected. In majority of the cases, they are incidental findings as they are asymptomatic, occasionally they present as pathological fractures.

X-rays show well-defined ,centrally placed lytic lesions in the metaphyseal areas expanding and thinning the cortices. It often abuts the physis but usually is not aggressive like ABCs (does not cross the physis). When fractures occur, a small fragment may be seen within the cavity, the classic ‘fallen leaf’ sign. MRI shows homogeneous fluid-filled cavity. 

Option C - Osteosarcoma is the most common primary malignant bone tumor. Primary osteosarcomas present most commonly during adolescence whereas secondary osteosarcomas present during the 7th decade of life. They arise from the metaphysis of long bones, especially the distal femur or the proximal tibia (i.e. around the knee joint).

Clinically, they present with worsening pain and swelling. The pain is described as non-mechanical and is often worse during the night. X-rays features include Codman’s triangle due to periosteal elevation from new bone formation and ‘Sunburst’ appearance due to rapid growth when the periosteum cannot lay down a new layer.

Option D -Giant cell tumors(GCT) or osteoclastoma is a benign but locally aggressive tumor that usually affects young adults of age 20 to 40 (mature skeleton) years with slight female predominance. It affects the ends of long bones, involving metaphysis/epiphysis of long bones. GCT is most commonly seen in the distal femur, proximal tibia, proximal humerus, and distal radius. Common presenting complaints are swelling and vague pain. Sometimes, the patient presents for the first time with a pathological fracture through the lesion.

X-ray features include the classical soap-bubble appearance , eccentric location and expansile in nature elevating the cortex.

questions.text: A patient had been treated for multi-drug resistant tuberculosis (MDR- TB) and his treatment outcome was labeled as ‘treatment failed’. This label applies to all of the following conditions, except:

choices.text: Lack of conversion by the end of intensive phase
Bacteriological reversion in the continuation phase after initial conversion
Adverse drug reactions to standard MDR-TB drugs
Patient treatment interrupted for atleast 2 consecutive months

questions.solution:
Patient treatment interrupted for atleast 2 consecutive months (Option D)- is not labelled as ‘treatment failed’ instead labeled as ‘lost to follow up’ and the patient’s treatment is continued as a new case.

Patients treated for MDR-TB and labeled as ‘treatment failed’ include - 

  • Lack of conversion by the end of intensive phase
  • Bacteriological reversion in the continuation phase after initial conversion
  • Adverse drug reactions to standard MDR-TB drugs
  • Evidence of additional acquired resistance to fluoroquinolones or second-line injectable drugs

For ‘treatment failed’, lack of conversion by the end of the intensive phase implies that the patient does not convert within the maximum duration of intensive phase applied by the programme. If no maximum duration is defined, an 8-month cut-off is proposed. 

Conversion (to negative) : culture is considered to have converted negative when two consecutive cultures, taken at least 30 days apart, are found to be negative. In such a case, the specimen collection date of the first negative culture is used as the date of conversion.

Reversion (to positive) : culture is considered to have reverted to positive when, after an initial conversion, two consecutive cultures, taken at least 30 days apart, are found to be positive. For the purpose of defining treatment failed, reversion is considered only when it occurs in the continuation phase.

Other outcomes for Rifampicin Resistant-TB(RR-TB)/MDR-TB/Drug-resistant TB patients treated include -

Cured - Treatment completed as recommended by NTEP(National tuberculosis eradication programme) without evidence of failure and three or more consecutive cultures taken at least 30 days apart are negative after the intensive phase.

Treatment completed - Treatment completed as recommended by NTEP without evidence of failure but no record that three or more consecutive cultures taken at least 30 days apart are negative after the intensive phase.

Died - A patient who dies for any reason during the course of treatment.

Not evaluated - A patient for whom no treatment outcome is assigned. (This includes cases transferred out to another treatment unit and whose treatment outcome is unknown).

Treatment success - The sum of cured and treatment completed.

questions.text: A middle-aged male patient comes with complaints of pain in his great toe. The pain is recurrent, usually starts at night, and is triggered by alcohol consumption. On examination, the toe is warm, tender, and swollen. Which of the following drugs would not be beneficial for his condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of gout flares and benzhexol, a central anticholinergic, would not be beneficial in this condition.  

Gout is a hyperuricemic condition that occurs among the middle-aged and elderly. It manifests as acute recurrent gout flares that often involve the metatarsophalangeal joint of the first toe (podagra). The pain begins at night and continues to early morning. Triggering factors include alcohol, diuretic use, trauma, purine-rich food, etc.   

Uricosuric drugs help in augmenting the excretion of uric acid. The various drugs used are: 

  • Probenecid inhibits the reabsorption of uric acid by the enzyme URAT-1. This effect is decreased if it is coadministered with salicylates such as aspirin. 
  • Benzbromarone: It is a reversible inhibitor of the urate-anion exchanger in the proximal tubule.
  • Lesinurad: It inhibits the reabsorption of uric acid by inhibiting URAT-1 and OAT-4.
  • Sulfinpyrazone: It inhibits the organic anion transporter that is involved in uric acid reabsorption in renal tubules.
  • Losartan is an angiotensin receptor antagonist that also has mild uricosuric action.

Other treatment goals include:

  • Symptomatic relief of an acute attack (glucocorticoids, NSAID)
  • Prevention of inflammatory responses to crystals (colchicine)
  • Inhibition of urate formation via xanthine oxidase inhibitors (allopurinol and febuxostat)
  • Uricase drugs that oxidize uric acid to more soluble allantoin (pegloticase and rasburicase)

Pegloticase is used in chronic gout or if it is refractory to other drugs.

Related Pearl: Drugs precipitating Gout

Drugs that precipitate gout are-

Cyclosporine or cancer drugs
Aspirin (low dose)
Niacin
Thiazide
Lasix (furosemide)
Ethambutol
Alcohol
Pyrazinamide

Mnemonic for drugs precipitating gout is 'CANT LEAP'

questions.text: Four types of breech presentations have been shown below. Which one has the highest chances of cord prolapse?
questions.solution:
The correct answer is option 3: Footling breech which has the highest chances of cord prolapse (15%) among the four types of breech presentation.

Overall highest chances of cord prolapse are in a transverse lie.

Types of breech:

Breech presentation can be divided into the following:

  • Incomplete: Breech with extended legs (frank breech), footling, or knee presentation
  • Complete: Breech with flexed legs

In frank breech presentation, thighs are flexed on the trunk, and legs are extended at the knees. The presenting part would be two buttocks and external genitalia.

In footling presentation, both thighs and legs are partially extended. The presenting part would be the legs.

In knee presentation, thighs are extended but the knees are flexed. The presenting part would be the knee.

In complete breech presentation, thighs are flexed at hips and legs at knees. The presenting part would be two buttocks, external genitalia, and two feet.

questions.text: A 64-year-old male patient is brought to the emergency room with features of myocardial infarction. Which of the following substances secreted by the endothelial cells will most likely lead to a decrease in thrombus propagation by inhibiting platelet aggregation?
questions.solution:
Intact endothelial cells produce substances such as prostacyclin that inhibit platelet aggregation and decrease thrombus propagation. 

Once a thrombus forms, counter-regulatory mechanisms activate in the endothelial cells distal to the site of injury to prevent thrombus propagation. Prostacyclin or prostaglandin I2 (PGI2), is a member of the eicosanoid family of lipids and is an inhibitor of platelet aggregation as well as a vasodilator.

Damage to the vascular endothelium leads to the formation of platelet plugs (primary hemostasis). It occurs in three main steps:

  • Platelets adhere to collagen in the tissues via a protein called von Willebrand factor.
  • Platelets get activated and secrete multiple substances such as adenosine diphosphate (ADP), platelet-activating factor (PAF), ionized calcium, fibrinogen, thromboxane A2 and others from their alpha and delta granules.
  • Thromboxane is a vasoconstrictor and, along with ADP and PAF, acts on nearby platelets to activate them as well; and is a potent stimulator of platelet aggregation.

Endothelial cells regulate hemostasis and they determine whether thrombus formation, propagation, or dissolution occurs. Coagulation is restricted to the site of endothelial cell damage by:

  • Antiplatelet effects: prostacyclin and nitric oxide
  • Anticoagulation effects: thrombomodulin, protein C receptor, heparin-like molecules, and tissue factor pathway inhibitors
  • Fibrinolytic effects: tissue plasminogen

Other options:

Options A, and B: They favor the coagulation cascade leading to thrombus propagation.

Option D: Thrombomodulin binds thrombin and negates thrombin's ability to activate coagulation. It acts as an anti-coagulation factor and does not interfere with platelet aggregation.

questions.text: All the following conditions present with secondary hemochromatosis except:
questions.solution:
Haemophilia does not present with secondary haemochromatosis.

The conditions presenting with secondary iron overload are:

  • Sideroblastic anemia
  • Thalassemia
  • Porphyria cutanea tarda
  • Hereditary aceruloplasminemia

Secondary iron overload with deposition in parenchymal cells occurs in chronic disorders of erythropoiesis, as iron absorption is increased in these conditions. Moreover, these patients require blood transfusions and are frequently treated inappropriately with iron.

Hemophilia presents with mucosal bleeding which usually does not require blood transfusions. Furthermore, iron metabolism is normal in hemophilia. Therefore, secondary hemochromatosis is not seen in hemophilia.

Related Pearl: Classification of Iron Overload

 Primary / Hereditary Hemochromatosis

HFE gene-related

  • Type 1: C282Y mutations of genes encoding HFE 

Non-HFE gene-related

  • Type 2: Juvenile hemochromatosis
    • 2a - HJV mutation (hemojuvelin)
    • 2b - HAMP mutation (Hepcidin)
  • Type 3: Transferrin receptor 2 (TfR2) related 
  • Type 4: Ferroportin-related HH
