  • Thalassemia major
  • Sideroblastic anemia
  • Chronic hemolytic anemias

Chronic liver disease

  • Alcoholic liver disease
  • Non-alcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH)
  • Porphyria cutanea tarda

Miscellaneous

  • Congenital atransferrinemia
  • African iron overload (Bantu siderosis)

questions.text:
A 50-year-old woman with diabetic foot has been admitted for septic shock. Which of the following are incorrect regarding the management of this patient?

1. Norepinephrine is the vasopressor of choice

2. Achieve a mean target arterial pressure of 65 mmHg or higher

3. Antibiotics are to be initiated only as per culture reports 

4. Initiate insulin therapy if glucose ≥140 mg/dL

5. Low molecular weight heparin as prophylaxis against venous thromboembolism
questions.solution:
Statements 3 and 4 are incorrect (Option B).

Target MAP (mean arterial pressure) in septic shock is ≥65 mmHg to ensure adequate organ perfusion (Statement 2). Norepinephrine is the vasopressor of choice in septic shock (Statement 1). Vasopressin should be used if MAP is not achieved. 

In the case of septic shock, empirical broad-spectrum antibiotics should be initiated as soon as possible and within 1 hour of recognition. Early initiation of empirical antibiotics is crucial as every 1-hour delay causes a 3-7% increase in the odds of death. Antibiotics should be narrowed once culture reports are available (Statement 3).

Glucose >180 mg/dL is an indication to start insulin therapy as glucose levels above this are associated with increased mortality in critically ill patients(Statement 4). 

Pharmacological prophylaxis against venous thromboembolism in the form of low molecular weight heparin is recommended in the absence of contraindications, as these patients are at risk of deep vein thrombosis and pulmonary embolism (Statement 5).

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about gamma knife?

choices.text: It is used for the treatment of tuberculoma
It can be performed anywhere in the body

questions.solution:
Gamma knife is a type of stereotactic radiotherapy or surgery (SRS) which is a reasonable alternative for people who refuse or cannot tolerate surgery. Here, beams are modified and focused only to concentrate on the tumor and have little effect on surrounding tissue. SRS can be done by using: 

  • X-knife using a linear accelerator (LINAC)
  • Gamma-knife using Cobalt 60 as source (Option B)
  • CyberKnife - image-guided linear accelerator using real-time image guidance to deliver radiation from multiple angles.

In gamma knife, the patient wears a specialized helmet called Leksell’s frame that is surgically fixed to the skull. Gamma knife aims gamma radiation through a target point in the patient’s brain. An ablative dose of radiation is thereby sent through the tumour in one treatment session while surrounding brain tissues are relatively spared. 

The classic indications of cobalt-based stereotactic radiosurgery (SRS) and gamma knife are:

  • Arterio-venous malformation
  • Acoustic schwannoma
  • Pituitary adenoma
  • Meningioma
  • Trigeminal neuralgia

The image below is an illustration of the priniciple of gamma-knife therapy:

 

Other options:

Option C: It is not used in the treatment of tuberculoma.

Option D: Helmet or frame is needed to perform gamma knife therapies. So, they are limited to brain pathology. Cyberknife uses X-ray (LINAC) and can be performed anywhere in the body with help of a robotic arm.

questions.text: The sign given below is seen in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
The given image has the characteristic wrist sign i.e. the distal phalange of the first and fifth fingers of the hand overlaps when wrapped around the opposite wrist. This is seen in Marfan's syndrome. This happens as their fingers and hands are long and slender and have a spider-like appearance (arachnodactyly). 

Marfan's syndrome is an inherited connective tissue disorder that is caused by a mutation in a gene that codes for an extracellular matrix protein-fibrillin-1 (FBN1). The FBN1 locus is on the long arm of chromosome 15. It is a clinical diagnosis based on skeletal, cardiovascular, and ocular manifestations. 

Skeletal manifestations: 

  • Overgrowth of long bones (dolichostenomelia) with an arm span to height ratio of more than 1.05
  • Pectus carinatum or pectus excavatum
  • Long and slender fingers (arachnodactyly), contracture of fingers (camptodactyly)
  • Malar hypoplasia
  • Joint laxity 

Cardiovascular manifestations:

  • Thickened atrioventricular valves, valvular prolapse (mitral regurgitation) 
  • Aortic valve dysfunction due to aortic root aneurysm
  • Aortic dissection and rupture due to cystic medial necrosis of the aorta

Ocular manifestations:

  • ectopia lentis
  • myopia
  • flat cornea
  • retinal detachments
  • early cataracts and glaucoma

Other systemic manifestations: 

  • thoracic scoliosis
  • spontaneous pneumothorax
  • striae atrophicae in the skin

Image (a) shows Walker-Murdoch (wrist) sign - the ability to join the thumb and fifth finger around the wrist. Image (b) shows Steinberg (thumb) sign - thumb tip extends from the palm of the hand in a closed fist 

 

Diagnosis is based on criteria depending on the family history, aortic root X score, ectopia lentis, mitral valve prolapse, and presence of FBN1 mutation.

Other options:

Option B: Ehler Danlos syndrome is characterized by hyperextensible skin and hypermobile joints. However, the wrist sign is not a characteristic of EDS.

Option C: Osteogenesis imperfecta is characterized by a decrease in bone mineral density. Hence, the bones are very fragile limiting the physical activity of the patient.

Option D: Pseudoxanthoma elasticum is characterized by abnormal deposition of calcium in the elastic fibers of skin, eyes, and vessels.

questions.text: A child presents with abdominal pain and red currant jelly stools. The child keeps crawling its knees up to the chest in episodes. Which of the following is expected upon clinical examination?

choices.text: Abdominal swelling with zone of resonance
Swelling mobile in direction perpendicular to mesentery
Sausage shaped mass in the right upper abdomen
Solid mass arising from left costal margin towards right iliac fossa

questions.solution:
Abdominal pain with increased severity as suggested by the upward crawling of knees along with red currant jelly stools is suggestive of intussusception. A sausage-shaped mass in the right upper abdomen is expected to be seen upon examination.

Intussusception is a condition in which one part of the bowel telescopes into the other, causing obstruction and abdominal pain. The ileocaecal region is most commonly involved in children. The classic triad of symptoms includes:

  • Abdominal pain
  • A sausage-shaped abdominal mass
  • Red currant jelly stools

The sausage-shaped mass is most commonly palpated in the right upper abdomen. There may be an associated "emptiness" on palpation in the right iliac fossa, known as the sign of Dance. 

Ultrasonogram reveals telescoping bowel segments classically called the “target sign / bull's eye sign” as shown below:


Chest X-ray can be done to confirm the presence of perforation along with other clinical signs.

It is considered as an emergency and immediate intervention is warranted. Air or barium enema is most commonly used if there are no signs of bowel strangulation or ischaemia and surgical intervention is mandatory if there are any. Presence of perforation or peritonitis is also an indication for surgery. 

Other options : 

Abdominal swelling which moves perpendicular to the line of attachment of mesentery with a zone of resonance around it are the components of Tillaux’s triad used to diagnose mesenteric cyst.

A solid abdominal mass arising from the left costal margin and progressing towards the right iliac fossa is suggestive of splenomegaly.

questions.text: A known diabetic patient on oral antidiabetic drugs for the past 20 years, now presents with paresthesias and difficulty in walking. Blood investigation showed raised MCV and elevated serum methylmalonate levels. Which drug might have caused these side effects in this patient?
questions.solution:
In this case, metformin can cause vitamin B12 deficiency which may manifest in the neurological symptoms of paresthesias, difficulty in walking, and causes megaloblastic anemia which on blood investigations show raised MCV and serum methylmalonate levels.

The levels of vitamin B12 should thus be monitored. The most common side effect of metformin is mainly GI intolerance like nausea, bloating, abdominal cramps, and diarrhea.

Note: The exact reason why metformin causes vitamin B12 deficiency is not known. The proposed mechanisms include:

  • Alterations in small bowel motility which stimulates bacterial overgrowth and consequential vitamin B12 deficiency
  • Competitive inhibition or inactivation of vitamin B12 absorption
  • Alterations in intrinsic factor (IF) levels and interaction with the cubilin endocytic receptor.
  • Inhibition of the calcium-dependent absorption of the vitamin B12-IF complex at the terminal ileum.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man has been admitted to the respiratory unit with a complication of pneumonia. He underwent a procedure as shown in the image below. Which of the following is not an indication for this procedure?

choices.text: Presence of gross pus in the pleural space
Positive Gram stain of pleural fluid

questions.solution:
A pleural fluid glucose of 72 mg/dL is not an indication for chest tube insertion.

The patient is likely to have developed an exudative pleural effusion as a complication of pneumonia. The given image shows a chest tube inserted to treat his condition.

Factors indicating the likely need for chest tube drainage in pleural effusion, in the setting of pneumonia, include:

  • Loculated pleural fluid
  • Pleural fluid pH <7.20
  • Pleural fluid glucose <3.3 mmol/L (<60 mg/dL)
  • Positive Gram stain or culture of the pleural fluid
  • Presence of gross pus in the pleural space 

Pleural effusions can be transudative or exudative pleural effusion. Transudative and exudative pleural effusions are distinguished by measuring the lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) and protein levels in the pleural fluid.

Exudative pleural effusion- protein concentration >3 gm% or by Light's criteria they follow atleast one of the following criteria -

  • Pleural fluid protein/serum protein >0.5
  • Pleural fluid LDH/serum LDH >0.6
  • Pleural fluid LDH >2/3 of the normal upper limit for serum LDH

If none of the above are present, then they are categorised as transudative pleural effusion.

questions.text: A 25-year-old badminton player presents with complaints of pain in the right arm for a few weeks. On physical examination, the right arm is pale and cool to the touch. A radiograph of the patient is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical features and X-ray showing elongation of the transverse process of the C7 vertebra are suggestive of a cervical rib. The symptoms of pain and pallor of the arm are due to neural and vascular compression respectively.

The cervical rib is the extension of the anterior part of the transverse process of the C7 vertebrae which narrows the scalene triangle leading to compression of the subclavian artery, C8 and T1 nerve roots. 


Clinical features:

Most of the cases are asymptomatic. Vascular manifestations include upper limb claudication especially after usage, vasomotor changes (cyanosis, cold fingers and excessive sweating), Raynaud's phenomenon, wasting of the thenar, hypothenar, and forearm muscles, and ischemic ulcers or gangrene of digits. 

Neurological features include pain and weakness in the medial aspect of the arm, forearm, and hand. There may be a hard, fixed bony mass in the supraclavicular region. A palpable thrill and a bruit may be present in the subclavian artery. Positive Roos and elevated arm stress test are characteristic of thoracic outlet syndrome.

A radiograph of the neck is useful in detecting a cervical rib. However, the absence of a rib on the x-ray does not rule out the possibility of a cervical rib. CT and MRI are more sensitive.

Other options: 

Option A: Herniation of the cervical disc occurs due to degenerative changes with advancing age. MRI may show the protrusion of the disc and associated compression of the nearby nerves. An X-ray may be usually normal.

Option B: Spondylolisthesis refers to the forward translation of one segment of the spine upon the other most commonly occurring between L4 and L5, or between L5 and the sacrum. Oblique view X-rays may show the characteristic ‘Scotty dog neck’ appearance suggestive of a pars fracture with a broken neck or collar. Lateral views show the forward shift of the part of the spinal column above over the stable vertebra below. 

Option D: Cervical spondylosis refers to the degenerative changes in the adjacent vertebra and the intervening intervertebral disc more commonly affecting the C5 and C6 vertebra. X-ray shows a narrow intervertebral space with osteophyte formation.

Related Pearl: Thoracic outlet syndrome and its tests:

Thoracic outlet syndrome (TOS) is a neurovascular syndrome caused due to the compression of the lower trunk of brachial plexus (C8 and T1) and subclavian vessels in the thoracic outlet between the clavicle, the first rib, and scalene muscles.

Clinical features due to compression of:

  • Brachial plexus: Pain and paraesthesia along the ulnar aspect of the arm.
  • Subclavian vessels: Cyanosis, cold fingers, pallor and Raynaud's phenomenon.

Provocative tests: Adson's test, Halstead's maneuver, Wright's test, Roos test.

Adson’s test: The examiner locates the radial pulse while arm is held in extension, external rotation, and slight abduction. The patient is instructed to take a deep breath and turn head towards the test arm while extending the neck. This manoeuvre will tense the anterior and middle scalenes. If there is outlet obstruction, the radial pulse will get diminished or absent on that side. 

Halstead maneuver (reverse Adson's): The examiner palpates the radial pulse and applies downward traction on the tested extremity while the patient’s neck is hyperextended and rotated to the opposite side. Diminished or absent pulse indicates a positive test.

Wright’s hyperabduction test: The examiner palpates the radial pulse and hyper-abducts the arm. The patient takes a deep breath and may rotate or extend his neck for additional effect. Absence of pulse indicates a positive test.

Roos test: The patient abducts the shoulders to 90 degrees and flexes the elbow to 90 degrees. The patient is made to open and close the hand repeatedly for three minutes. The test is positive if the patient is unable to complete the test or experiences cramping, pain, numbness, on the affected side.

questions.text: A woman delivered her first baby in a face to pubes presentation 3 days ago. She complained of pain in her perineal region and inability to hold flatus and feces. Examination findings of her perineum are shown in the image below. What is the ideal time for intervention to manage this condition?
questions.solution:
The given image shows a complete tear of the anal sphincter, indicating a complete perineal tear. As the woman presented >24 hours after the tear, the best time to repair is 3-6 months after delivery.

The given image shows a fourth-degree perineal tear involving the vaginal mucosa, perineum, external and internal anal sphincters, and the anal mucosa. In this case, the risk factors were primigravida and face to pubes delivery. The main complaint in complete tears is fecal incontinence. It is regarded as a surgical emergency and should be repaired immediately following delivery of the placenta; if delayed by >24 hours repair is to be withheld and antibiotics should be started to prevent infection.

The optimum time for operation in case of old tears is 3-6 months after delivery. If attempted earlier than this healing by first intention is an exception due to the risk of infection, whereas if the operation is further delayed dense scar tissue forms which adds to operative difficulties.

questions.text: A child presents with fever and crops of pustules over the trunk with centripetal distribution. He is diagnosed with a virus for which humans are the only known reservoir. Which of the following is the most common site of extra-cutaneous manifestation ?
questions.solution:
The presence of fever with crops of pustules over the trunk in a centripetal distribution is suggestive of Varicella Zoster infection (chickenpox). Humans are the only known reservior for varicella zoster virus (VZV). The most common extra-cutaneous site of involvement in children is the central nervous system (CNS).

The syndrome of acute cerebellar ataxia and meningeal inflammation generally appears in 21 days after onset of the rash. The CSF contains lymphocytes and elevated levels of protein. CNS involvement is a benign complication of VZV infection in children and generally does not require hospitalization.

The most common infectious complication of varicella is secondary bacterial superinfection of the skin, which is caused by Streptococcus pyogenes or Staphylococcus aureus

The most common serious complication of varicella is Varicella pneumonia

questions.text: A 60-year-old asthmatic lady on inhalational bronchodilators presents with shortness of breath. Incidentally, you also notice the outpatient slip to be bearing the same date with an entry in the ophthalmology glaucoma clinic. Which of the possible drugs would have most likely exacerbated her attack of asthma?
questions.solution:
Timolol is a non-selective beta-blocker that is used in glaucoma. Non-selective beta-blockers can cause precipitation of bronchial asthma in susceptible individuals due to its antagonist effect on β2 receptor on bronchial smooth muscles. 

Timolol reduce intraocular pressure by decreasing aqueous formation by blockade of β2 receptor which are present on ciliary epithelium.

Timolol is also used for hypertension, congestive heart failure, acute myocardial infarction,and migraine prophylaxis. In ophthalmology, timolol has been used inthe treatment of open-angle glaucoma and intraocular hypertension. 

Timolol is associated with exacerbation of respiratory conditions like asthma & COPD, bradycardia, hypoglycemia, depression, and impotence (Due to non selective β2 receptor blockade).

Other options:

Option B : Betaxolol is a  β1 selective blocker that is used in glaucoma and has a lower propensity to precipitate bronchial asthma.

Options C : Celiprolol is a third-generation selective β1  blocker with weak β2 agnostic action used for hypertension. It is safe in asthmatics. 

Option D : Latanoprost is a prostaglandin (PGF2α) analog and safe in patients with bronchial asthma.

questions.text:
A child with feeding problems and muscle tone changes is diagnosed to have Maple-syrup urine disease. Match the amino acid responsible to the clinical feature seen in this condition.

1- caused a burnt-sugar odour in the urine
2- caused the neurological damage
questions.solution:
The burnt sugar odour in the urine is due to release of isoleucine in excess and the neurological changes are due to the toxic effect of leucine.

Maple-syrup urine disease is caused by defective oxidative decarboxylation of branched chain amino acids - valine, leucine, isoleucine. This occurs due to partial or complete deficiency of branched chain ketoacid dehydrogenase (BCKA) enzyme.

The resultant accumulation of these BCAAs and their ketoacids exert toxic effect in the nervous system causing muscle tone abnormalities, feeding difficulties and even upto coma.

Related Pearl: Maple syrup urine disease(MSUD)

questions.text: Select the correct statement regarding the nerve that supplies coracobrachialis.

choices.text: Gives sensory supply to lateral aspect of forearm
Gives motor supply to anterior compartment of forearm

questions.solution:
The nerve that supplies the coracobrachialis is the musculocutaneous nerve. It gives sensory supply to the lateral aspect of the forearm (statement A).

The musculocutaneous nerve (C5, C6, C7) is a branch of the lateral cord of the brachial plexus (statement C). It emerges at the lower border of the pectoralis minor and pierces coracobrachialis. It then descends between biceps brachii and brachialis where it supplies a branch to the shaft of the humerus. Then it enters the elbow and continues as the lateral cutaneous nerve of the forearm. 

Musculocutaneous nerve innervates all the muscles of the anterior compartment of the arm (statement B) i.e., 

  • Biceps brachii - involved in flexion of elbow and supination of the forearm
  • Brachialis -  involved in the flexion of the elbow
  • Coracobrachialis - flexes the arm at the glenohumeral joint

Injury to the musculocutaneous nerve results in weakness of supination of forearm (biceps brachii), weakness in flexion of the elbow (biceps brachii, brachialis), and loss of sensation over the lateral aspect of the forearm (lateral cutaneous nerve of the forearm).

NOTE: Ulnar nerve passes below guyon’s canal not musculocutaneous nerve.

questions.text: A patient with stroke is started on multiple medications. Which of the following drugs in his prescription can lead to thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura?
questions.solution:
Ticlopidine acts through the ADP receptor of the platelet and prevents its recruitment and activation, can lead to drug induced thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP).

Thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura is thrombotic microangiopathy that can be inherited or spontaneously acquired. It results from a deficiency of or antibodies to the metalloprotease ADAMTS13, which normally cleaves multimers of vWF.

Examples of drugs causing TTP are as follows:

  • Ticlopidine produces TTP by inducing an autoantibody to ADAMTS13
  • Quinine appears to induce autoantibodies to granulocytes, lymphocytes, endothelial cells, and platelet glycoprotein Ibβ/IX or IIb/IIIa complexes. Quinine-associated TTP is relatively more common among women.
  • Immunosuppressive agents: mitomycin C, gemcitabine, cyclosporine, tacrolimus and sirolimus
  • Bevacizumab

Other side effects of Ticlopidine include Diarrhea (most common), abdominal pain, headache, tinnitus, and skin rash. Serious adverse effects include - Bleeding, neutropenia, thrombocytopenia, hemolysis, and jaundice. Neutropenia incidence is around 2.4%.

questions.text: A 58-year-old woman with gout complains of acute onset redness of the eye as given below which is not associated with pain. On further probing, she gives a history of multiple visits to the hospital with the same complaints. What could be the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of an elderly female with gout presenting with recurrent acute onset redness of the eye not associated with pain and the image showing a nodule away from the limbus surrounded by redness is suggestive of nodular episcleritis.

Episcleritis is benign, recurrent, inflammation of the episclera, involving the overlying Tenon's capsule but not the underlying sclera. It is more common in women than in men. Causes include a hypersensitivity response to internal streptococcal or tubercular toxins. Syphilis, Tuberculosis, Lyme disease, and the herpes zoster virus can all lead to infectious episcleritis. It is also associated with systemic diseases like gout, rosacea, psoriasis and connective tissue diseases.

Episcleritis is characterized by redness, and mild ocular discomfort described as a gritty, burning, or foreign body sensation.

Clinically, two types of presentations may occur:

  • Simple episcleritis is characterized by sectorial or diffuse inflammation of the episclera. The image given below shows diffuse episcleritis:
  • Nodular episcleritis is characterized by a pink or purple flat nodule surrounded by erythema, usually situated 2-3 mm away from the limbus. The nodule is firm, and tender and can be moved separately from the sclera, and the overlying conjunctiva also moves freely.

Treatment includes topical NSAIDs, corticosteroid eye drops, cold compress, and artificial tears. In recurrent cases, systemic NSAIDs are used.

Other options:

Option B: Tenon's cyst or conjunctival inclusion cyst is a benign condition filled with serous fluid and slimy mucous secretions of congenital or acquired origin. Acquired cysts can occur following strabismus surgery, pars plana vitrectomy, scleral buckling, and Ahmed glaucoma valve insertion. The patient presents with swelling near the limbus with no pain or redness. The consistency is cystic to firm, non-tender with no mobility suggesting that the cyst is adherent to the underlying scleral tissue. The image of Tenon's cyst is given below:

Option D: Scleritis refers to an inflammation of the sclera proper. It usually occurs in elderly patients (40-70 years) involving females more than males. It is frequently associated with an underlying systemic inflammatory condition. The patient presents with moderate to severe pain, redness, lacrimation, photophobia, and diminution of vision.

questions.text:
Which of the following hormones act via stimulation of secondary messenger cAMP?

1. Vasopressin (V1 receptor)
2. Somatostatin
3. Oxytocin
4. Vasopressin (V2 receptor)
5. Secretin
questions.solution:
The hormones that act via stimulation of secondary messenger cAMP are somatostatin (2), vasopressin via V2 receptor (4), and secretin (5).

G protein-coupled receptors (GPCRs) are cell membrane receptors that span across the membrane 7 times. They also serve as receptors for various peptide hormones, neurotransmitters, amino acids, etc. Subtypes of GPCRs are distinguished by their alpha subunits. The important subtypes of GPCRs are Gs, Gi, and Gq.

  • Gs causes activation of adenylyl cyclase ,resulting in increased cAMP levels leading to activation of cAMP-dependent protein kinase.
  • Gi causes inhibition of adenylyl cyclase and results in K+ channel opening.
  • Gq causes activation of phospholipase C, which generates the second messengers inositol 1,4,5-trisphosphate (IP3) and diacylglycerol (DAG). The IP3 mobilizes calcium ions from mitochondria and the endoplasmic reticulum, and the calcium ions results in smooth muscle contraction and changes in cell secretion. DAG activates the enzyme protein kinase C and produces its effects.

Oxytocin and vasopressin (V1 receptor) act via Gq - phospholipase C secondary messenger pathway producing smooth muscle contraction.

questions.text: Which of the following is an ultra-short acting anaesthetic agent used for a short painful procedure?
questions.solution:
The ultra-short acting anaesthetic agent for a short painful procedure is remifentanil. Analgesic action (peak) is achieved within 1 to 1.5 min following intravenous administration.

The rapid onset of action and the rapid recovery (within 15 min) owing to metabolism by plasma esterases of remifentanil make it an ideal analgesic for short painful procedures. The elimination is independent of hepatic metabolism or renal excretion. Remifentanil is not used intraspinally because of formation of glycine which is a inhibitory neurotransmitter.

Other options: 

Option A : Sufentanil has rapid onset of action within 5 min. It is given intravenous or epidural route. Sufentanil and fentanyl are used in post operative or labour analegia.

Option C : Analgesic effects of meperidine is achieved in about 15 min after oral administration. It is effective in post anesthetic shivering. It is not used for longer duration due to accumulation of seizure-inducing metabolite (normeperidine) . It also causes histamine release. 

Option D : Fentanyl has rapid onset of action within 5 mins same as sufentanil and has short duration of action. But remifentanil is ultra short acting.

questions.text: A young woman presented with ocular pain, photophobia, and blurred vision in her left eye for 10 days. She explains that her symptoms started after she had slept without removing her contact lenses. Her left eye is shown in the image below. Intra-ocular pressure is normal in both eyes. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image shows localized bulging of the cornea surrounded by a white cicatricial ring suggestive of descemetocele. 

Descemetocele (Keratocele) is a localized bulging of Descemet's membrane. Patients with regular use of contact lenses are at higher risk of developing keratitis. Infections from the organisms like pneumococci, pseudomonas, and other septic organisms destroy all the layers of the cornea except for Descemet's membrane. However, this membrane alone is not able to support the intraocular pressure and therefore herniates. Patients will complain of pain, photophobia, and blurred vision.

The bulging membrane may persist surrounded by a white cicatricial ring or may rupture. It presents with severe pain and is a sign of impending perforation.

 

Other options:

Option A: Healed corneal ulcer will have a visual impairment and irregular opacity on the cornea.

The below image shows healed corneal ulcer.

 

Option C: In perforated corneal ulcers, patients complain of sudden gushing of hot fluid out of the eyes. Following this pain suddenly reduces. On examination, there is corneal opacity, prolapse of the iris, anterior dislocation of the lens, and reduced intraocular pressure.

Option D: Mooren's ulcer is a superficial ulcer that may occur due to autoimmune diseases. It starts as patches of grey infiltrates at the corneal margin. The ulcer then progresses to the whole of cornea.

Below image shows Mooren's ulcer in the periphery of the cornea.

questions.text: Which of the following types of Polymerase Chain Reaction uses two primer sets sequentially for amplification of the desired product?
questions.solution:
The sequential use of two primer sets to obtain the desired product is a feature of Nested PCR.

Nested polymerase chain reaction (PCR) is used in situations where the sensitivity and/or specificity of PCR needs to be increased. For example, amplification of a cDNA copy present at very low abundance in a clinical specimen containing a heterogeneous population of cell types. It involves two sequential amplification reactions, each of which uses a different pair of primers.

The first primer set is used for the amplification of the target sequence. The amplicon (product of the first amplification) obtained is then used to amplify specific regions belonging to the first target, in the second amplification. This ensures increased specificity. Nested PCR is currently used in GeneXpert to detect Mycobacterium TB and resistance to rifampicin as a part of drug resistance detection in the RNTCP program. The image depicts the process of Nested PCR.

RT-PCR (Option A) or Reverse transcriptase PCR is used to amplify RNA and thus help in detecting RNA-containing viruses. The enzyme reverse transcriptase (RT) is used to synthesize a complimentary copy of DNA (cDNA) from RNA, and this cDNA is then used as a template for PCR.

Multiplex PCR (Option C) uses multiple primers to amplify several DNA sequences simultaneously. As this process targets multiple genes simultaneously, a single test run gives additional information that would otherwise require several times the reagents and technician time to perform.

q-PCR (Option D) or Quantitative PCR or Real-time PCR helps quantify the PCR and estimates the pathogen DNA load in the specimen. It uses fluorescent dyes or specific DNA probes.

questions.text:
You are resuscitating a term neonate who did not cry at birth. Despite 1 minute of effective PPV, heart rate is less than 60. What would you do next?

PPV - Positive Pressure Ventilation
questions.solution:
In this scenario where the neonate’s heart rate is less than 60 despite 1 minute of effective positive pressure ventilation (PPV), the next best step would be to intubate and start chest compressions.

Initiating positive pressure ventilation is the single most important step in babies who fail to breathe at birth. Ventilation should be carried out at 40-60 breaths/min (following a squeeze, two, three sequence). Response to PPV is primarily indicated by an increase in heart rate.

Signs of effective ventilation include:

  • Adequate chest rise
  • Symmetric breath sounds
  • Increase in heart rate
  • Improvement in color
  • Improvement in tone
  • Improvement in oxygen saturation
  • Spontaneous respiratory efforts

If there are no signs of effective ventilation even after 30 seconds of PPV, ventilation corrective steps (Mnemonic - MRSOPA) should be carried out. MRSOPA comprises:

  • Mask readjustment
  • Repositioning the head
  • Suctioning mouth followed by nose
  • Opening the mouth
  • Increasing the Pressure of ventilation
  • Establishing an Alternate airway

Endotracheal intubation is indicated if heart rate is less than 100 beats per minute despite 30 seconds of effective PPV. Chest compressions are to be initiated if heart rate is less than 60 beats per minute following endotracheal intubation. A positive breath should follow every third chest compression. The ratio of compressions to ventilation is 3:1 (90 compressions: 30 breaths). 

After 60 seconds of ventilation with chest compressions, if heart rate is still less than 60 beats per minute, adrenaline needs to be administered. The dose of adrenaline is 0.2 ml/kg (0.1-0.3 ml/kg) of 1:10,000 dilution.

questions.text: A 30-year-old pregnant woman in her third trimester presented with tense periumbilical blisters preceded by severe itching for the past week. Direct immunofluorescence of the perilesional skin reveals linear C3 deposition along the dermoepidermal junction. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The history of pruritis along with the presence of blisters in the periumbilical region during pregnancy clinches the diagnosis of pemphigoid gestationis.

Pemphigoid gestationis is an autoimmune, bullous disorder that presents mainly in late pregnancy or the immediate postpartum period. It is associated with intense pruritus that occasionally may precede skin lesions. Initially, erythematous urticarial papules and plaques typically develop on the abdomen, characteristically involving the periumbilical region and later progress to tense blisters, resembling bullous pemphigoid. Complement fixing IgG antibodies against BP 180 antigen of the hemidesmosomes at the dermoepidermal junction are responsible for the linear immunofluorescence.

Other options :

Option A)Although bullous pemphigoid can cause tense blisters with linear immunofluorescence it presents in the older age group. The history of pregnancy and involvement of umbilicus makes diagnosis of pemphigoid gestationis more likely.

Option B) Polymorphic eruption of pregnancy is another pruritic inflammatory condition affecting pregnancy. It typically starts on the abdomen, often within the striae distensae if present, with severely pruritic urticarial papules that coalesce into plaques, spreading to the buttocks and proximal thighs. However it spares the umbilicus and never develops into blisters. Direct immunofluorescence is usually negative.

Option D)Atopic eruption of pregnancy is a benign pruritic disorder of pregnancy that includes eczematous and/or papular lesions in patients with an atopic diathesis, once the other dermatoses of pregnancy have been excluded. It affects typical atopic sites such as the face, neck and flexural surfaces of the limbs. Immunofluorescnce studies are negative.

questions.text: Which of the following is not true with respect to Onchocerca volvulus life cycle?

choices.text: Female black flies are the intermediate host
L3 larva is the infective form
Lifespan of microfilaria in humans is 30 - 45 days

questions.solution:
The adult worm of Onchocerca volvulus can live in the human host for about 15 years while the microfilariae for about a year.

The life cycle is completed partly in humans, the definitive host, and partly in a female black fly, the intermediate host (not male).

During a blood meal, the female black fly ingests the microfilariae from the skin and lymphatics of an infected person. It is within the vector that the microfilariae develop into first-stage larvae and subsequently into third-stage infective larvae (L3).

When the infected black fly bites another person, it introduces third-stage filarial larvae into the skin of the human host.

They penetrate into the bite wound and develop into adult worms in the subcutaneous tissues within subcutaneous nodules called onchocercomas or live freely in the tissues.

questions.text: A boy who presented with polyendocrinopathy and enteropathy is diagnosed with IPEX syndrome. Which of the following is used as the diagnostic test as depicted in the image below ?
questions.solution:
The diagnostic test depicted in the image is flow cytometry.

Flow cytometry can be used for the rapid detection of various physical and chemical properties of a cell. It works on the principle of hydrodynamic focusing of cell suspensions. Flow cytometers employ lasers as light sources to produce both scatter and fluorescent light signals. Cells are allowed to pass through a laser beam, one at a time and are analyzed for visible light scatter. 

Visible light scatter is measured in two different directions - forward scatter indicates the relative size of the cell and side scatter indicates the granularity or internal complexity of the cell. The results of the flow cytometric analysis are often interpreted as a dot-plot histogram.

The results can be interpreted as follows:

Quadrant 1- Cells marked in green: -VE for A antigen, +VE for B antigen
Quadrant 2- Cells marked in purple: -VE for both the antigens.
Quadrant 3- Cells marked in yellow: +VE for both the antigens.
Quadrant 4- Cells marked in red: +VE for A antigen, -VE for B antigen

The image depicted in the question shows positivity for both CD25 and FOXP3, seen in positive T regulatory cells, suggestive of IPEX syndrome.

Uses of flow cytometry are:

  • Cell counting
  • Cell sorting
  • Cell cycle analysis
  • Immunophenotyping
  • Analysis of microorganisms

Flow cytometry is thereby having its application in immunology, molecular biology, oncology and infectious disease monitoring.

Immunohistochemistry is a technique that incorporates immunology and histopathology. It is used to detect specific antigens in cells and tissues by using antibodies. The quality of the immunohistochemical stain depends on the integrity of the antigen-antibody interaction. Cells are examined under the light microscope.

They are used in:

  • Categorization of undifferentiated malignancies
  • Determination of site of origin of metastatic tumors
  • Determination of molecules that have prognostic or therapeutic significance

The image below is of PAX5 immunohistochemistry in a case of relapsed Hodgkin’s lymphoma:

 

Southwestern blot is used to analyze DNA-protein interactions.This method detects specific DNA-binding proteins by incubating radiolabeled DNA with a gel blot, washing, and visualizing through autoradiography. 

Cytogenetics is the study of chromosomes and their role in heredity. It entails the structure and properties of chromosomes, and their behavior during mitosis and meiosis. Some of the cytogenetic techniques used are:

  • Karyotyping
  • Fluorescent in situ hybridization (FISH)
  • Comparative genomic hybridization (CGH)

questions.text: A group of third MBBS students are on an industrial visit to the nearby milk factory. Their community medicine professor is quizzing them on the Holder method of milk pasteurization. What are the duration and the temperature at which the milk is heated in this method?
questions.solution:
In the Holder method of pasteurization, the milk is heated at 63°C for 30 minutes, followed by cooling quickly to 13°C or lower.

In the flash process of pasteurization, the milk is heated at 72°C for 15-20 seconds followed by cooling quickly to 13°C or lower.

These processes destroy all non-sporing pathogens such as Mycobacteria, Brucellae, and Salmonellae. Coxiella burnetii which is the causative organism of Q fever, is relatively heat-resistant and may survive the Holder method.

questions.text:
Fine needle aspiration cytology (FNAC) is used as the confirmatory test in which of the following conditions?

1. Mycetoma
2. Follicular carcinoma of the thyroid
3. Mediastinal tumour
4. Hepatic echinococcosis 
5. Granulomatous thyroiditis
questions.solution:
FNAC is used as the confirmatory test in diagnosing 1, 3, and 5 - mycetoma, mediastinal masses and granulomatous thyroiditis.

Fine needle aspiration cytology involves the puncture of the mass using a fine needle and immediate aspiration for assessment of cytology of the mass. A 21G or 23G needle and a 10 mL syringe are used. Aspiration must be done only when the needle is within the swelling. The sample is then smeared on a microscopic slide and fixed and sent for assessment. But if it can be immediately assessed, it can be sent without fixation. A positive FNA depends on the quality of the sample obtained and the skill of the cytologist.

It is used to sample accessible sites such as the breast, thyroid, and superficial lymph nodes. But, if FNA needs to be done for deeper structures, it is done under imaging guidance with ultrasound (USG) or computed tomography (CT). For example, USG-guided transbronchial FNA is used to assess mediastinal masses (3)

FNAC cannot distinguish between a follicular adenoma and a follicular carcinoma (2) of the thyroid. This distinction depends on histology based on capsular and vascular invasion and not on cytology. Diagnosis and treatment are made by wide local excision of the mass.

FNAC is also contraindicated in hepatic echinococcosis because of the risk of spillage of hydatid fluid, which can potentially cause peritoneal spread of the infestation and more importantly, fatal anaphylaxis.

There are certain contraindications for performing an FNAC : 

  • Hepatic echinococcosis
  • Bleeding diathesis
  • Hepatic surface hemangioma
  • Scrotal / testicular masses (risk of tumour seeding)
  • Mass near carotid bifurcation (carotid body tumour)

questions.text: A wildlife enthusiast presented with a small black lesion on his hand over the site of an insect bite. He had fever for 3 days. The agglutination pattern in Weil-Felix reaction was negative for OX 19 and OX2. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The history of wildlife travel with a small black lesion over the site of insect bite called an eschar is suggestive of scrub typhus. This is supported by negative OX 19 and OX2 agglutination pattern in Weil-Felix reaction.

Scrub typhus is caused by Orientia tsutsugamushi. It is diagnosed by Weil-Felix reaction, which is an agglutination test in which sera are tested for agglutinins to the O antigens of certain non-motile Proteus strains OX 19, OX 2 and OX K. 

Scrub typhus shows negative reaction for OX 2 and OX19, but it shows positive for OX K. All the other diseases are positive for either OX2 or OX19.

This is shown in the table below:

DISEASE OX 19 OX 2 OX K
Scrub typhus - - +++
Endemic typhus +++ +/- -
Epidemic typhus +++ + -
Tickborne spotted fever ++ ++ -

questions.text: During the cardiovascular examination of a pregnant woman, which among the following findings is not considered physiological change?
questions.solution:
Among the given options, exaggerated splitting of S2 is not a physiological change seen in pregnancy.

Physiological changes in the cardiovascular system in pregnancy:

  • Exaggerated splitting of S1 and increased loudness of both components
  • Loud, easily heard third heart sound (S3)
  • A sys­tolic murmur that intensifies on inspiration or expiration
  • Soft diastolic murmur
  • Mammary souffle- continuous murmur at 2nd to 4th intercostal space
  • A shift of the cardiac apex laterally
  • ECG changes: 
    • Left axis deviation
    • Q waves in leads 2, 3 and avF
    • Flat or inverted T waves in lead 3, V1-V3
  • Increased cardiac output, heart rate, and ejection fraction
  • Decreased systemic vascular resistance and blood pressure

Related Pearl: Cardiovascular changes in pregnancy

  • The resting pulse rate increases by 10 beats/min
  • The apex is moved laterally 
  • Cardiac output remains elevated throughout (maximum in the immediate postpartum period)
  • X-Ray shows a larger cardiac silhouette (due to benign pericardial effusion and shifted apex)
  • ECG: Slight left axis deviation

Heart sounds:

  • First heart sound: Loud with an exaggerated split
  • Second heart sound: Normal but loud
  • Third heart sound: Loud and easily heard

Murmurs:

  • A systolic murmur that was intensified during inspiration or expiration
  • A soft diastolic murmur (in 20%)
  • Continuous murmur arising from the breast vasculature (in 10%)

questions.text:
Which of the following options accurately describes smooth muscle contraction?

SERCA: Sarcoendoplasmic reticulum calcium ATPase

choices.text: Smooth muscle uses calmodulin instead of troponin C for binding Ca2+
Smooth muscle contraction relies solely on extracellular Ca2+
Both skeletal and smooth muscle release Ca2+ through the same mechanism

questions.solution:
The correct statement that accurately describes smooth muscle contraction is that smooth muscle uses calmodulin instead of troponin C for Ca2+ binding and myosin activation.

Calmodulin is structurally and functionally related to troponin. In place of troponin, smooth muscle cells contain a large amount of the regulatory protein calmodulin; it is different in the manner in which it initiates contraction. Calmodulin initiates contraction by activating the myosin light chain kinase. Troponin, on the other hand, initiates contraction by causing a conformational change in the tropomyosin molecule which then uncovers the active sites on the actin filament.

The sequence of events in smooth muscle contraction:

  • Binding of acetylcholine to muscarinic receptors
  • Increased influx of Ca2+ into the cell
  • Activation of calmodulin-dependent myosin light chain kinase
  • Myosin phosphorylation
  • Increased myosin ATPase activity and binding of myosin to actin

Other options:

Option B: Smooth muscle utilizes both internal stores and extracellular Ca2+ for contraction, not solely the latter.

Option C: Smooth muscle possesses SERCA pumps for Ca2+ reuptake, although with different isoforms compared to skeletal muscle. Prolonged contraction can occur due to other factors but not from missing SERCA. 

Option D: The mechanism of Ca2+ release is different in skeletal muscles and smooth muscles.  

In skeletal muscle, the voltage-gated dihydropyridine receptor(DHPR) in the T tubule triggers Ca2+ release from the sarcoplasmic reticulum via the ryanodine receptor (RyR). Upon sensing voltage change by DHPR receptors, there is a physical interaction between the sarcolemmal-bound DHPR and the sarcoplasmic reticulum-bound RyR. This interaction opens the RyR and allows for Ca2+ release from the sarcoplasmic reticulum.

In smooth muscles, depending on the activating stimulus, cytosolic Ca2+ increase can be due to Ca2+ influx through

  • voltage or ligand-gated Ca2+ channels in the plasma membrane.
  • Ca2+ release from sarcoplasmic reticulum through the RyR as in skeletal muscles.
  • Inositol trisphosphate receptor (IP3R) induced Ca2+ release from the sarcoplasmic reticulum.

In cardiac muscles , release of Ca2+ is through the same mechanism of Ca2+ release as like skeletal muscles , but additionally extracellular Ca2+ passing through voltage-gated DHPR channels play a role in activating RyR receptors and not mere physical interaction between DHPR and RyR receptors.

Related Pearl: Sarcomere

questions.text: Which of the following tests measures ratio of weight of the lungs to the body weight  that helps in determination of  whether the baby was born alive or not?
questions.solution:
The test that measures the ratio of the weight of the lungs to the body weight  that helps in the determination of  whether the baby was born alive or not is Plocquet’s test.

Ploucquet’s test: It is based on the ratio of weight of lungs to whole body weight, a respired lung weighs 1/35 of the body weight.

Before respiration 1/70 of body weight
After respiration 1/35 of body weight

Other options:

Option A: Hydrostatic Test/Floatation Test/Raygat's Test: It is based on the lung changes in a fetus after respiration. On breathing, the volume of the lungs is increased, which more than compensates for the weight of additional blood, due to which specific gravity is diminished. Hence, after respiration, the lung floats in water.

Option C: Breslau's second life test: It works on the principle that some air is swallowed during respiration in a live born child and detecting the presence of this air in these viscera constitutes the basis for this test.

Option D: Wredin’s test: Before birth, the middle ear contains gelatinous embryonic connective tissue and not air. With respiration, the eustachian tube opens and air replaces the gelatinous substances in a few hours to five weeks.

questions.text: Which color of Venturi device will you use to administer a 40% concentration of oxygen to the patient?
questions.solution:
The red venturi device is used to deliver 40% concentration of oxygen to the patient.

The Venturi mask is a high-flow oxygen delivery system with a fixed-performance device. It can deliver a maximum oxygen concentration (FiO2) of 60% at a flow rate of 15 L/min.

Red 40%

The Venturi mask is used to deliver oxygen to patients when a specific and consistent concentration is needed. It is the preferred mode of oxygen delivery for COPD patients due to the accuracy of oxygen concentration.

questions.text: A 24-year-old nulligravid woman is to undergo a hysterosalpingogram to look for uterine anomalies. The gynaecologist chooses Leech-Wilkinson cannula for the procedure. Identify the instrument.
questions.solution:
Instrument 2 is Leech Wilkinson cannula. It can be identified by the spiral cone at the tip.

Hysterosalpingography (HSG) is a technique used for visualization of the uterine cavity and fallopian tubes by the injection of a radiopaque dye, and visualization of the dye by fluoroscopy as it passes through the uterine cavity and fallopian tubes.

It is best performed between the end of the menstrual period and ovulation (i.e 9th or 10th day of the cycle).

The patient is pre-medicated with atropine and analgesia to prevent tubal spasm, especially in an apprehensive woman. Then, 10-15ml of the dye is injected using a Leech-Wilkinson cannula, Rubin's cannula, or Foley's catheter. If the tubes are patent, the dye will spill out of the tubal ostia and smear the adjacent bowel.

It is used to detect:

  • Tubal block.
  • Uterine anomalies
  • Uterine polyps
  • Uterine synechiae
  • The feasibility to tuboplasty, by studying the location and extent of tubal pathology

Contraindications for HSG:

  • Presence of genital tract infection and bleeding.
  • Genital tuberculosis, due to the risk of spreading infection.
  • Suspected pregnancy.
  • Allergy to the dye.
  • Premenstrual phase
    • If by chance pregnancy has occurred, it may be dislodged.
    • Thick endometrium might prevent the smooth flow of the dye, at the cornual end.
    • There is a risk of embolism and endometriosis if HSG is done during this phase.

Other options

Instrument 1 - Rubins cannula - used to introduce dye into the uterine cavity during hysterosalpingography or diagnostic laparoscopy.

Instrument 3 - Karman's cannula. It is used for menstrual regulation. It can be identified by the whistle-like tip.

Instrument 4 - Simpson's uterine sound. It is used to measure the length of uterus. It can be identified by the markings used for measurement.

Related Pearl: Instruments in OBG

questions.text: Identify the correctly matched pair of drug and the receptor on which it acts:
questions.solution:
The correctly matched option is Isoproterenol - β1.

Isoproterenol is a non-selective beta agonist (β1=β2) with no α action. The direct action on cardiac β1 receptors causes an increased risk of tachycardia and arrhythmias. The decrease in peripheral vascular resistance is due to β2 action causing a fall in diastolic blood pressure and

Isoproterenol currently may be used as a cardiac stimulant in patients with bradycardia or heart block, particularly in anticipation of inserting an artificial cardiac pacemaker.

Other options:

Option A: Midodrine is an α1 receptor agonist. It is used for autonomic insufficiency and postural hypotension.

Option B: Fenoldopam is a D1 receptor agonist. It is a vasodilator and primarily vasodilates coronary, peripheral, renal, and splanchnic vessels. It also promotes natriuresis and is used in postoperative hypertension and hypertensive crises.

Option C: Dobutamine acts on β1>β2 and α receptors. It is used in cardiac stress testing and acute decompensated heart failure with cardiogenic shock.

questions.text: A patient presents with rapid y descent, prominent x descent, and Kussmaul sign on jugular venous pulse examination. Which of the following conditions is most likely responsible for these findings?
questions.solution:
The combination of rapid y descent, prominent x descent (forming a W- or M-shaped waveform), and Kussmaul sign is highly suggestive of constrictive pericarditis.

The restricted atrial and ventricular filling leads to rapid and deep descents. The Kussmaul sign is an elevation of JVP during inspiration. It reflects impaired right ventricular compliance during inspiration.


The waveforms seen in a normal JVP are:

  • a wave corresponds to atrial contraction and occurs just after the P wave (on ECG) and just before the first heart sound.
  • c wave represents the bulging of the tricuspid valve into the right atrium during ventricular systole.
  • x descent corresponds to the atrial relaxation during atrial diastole.
  • v wave represents atrial filling during ventricular systole and peaks at the second heart sound.
  • y descent represents passive emptying of the right atrium into the right ventricle after tricuspid valve opening.

A normal tracing of the jugular venous pulse is given below:


Other options:

Option B: Cardiac tamponade:  On JVP tracing, cardiac tamponade characteristically shows a prominent x-descent and absent y-descent.

The image of JVP in cardiac tamponade is given below:


Option C: Tricuspid regurgitation will have accentuated v wave with rapid y descent, as shown below.


Option D: Tricuspid stenosis will have prolonged y wave, as shown below.

1) The a-wave corresponds to atrial contraction.

Abnormality Conditions

Cannon a-waves

Complete AV block, ventricular tachycardia, and premature atrial/ junctional/ ventricular beats
Absent a-waves Atrial fibrillation

 

2) The c-wave corresponds to the bulging of tricuspid valve into right atrium during ventricular contraction.

 

3) The x-descent corresponds to atrial relaxation during atrial diastole.

Abnormality Conditions

4) The v-wave corresponds to the venous filling of right atrium.

Abnormality Conditions

5) The y-descent corresponds to the passive emptying of the right atrium into right ventricle.

Abnormality Conditions
Prolonged y-descent Tricuspid stenosis
Rapid y-descent

Constrictive pericarditis and isolated severe tricuspid regurgitation
Absent y-descent Cardiac tamponade

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presents with an acutely painful, purple protrusion at the anal verge for the past 12 hours, as shown in the image. He reports pain and straining during recent bowel movements and denies any bleeding or fever. What is the most appropriate management for this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette is suggestive of thrombosed external hemorrhoids. As the patient presented within the first 48 hours of thrombosis, the most appropriate management is evacuation of the clot under local anesthesia.

Thrombosed external hemorrhoids, also called perianal hematomas, present with sudden onset pain and a tender bluish swelling at the anal margin. If presenting within the first 48 hours, clot evacuation is done. If it presents after 48 hours, it is treated conservatively with analgesics and a Sitz bath (Option A). Once the symptoms come down, definitive surgery is performed.

External hemorrhoids occur as a result of dilatation of the superficial or external hemorrhoidal plexus. They appear as rubbery lumps at the anal orifice. They usually don't need any specific treatment and can be conservatively managed by giving stool softeners and ensuring adequate fluid intake, good physical activity, and a high-fiber diet.


Other options:

Option C and D: Injection sclerotherapy and rubber band ligation are done for 1st and 2nd degree internal hemorrhoids.

questions.text: A farmer presents with eczematous eruption all over his upper limbs and face. He has had similar episodes during previous cultivation times also and you suspect airborne contact dermatitis. Which of the following would have commonly caused this?
questions.solution:
In India, the weed Parthenium is the most common cause of airborne contact dermatitis.

Many allergenic plants, especially those belonging to the Compositae (Asteraceae) family, are destroyed by cold and frosty weather, but return during the warmer spring and summer months. Compositae allergy is seen in many parts of the world, but the plants responsible vary.

  • Ragweed is the main cause in the USA (Option D)
  • Chrysanthemums and garden weeds in Europe
  • Toxicodendron species are mainly seen in North America

After confirming the allergen using patch test, avoidance of contact and topical corticosteroids is the mainstay of treatment

questions.text: A woman at 34 weeks of gestation presents with severe pruritus and yellowish discoloration of the sclera. Her total bilirubin level was 3.8 mg/dL and serum transaminase levels were mildly elevated. Which of the following is not a possible complication of her condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical features are suggestive of intrahepatic cholestasis of pregnancy. Antepartum hemorrhage is not a complication of obstetric cholestasis.

Complications of obstetric cholestasis are-

  • Spontaneous preterm births 
  • Respiratory distress syndrome in the infant
  • Sudden fetal death/ stillbirths
  • Passage of meconium and fetal distress
  • Rarely, fetal coagulopathy with intracranial hemorrhage (Can be prevented by giving Vitamin K to the mother)

Intrahepatic cholestasis of pregnancy is a reversible cholestatic disease that may occur later in pregnancy. It is characterized by intense pruritus, which is worse on palms and soles, and icterus. The key laboratory findings include increased serum bile acid levels, elevated transaminases, and elevated direct and total bilirubin serum concentrations.

Management:

  • Antihistamines and topical emollients 
  • Cholestyramine
  • Ursodeoxycholic acid

Ursodeoxycholic acid is the drug of choice in obstetric cholestasis. Cholestyramine causes decreased absorption of fat-soluble vitamins, which leads to vitamin K deficiency. Fetal coagulopathy may develop, which may lead to intracranial hemorrhage and stillbirth, and therefore it is not preferred.

questions.text: A child brought to a vaccination camp is allergic to neomycin. Which of the following vaccines is contraindicated for this child?
questions.solution:
Among the given vaccines, Varicella vaccine is contraindicated in a child with a known allergy to neomycin (Option D).

Other options -

Options A and B - MMR  and IPV vaccines each contain less than 25 micrograms of neomycin per dose. Persons who are known to be allergic to neomycin should be closely observed after administration of vaccine so that any allergic reaction can be treated immediately.

Option C - Japanese Encephalitis(JE) vaccine does not constitute neomycin as a constituent. Hence, can be given safely to a person with neomycin allergy.

questions.text: A patient who had cholecystectomy 3 days ago now presented with severe abdominal pain and fever. He is tachycardic and hypotensive. What is the most appropriate management for this patient ?
questions.solution:
The clinical features post-cholecystectomy along with tachycardia and hypotension suggest sepsis secondary to biliary tract injury and intra-abdominal bile leak. If 48 hours have gone by, the chances of the surrounding tissue getting inflammed is high and hence Magnetic Resonance Cholangiopancreatography (MRCP) followed by Endoscope Retrograde Cholangiopancreatography (ERCP) and stenting is the most appropriate management because it is both diagnostic and therapeutic.

Bike leak identified immediately after surgery can be managed by inserting a drain (option B) and if patient remains stable, no specific intervention is needed. If a patient presents with similar features within 48 hours of surgery, re-exploration should be done and depend on the type, location and extent of the injury, appropriate repair can be done.

Bile duct injury identified during the surgery can be managed as follows : 

  • Incomplete injury : repair of the injured part
  • Transection without segmental loss : T-tube insertion and anastomosis (option C)
  • Transection with segmental loss : Roux-en-Y hepaticoduodenostomy / jejunostomy (option D)
  • Type A: Bile leak from cystic duct stump or a minor biliary radical in the gallbladder fossa
  • Type B: Occluded right posterior sectoral duct.
  • Type C: Bile leak from the divided right posterior sectoral duct.
  • Type D: Bile leak from the main bile duct without major tissue loss.
  • Type E: Injury to the main hepatic duct; classified according to the level of injury


E1: Transected main bile duct with a stricture more than 2cm from the hilus.
E2: Transected main bile duct with a stricture less than 2cm from the hilus
E3: Stricture of the hilus with right and left ducts in communication.
E4: Stricture of the hilus with separation of right and left hepatic ducts.
E5: Stricture of the right aberrant sectoral duct and the main bile duct.

questions.text: Which of the following services does the following health program provide?

choices.text: Free delivery and treatment services for mother and neonate
Improve nutrition status of pregnant mothers

questions.solution:
The given logo is that of the national programme - Janani Shishu Suraksha Karyakram (JSSK) and one of the services provided by the programme is free delivery and treatment services for mother and neonate (Option B).

Under JSSK, the following are the free entitlements for pregnant women:

  • Free and cashless delivery
  • Free C-Section
  • Free drugs and consumables
  • Free diagnostics
  • Free diet during the stay in the health institutions
  • Free provision of blood
  • Exemption from user charges
  • Free transport from home to health institutions
  • Free transport between facilities in case of a referral
  • Free drop back from Institutions to home after 48 hours stay

The following are the free entitlements for sick newborns till 30 days after birth. This has now been expanded to cover sick infants:

  • Free treatment
  • Free drugs and consumables
  • Free diagnostics
  • Free provision of blood
  • Exemption from user charges
  • Free Transport from Home to Health Institutions
  • Free Transport between facilities in case of a referral
  • Free drop Back from Institutions to home

 

Other options -

Option A - Janani Suraksha Yojana promotes institutional delivery among poor pregnant women by giving cash incentives  to reduce maternal and neonatal mortality rate. Other services include , safe motherhood services (IFA tablets, TT vaccination) under the Vande Mataram scheme , safe abortion services, pregnancy tracking and maternal death review.

Option C - Prime Minister’s Overarching Scheme for Holistic Nourishment (POSHAN) Abhiyaan is the programme concerned with improving nutritional status of infants, pregnant women and lactating women.

It targets to reduce stunting, underweight, and low birth weight by 2% per annum. The target for the reduction in anemia among young children, and adolescent girls is 3% per annum.

Option D - Integrated child development services (ICDS) program provides preschool non-formal education through Anganwadis.

ICDS was launched on the 2nd of October, 1975, and focuses on early childhood care and development. Beneficiaries under the scheme are children in the age group of 0-6 years,adolescent girls, reproductive age group women, pregnant women and lactating mothers.

questions.text: An 8-month-old male baby presents with a history of recurrent sinusitis and otitis media. Further assessment shows normal cellular immunity and the absence of surface IgG on flow cytometry. Histopathology of lymph node shows underdeveloped germinal centers. His father gives a history of the death of another male child due to this condition.  Which of the following is correct regarding this condition?
questions.solution:
The history of recurrent sinusitis and otitis media, the same disease in another male sibling, flow cytometry revealing the absence of surface IgG in the presence of normal cellular immunity, and histopathology showing underdeveloped germinal centers of the lymph node are suggestive of Bruton X-linked agammaglobulinemia. It occurs due to a defect in the cytoplasmic tyrosine kinase called Burton's tyrosine kinase.

The congenital disorder Bruton X-linked agammaglobulinemia occurs in male infants. The disease typically shows symptoms after six months of life due to the depletion of maternal immunoglobulins.

It is caused by mutations in a cytoplasmic tyrosine kinase located on the long arm of the X chromosome, called Bruton tyrosine kinase (Btk). This gene encodes an enzyme critical to B-lymphocyte maturation. Recurrent bacterial respiratory tract infections, including sinusitis, otitis media, pneumonia, bronchitis, and acute and chronic pharyngitis are common.

In the classic form of this disease, B-cells are absent or markedly decreased. Serum levels of all classes of immunoglobulins are decreased. Plasma cells are absent, and germinal centers of lymphoid organs are underdeveloped. It is treated using replacement therapy with immunoglobulins.

Other options:

Option B: Defect in CD40 ligand leads to hyper IgM syndrome. Patients present with recurrent staphylococcal skin abscesses, recurrent lung infections (pneumatoceles), eczema, eosinophilia, and extremely low serum levels of IgG, and no IgA and IgE. 

Option C: BAFF gene mutation leads to common variable immunodeficiency. Patients usually have persistent diarrhoea caused by G. lamblia, recurring sinopulmonary pyogenic infections, and potentially serious enterovirus infections that cause meningoencephalitis. Symptoms appear later in childhood or adolescence than in X-linked agammaglobulinemia.

Option D: WASP gene mutation leads to Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome. In this syndrome, the triad of thrombocytopenia, eczema, and recurrent infections are observed.

  • Transient hypogammaglobulinemia of infancy

  • Chronic mucocutaneous candidiasis
  • DiGeorge syndrome
  • X-linked lymphoproliferative syndrome

questions.text: A 60-year-old chronic smoker presents with complaints of progressive proximal muscle weakness which seems to improve temporarily with exercise. He also has complaints of diplopia and dryness of mouth. Repetitive nerve stimulation reveals an incremental response. Which of the following could be beneficial in the treatment of his symptoms?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario points to Lambert-Eaton myasthenic syndrome(LEMS). Aminopyridines are used in the treatment of this condition. 

Lambert-Eaton myasthenic syndrome is commonly associated with small cell carcinoma of lung in the elderly as a paraneoplastic syndrome and an incremental response on nerve stimulation confirms the diagnosis. Myasthenia gravis shows decremental response on nerve stimulation.

Aminopyridines are potassium channel blockers that cause an increase in ACh release from the presynaptic neuron and thereby improve muscle strength. Presynaptic potassium channel blockade promotes the activation of voltage-gated calcium channels (VGCCs). This leads to a release of acetylcholine in the neuromuscular junction and thereby causes symptomatic improvement. 

Pyridostigmine prolongs the action of acetylcholine, allowing repeated interactions with acetylcholine receptors and thereby helps in reducing symptoms. Plasmapheresis and immunotherapy can also help in the management of LEMS, as for myasthenia gravis.

Other options - 

Option A - Succinylcholine is a depolarising neuromuscular blocker used for skeletal muscle relaxation during general anesthesia. It acts by competitively inhibiting acetylcholine in the Nm receptor and producing prolonged depolarization of the membrane leading to brief periods of repetitive excitation(fasciculations) initially, followed by blocking of neuromuscular transmission and flaccid paralysis(phase I block). It will worsen the Lambert-Eaton myasthenic crisis.

Option B - Atropine is an anticholinergic drug which acts by competitively inhibiting acetylcholine binding on muscarinic receptors and thereby causing anti-muscarinic effects. It has no action on nicotinic receptors and hence not useful in Lambert-Eaton myasthenic syndrome.

Option C - Edrophonium is a quarternary amine which acts as a short acting acetylcholinesterase inhibitor leading to prolonged Ach binding to the Nm receptors and thereby increasing muscle excitation shortly. It is used as a diagnostic test to differentiate between myasthenia crisis and a cholinergic crisis.

The edrophonium test is performed by rapid intravenous injection of 2 mg of edrophonium chloride, followed 45 seconds later by an additional 8 mg if the first dose is without effect. A positive response or an improvement in muscle weakness implies a  myasthenic crisis and a negative response or worsening of muscle weakness implies cholinergic crisis(excessive Ach in the Nm receptors leading to prolonged depolarisation like succinyl choline). The duration of action is approximately for 10 minutes.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements are true regarding the regulation of cholesterol synthesis?
  1. Insulin and thyroxine decrease HMG CoA reductase activity.
  2. Cortisol and glucagon decrease HMG CoA reductase activity.
  3. Statins inhibit HMG CoA reductase.
  4. Cholesterol increases HMG CoA reductase activity.
  5. Cholesterol represses transcription of HMG CoA reductase mRNA.
questions.solution:
Statements 2, 3, and 5 are true regarding the regulation of cholesterol synthesis.

HMG CoA reductase is the principal enzyme involved in the regulation of cholesterol synthesis. Cholesterol is synthesized from acetyl-CoA mainly in the liver and intestine. This process occurs in the endoplasmic reticulum and cytosol.

HMG-CoA reductase reduces HMG-CoA to mevalonate by NADPH in the pathway of cholesterol synthesis. This principal regulatory step is targeted by statins, which are drugs that efficiently lower cholesterol by inhibiting HMG-CoA reductase.

Activity of HMG-CoA reductase is influenced by the following factors:

  • By-products of the cholesterol synthesis pathway: Mevalonate, the immediate product of the reaction, and cholesterol, the main product of the pathway, inhibit enzyme activity. These metabolites also repress transcription of HMG-CoA reductase mRNA by inhibiting sterol regulatory element-binding protein (SREBP) transcription factor.
  • Hormones: Insulin and thyroid hormones increase enzyme activity, whereas glucagon or glucocorticoids decrease it.
  • Posttranslational modifications: Phosphorylation–dephosphorylation reactions affect enzyme activity. AMP-activated protein kinase (AMPK) phosphorylates and inactivates the enzyme.
  • Diurnal variation

questions.text: A 13-year-old boy presented with right hip pain. On examination, his BMI is 29 and there is a shortening of the limb with limitation of abduction, flexion, and internal rotation. Which among the following lines is drawn on the X-ray for the diagnosis of this condition?
questions.solution:
The condition described is slipped capital femoral epiphysis (SCFE) and the line used to diagnose it is Klein’s line - marked in green.

Klein's line is a line drawn on the A-P view or frog lateral view of the hip X-ray along the superior border of the neck of the femur. Failure of Klein’s line to intersect with the epiphysis results in a positive Trethowan sign- seen in SCFE. Klein’s line is less sensitive for diagnosis in the pre-slip stage.

A modification of this measurement is that if the maximal width of the epiphysis lateral to Klein's line is 2 mm or more than that in the contralateral hip, it is considered as a slip.

 

Other X-ray features seen in SCFE include :

  • Wide or irregular physis with loss of the anterior head-neck concavity
  • Sharp metaphyseal border of the head
  • Loss of total epiphyseal height
  • Steel sign (Metaphyseal blanch sign) - The posteriorly displaced femoral epiphysis overlaps over the metaphysis causing a crescent-shaped area of increased density on the AP radiograph.
  • Capener’s sign –the metaphysis displaces laterally, worsening the slip and causes a reduction in the double-density crescent created by the overlap of the posterior acetabulum and proximal metaphysis on the AP radiograph.
  • Southwick angle – The angle between the line drawn perpendicular to the physis and a line parallel to the femoral shaft. As slip worsens, the Southwick angle will increase. It is measured on the frog lateral X-ray view.

Patients with SCFE typically present in the rapid growth phase of adolescence with pain in the thigh, groin, or knee. On examination, the affected limb is shortened and externally rotated. There is a limitation in abduction, flexion, and internal rotation on the affected side. Flexion of the hip might lead to obligate external rotation and abduction - positive Drehmann’s sign. Patients may have an antalgic or Trendelenburg gait.

Other options:

The other three lines are used in the diagnosis of developmental dysplasia of the hip (DDH).

Hilgenreiner's line (Red line in the image) - A horizontal line through the tri-radiate cartilages.

Perkin's line (Blue line in the image) - A vertical line drawn at the outer border of the acetabulum. It is perpendicular to Hilgenreiner's line.

In DDH, the femoral head lies in the upper and outer quadrant formed by these two lines.

Shenton's line (Yellow line in the image) - A smooth curve formed by the inferior border of the neck of the femur with the superior margin of the obturator foramen. It is broken in DDH.

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman presented with 12 weeks of amenorrhea. The ultrasonography of the abdomen and pelvis revealed twin gestation, as shown in the image below. This type of twin gestation results if the division of the inner cell mass occurs:
questions.solution:
The image shows the lambda sign or twin peak sign seen in dichorionic diamniotic pregnancy. If the division of the inner cell mass occurs within 3 days of fertilization, it results in this type of twin gestation. 

Placental chorionicity is best diagnosed by ultrasound at 10–13 weeks of gestation. A thick septum between the two gestational sacs is present in dichorionic twins.

questions.text: A 36-year-old nulliparous woman presents with menorrhagia for 3 months. The first day of her last menstrual period (LMP) was 3 weeks ago. She undergoes a Pap smear which shows atypical glandular cells of unknown significance. How would you proceed with further management?

choices.text: Schedule an endometrial and cervical sampling

questions.solution:
The pap smear shows atypical glandular cells in a woman aged ≥35 years should proceed with an endometrial and cervical sampling.

Atypical glandular cells on a Pap smear usually signify underlying cervical or endometrial neoplasia. The glandular abnormality is evaluated by doing a colposcopy and endocervical curettage. Endometrial biopsy is also needed in the following cases to be certain that the endometrial cells originated in the endometrium:

  • Female patients ≥ 35 years.
  • Female patients < 35 years, and a risk factor for endometrial diseases like abnormal uterine bleeding(AUB) or anovulation.

Other options:

Options A & D: Since the atypical glandular cells are seen on a pap smear, we need to sample the endometrium and cervix to see from where the cells have originated. Colposcopy will help in locating abnormal areas and accurately obtaining a directed biopsy from the suspicious areas on the cervix. Hence, only an endometrial biopsy or only colposcopy(Option D) is not sufficient.

Option B: Loop electrosurgical excision procedure is an acceptable option for patients who have moderately severe to severe dysplasias. As the pap smear shows atypical glandular cells, colposcopy with endocervical curettage and endometrial sampling is required before an excisional procedure is considered.
