questions.text: Which of the following statements about hyperemesis gravidarum is false?

choices.text: More common in the first pregnancy
More common in women with high BMI

questions.solution:
Hyperemesis gravidarum is more common in women with low BMI. The term refers to unrelenting nausea and vomiting that is severe enough to cause weight loss, dehydration, ketosis, alkalosis or hypokalaemia.

It is associated with the following factors:

  • First pregnancy
  • Young age
  • Low body mass
  • History of migraine/motion sickness
  • Positive family history
  • Hydatidiform mole and multi-foetal gestation

questions.text: Which of the following are now being used in clinical trials as targets for chemotherapeutic agents, since they play a key role in carcinogenesis and tumour metastasis ?
questions.solution:
miRNAs are key players in carcinogenesis and tumor metastasis, hence now being used as targets for chemotherapeutic agents.

Micro RNAs (miRNAs) are short single-stranded RNA molecules that can regulate transcription and/or translation of protein-coding genes.They are now known to play multiple roles in every aspect of tumor formation and progression.Some miRNAs are tumor suppressors and can act by degrading RNA coding for oncogenic proteins, thus decreasing their expression.These miRNAs are found to be downregulated in a number of different types of cancer.

On the other hand, some miRNAs are oncogenic in nature.For, example, miR-21, one of the most widely studied oncogenic miRNAs, has been found to be upregulated to varying extents in almost all types of cancer. Other miRNAs play key roles in activating or inhibiting metastasis.

tRNA

tRNA molecules vary in length from 74 to 95 nucleotides, like many other RNAs, are also generated by nuclear processing of a precursor molecule. The tRNA molecules serve as adapters for the translation of the information in the sequence of nucleotides of the mRNA into specific amino acids.

There are at least 20 species of tRNA molecules in every cell, atleast one (and often several) corresponding to each of the 20 amino acids required for protein synthesis. The primary structure—that is, the nucleotide sequence—of all tRNA molecules allows extensive folding and intra strand complementarity to generate a secondary structure that appears in two dimensions like a cloverleaf.

rRNA

A ribosome is a cytoplasmic nucleoprotein structure that acts as the machinery for the synthesis of proteins from the mRNA templates.On the ribosomes, the mRNA and tRNA molecules interact to translate the information transcribed from the gene during mRNA synthesis into a specific protein.

During periods of active protein synthesis, many ribosomes can be associated with any mRNA molecule to form an assembly called the polysome.Recent studies indicate that the large rRNA component performs the peptidyl transferase activity and thus is a ribozyme.

mRNA

A messenger RNA (mRNA) is a single stranded RNA molecule that corresponds to the genetic sequence of a gene that is responsible for the synthesis of a protein molecule. 

Synthesized nucleotside-modified messenger RNA sequence can cause a cell to make a protein, which in turn could directly treat a disease or could function as a vaccine.

questions.text: On neurologic examination, a patient is not able to recognize the key kept in his hand with his eyes closed. But, immediately recognizes the object once he sees it. Which lobe of the brain is likely affected in this case?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of astereognosis. It is seen in lesions involving the superior parietal lobe which is marked as '3' in the given image.

Stereognosis is the ability to identify an object by a perception of the form and nature of an object without looking at it. This ability depends on intact touch, pressure, and proprioceptive impulses. The loss of integration of sensory impulses is called astereognosis. Astereognosis is seen in lesions of the superior parietal lobule and dorsal column pathways.

There are two parietal lobes, the dominant side, and the non-dominant side:

  • The functions of the dominant side of the parietal lobe are calculation, language, planned movement, appreciation of size, shape, weight, and texture. A lesion here causes dyscalculia, dysphasia, dyslexia, apraxia, agnosia, and homonymous hemianopia.
  • The function of the non-dominant side is spatial orientation and constructional skills. Its lesion causes spatial disorientation, constructional apraxia, neglect of the non-dominant side, dressing apraxia, and homonymous hemianopia.

The lesions in the posterior parietal lobe lead to loss of hand-eye coordination. Because neurons in this posterior parietal cortex contribute to the descending pathways involved in motor control.

questions.text:
An 8-year-old boy came with complaints of fever, increasing yellowish discoloration of eyes, and increasing abdominal distension for 3 days. On examination, he has bilateral Kayser–Fleischer rings. There are no features suggestive of hepatic encephalopathy. Laboratory investigations are given below. What is the definitive management of his condition?

S. bilirubin - 12 mg/dL
International Normalised Ratio - 6.6
questions.solution:
The above clinical vignette is suggestive of acute Wilsonian crisis leading to acute liver failure. The patient meets the Kings criteria for acute failure (raised INR >6.5) and therefore the definitive treatment in this case is an emergency liver transplant (Option D).

Laboratory investigations of INR- 6.6 (> 6.5) which is one of the definitive criteria of King’s criteria 

King's College criteria for liver transplantation in acute hepatic failure (AHF)

Paracetamol-associated AHF

pH < 7.3 or 

All three of the following -


INR > 6.5

serum creatinine >3.4 mg/dl

Grade III–IV encephalopathy

INR >6.5 or 

Three of the following variables:

Age <10 or >40 years
Cause is nonA, nonB hepatitis or idiosyncratic drug reaction
Duration of jaundice before encephalopathy >7 days
INR > 3.5
Serum bilirubin >17.5 mg/dl

Wilson disease (hepatolenticular degeneration) is an autosomal recessive disorder due to abnormal ATP7B gene in chromosome 13 which is characterised by liver disease, degenerative changes in the brain, and Kayser-Fleischer (K-F) rings in the cornea.

Copper excretion through ceruloplasmin is affected leading to decreased copper excretion through kidneys and increased accumulation in hepatocytes followed by brain and kidneys. 

Medical management of Wilson’s disease include penicillamine, trientine or zinc, but they are not the definitive treatment for Wilson’s disease presenting as acute liver failure. They are known to reduce the symptoms to an extent but are not therapeutic of acute Wilsonian crisis with acute liver failure (Option B).

Once the diagnosis of Wilson disease is made, lifelong treatment is required. Treatment includes limiting copper uptake and promoting copper excretion through dietary and pharmacologic measures.

Initial treatment in symptomatic patients is administration of copper-chelating agents such as  D-penicillamine or triethylene tetramine dihydrochloride (trientine) which lead to rapid excretion of excess deposited copper. This results in marked improvement of hepatic and neurologic function and the disappearance of K-F rings.

Zinc may have a role as a first-line therapy in patients with neurologic disease, but exclusive monotherapy with zinc in symptomatic liver disease is not recommended. It acts by inhibiting gastrointestinal absorption of copper.(Option C)

Corticosteroids are used to treat autoimmune hepatitis and have no role in the management of Wilson’s disease.(Option A)

questions.text: A 60-year-old man who underwent a coronary artery bypass 6 days ago developed fever and productive cough with purulent, blood-tinged sputum. His chest X-ray and sputum culture on Cetrimide agar are shown in the image below. Which of the following is the most probable causative organism?
questions.solution:
This patient has developed Late-onset hospital-acquired pneumonia (> 5 days). The chest-Xray shows wedge-shaped opacity involving the right middle lobe, suggestive of bacterial pneumonia. Culture shows the growth of Pseudomonas aeruginosa in Cetrimide agar with colonies showing  greenish-yellow fluorescein pigment.

Pseudomonas aeruginosa is a gram-negative, catalase-positive, oxidase-positive, non-lactose fermenting bacteria that shows swarming motility. They produce a characteristic blue-green pigment called pyocyanin and greenish-yellow pigment called fluorescein/pyoverdin. Other pigments produced by these organisms include Pyorubin (Red), Pyomelanin (Brown).

Diseases caused by Pseudomonas aeruginosa include-

  • Malignant otitis externa in diabetics
  • Pneumonia and sepsis in cystic fibrosis
  • Wound infection and sepsis in burns
  • Hot tub folliculitis/Pseudomonas aeruginosa folliculitis/ Jacuzzi syndrome is a common type of folliculitis, which causes inflammation of hair follicles
  • Shanghai fever is a febrile illness that manifests as severe enteric disease, sepsis with invasive disease.
  • Ecthyma gangrenosum

Hospital-acquired pneumonia (HAP) or nosocomial pneumonia is a lower respiratory infection that presents clinically 2 or more days after hospitalization and was not there at the time of admission.

  • Early-onset HAP (occurring within 4-5 days) is most commonly caused by S. aureus, P. aeruginosa, Enterobacter species, K pneumoniae, Legionella pneumophila
  • Late-onset HAP (> 5 days) is usually caused by Gram-negative bacteria (ex: Escherichia coli, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, Klebsiella spp, and Acinetobacter baumannii), S. aureus, and anaerobes.

Other options:

  • Klebsiella species has no particular selective medium and is usually differentiated through biochemical reactions
  • Staphylococcus aureus is selectively cultured in Mannitol salt agar, Ludlam's medium and Salt milk agar. Mannitol salt agar showing golden-yellow S. aureus colonies is given below.

Legionella pneumophila causes community-acquired pneumonia and early-onset hospital-acquired pneumonia and grows selectively on BCYE (Buffered charcoal yeast extract agar) medium. It is as shown below.

questions.text: A 19-year-old male patient comes to the clinic for follow-up 3 weeks after a traumatic fracture in his right upper limb. On examination, he was found to have a hard palpable mass near the fracture site. X-ray of the area shows the findings below. A histological section shows central fibrous tissue and mature bone at the periphery. Which of the following is true about this patient's diagnosis?

choices.text: It is a type of connective tissue metaplasia
It is a type of connective tissue hyperplasia
It is a type of connective tissue hypertrophy
It is a type of malignant transformation

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario describes a case of traumatic heterotopic ossification. Myositis ossificans is a type of heterotopic ossification which occurs as a result of pathological connective tissue metaplasia.

Metaplasia is a reversible change in which one differentiated cell type (epithelial or mesenchymal) is replaced by another cell type. It usually represents an adaptive response in which one cell type is replaced by another more capable of handling the stressor. Although, in the case of myositis ossificans, it is not clearly seen as an adaptive response.

Common examples of metaplasia include- Barrett's esophagus (squamous epithelium replaced by intestinal-like columnar cells due to chronic gastric reflux), columnar to squamous epithelium in the respiratory tract of chronic smokers.

Connective tissue metaplasia is the formation of cartilage, bone, or adipose tissue (mesenchymal tissues) in tissues that normally do not contain these elements. Myositis ossificans is characterized by heterotopic bone formation within muscle tissue following traumatic injury to the area with hemorrhage into it. Heterotopia refers to the presence of normal cells in abnormal places.

There are three types of heterotopic ossification known

  • Myositis ossificans progressiva: A rare genetic condition with the autosomal dominant transmission with variable penetrance. This leads to recurrent painful soft-tissue swellings. Patients usually die from restrictive lung disease
  • Traumatic myositis ossificans: This case develops after a single blow to the area, a muscle tear, or repeated minor trauma. The painful area gradually develops masses with a cartilaginous consistency and within 4-7 weeks, a solid mass of bone can be felt
  • Neurogenic heterotopic ossification: Heterotopic bone formation around joints, limiting mobility. Seen in patients with traumatic brain or spinal cord injury.

Other options-

Option (B): Hyperplasia is increased cell number in response to hormones and growth factors that occur in tissues whose cells are able to divide and have abundant stem cell reserve. Common examples- female breast during puberty and pregnancy, benign prostatic hyperplasia, etc.

Option (C): Hypertrophy is an increase in cell size and organ size which occurs in response to increased workload in tissues incapable of cell division. Common examples- uterus during pregnancy, cardiac muscle in response to chronic hypertension (due to overload), skeletal muscles in bodybuilders, etc.

Related Pearl: Three point bony relationship in elbow:

The three bony points in the elbow are :

  • Tip of the medial epicondyle
  • Tip of the lateral epicondyle
  • Olecranon

When the elbow is in 90 degrees of flexion, these points form an isosceles triangle. When the elbow is extended, they lie transversely in a straight line.

The three-point bony relationship is maintained in the case of supracondylar fracture of the humerus as the fracture occurs above the level of these bony landmarks.

Conditions where it is distorted:

  • Fracture medial condyle and epicondyle
  • Fracture lateral condyle and epicondyle
  • Intercondylar fracture of humerus
  • Fracture olecranon
  • Elbow dislocation

questions.text: A 24-year-old patient undergoes a session of  Electroconvulsive Therapy. It is noticed that the seizures are prolonged i.e greater than 180 secs and there is also increased postictal delirium. Cessation of which of the following drugs prior to ECT would have prevented this?
questions.solution:
Cessation of lithium would have prevented prolonged seizures and increased postictal delirium. Lithium should be withheld before a session of ECT. 

Normally, for ECTs to be considered effective, induced seizures should last for at least 25 seconds. Prolonged seizures (lasting longer than 180 seconds) or status epilepticus can occur in certain situations. Lithium combined with ECT has been shown to cause prolonged seizures and increased postictal delirium. Doses are withheld for 24 hours prior to treatment, allowing for washout.

Prolonged seizures can be terminated with additional doses of barbiturate anesthetics or IV benzodiazepines. Intubation should also be considered in patients who are apneic for extended periods. Seizures lasting more than 30 minutes can cause permanent neuronal damage.

Other medications to be withdrawn before ECT:

  • Benzodiazepines 
  • Clozapine 
  • Buproprion 
  • Theophylline 
  • Reserpine  

Note: Tardive seizure is a rare complication of ECT. These are seizures that occur after the completion of treatment once the patient has regained consciousness. β-lactam antibiotics and ciprofloxacin have been associated with tardive seizures. 

Other options:

Options A and D:Clozapine and bupropion are associated with the development of late-onset seizures.

Option B: Benzodiazepines have anticonvulsant activity.

questions.text:
A middle-aged male patient who has been diagnosed with short bowel syndrome is to be given parenteral nutrition. All of the following are true about parenteral nutrition except:

PICC - peripherally inserted central venous catheter

choices.text: Central venous access can be achieved through subclavian vein
PICC line can produce irreversible thrombophlebitis
Peripheral feeding can be used for more than 2 weeks
Catheter-related sepsis is a common complication

questions.solution:
All of the above are true about parenteral nutrition except that peripheral feeding can be used for more than 2 weeks. 

Parenteral nutrition is defined as the continuous infusion of all the required nutrition through the intravenous route to completely avoid the use of the gastrointestinal tract. It is usually indicated when protein and energy demands cannot be met by enteral nutrition administration. They include causes such as short bowel syndrome, enterocutaneous fistula, etc.

It can be provided by obtaining either peripheral venous access or central venous access. Peripheral venous access is achieved either by inserting a catheter into a peripheral vein and then maneuvering it into the central vein (peripherally inserted central venous catheter-PICC) or by a short wrist vein cannula. PICC lines have a mean survival duration of 7 days and can cause irreversible thrombophlebitis. 

Central venous access is achieved by the subclavian, internal jugular, or external jugular vein. The infraclavicular subclavian approach is preferred as it is easier to provide nursing care. For long-term parenteral nutrition, Hickman lines are more appropriate.

The image below shows (A) a typical PICC line (B) the insertion of a PICC line (C) a patient with a PICC line inserted through the upper arm.

Parenteral nutrition can cause metabolic complications such as fluid overload, hyperglycemia (due to insulin resistance in critically ill patients), vitamin deficiencies, and impaired liver function. Catheter-related sepsis is common and can be diagnosed by culturing organisms from the blood or catheter tip. Refeeding syndrome is caused by severe fluid and electrolyte shifts in patients undergoing refeeding and results in hypophosphatemia, hypocalcemia, and hypomagnesemia.

Related Pearl: Complications of total parenteral nutrition

A. Related to nutrient deficiency

  • Hypocalcaemia/hypophosphatemia/hypomagnesaemia/hypoglycemia (refeeding syndrome)
  • Chronic deficiency syndromes (essential fatty acids, zinc, mineral and trace elements)

B. Related to overfeeding

  • Excess glucose: Hyperglycemia, hyperosmolar dehydration, hepatic steatosis, hypercapnia, increased sympathetic activity, fluid retention, electrolyte abnormalities
  • Excess fat: Hypercholesterolemia and formation of lipoprotein X, hypertriglyceridemia, hypersensitivity reactions
  • Excess amino acids: Hyperchloremic metabolic acidosis, hypercalcemia, aminoacidemia, uremia

C. Related to sepsis

  • Catheter-related sepsis
  • Possible increased predisposition to systemic sepsis

D. Related to IV line

  • On insertion: Pneumothorax, damage to adjacent artery, air embolism, thoracic duct damage, cardiac perforation or tamponade, pleural effusion, hydro mediastinum
  • Long-term use: Occlusion, venous thrombosis

E. Related to motility

  • Cholestasis
  • Gallstones

questions.text: The given image represents an examination finding of a 25-year-old woman presenting with recurrent seizures and low intelligence. What is the most likely diagnosis and chromosome affected?
questions.solution:
This clinical vignette and the given image of subungual fibroma (Koenen tumor) are suggestive of tuberous sclerosis, also called epiloia - the triad of epilepsy, low intelligence, and adenoma sebaceum.

Tuberous sclerosis is a neurocutaneous syndrome, which occurs due to mutations in the genes hamartin and tuberin on chromosomes 9 and 16, respectively. It is inherited in an autosomal dominant fashion and presents with multiple cutaneous findings which are divided into major and minor features.

Major features :

  • Ash leaf macules -lance ovate shaped, hypopigmented lesions which are the earliest to manifest( at birth or early infancy)
  • Adenoma sebaceum - facial angiofibromas, which are the characteristics lesions of tuberous sclerosis. Usually appear between 3 to 10 years and become extensive at puberty
  • Shagreen patches - collagenomas which are leathery in texture and found in the lumbosacral region
  • Koenen tumors - periungual fibromas, with appear at or after puberty

Minor features :

  • Hypopigmented confetti macules
  • Dental enamel pits
  • Gingival fibromas

The central nervous system lesions include cortical tubers, subependymal nodules and subependymal giant cell astrocytomas.The other systemic manifestations are renal angiomyolipoma, cardiac rhabdomyoma and pulmonary lymphangioleiomyomatosis.

Other options:

Option A: Friedreich ataxia is the most common inherited ataxia. It is an autosomal recessive cause of spinocerebellar degeneration, caused by the expansion of GAA trinucleotides on chromosome 9. Most patients have pes cavus.

Option B: Neurofibromatosis type 2 (NF2) is an autosomal dominant neurocutaneous disorder due to a mutation in the Merlin gene on chromosome 22, which is a tumor suppressor gene. It presents as bilateral eighth nerve schwannomas, ependymomas, and meningiomas. It is less common than neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF1). 

Option D: Von Hippel Lindau is an autosomal dominant disease affecting the VHL gene on chromosome 3. It presents with hemangioblastomas of the CNS and cysts of the pancreas, kidneys, and liver.

Related Pearl: Cutaneous lesions of Tuberous sclerosis

Tuberous sclerosis (TS) is also known as tuberous sclerosis complex or Bourneville disease. It is a neurocutaneous disorder (phakomatosis) characterized by the development of multiple benign tumors of the embryonic ectoderm (e.g. skin, eyes, and nervous system). It is an autosomal dominant condition.  The mutations are involved in the TSC1 gene that encodes hamartin on chromosome 9 and the TSC2 gene that encodes a protein tuberin on chromosome 16.

Tuberous sclerosis presents in childhood with a triad (Vogt triad). The triad comprises of:

  • Seizures
  • Mental retardation
  • Adenoma sebaceum

Skin lesions in tuberous sclerosis:

Shagreen patch consists of a roughened, raised lesion with an orange-peel consistency, located primarily in the lumbosacral region. Shagreen is shark skin used as a decorative material present in the right image given below.

The typical hypomelanotic ash leaf–type macules on the trunk and extremities are seen in 90% of the patients. It is visualized by the use of a wood ultraviolet lamp.

Facial angiofibromas (adenoma sebaceum) develop between 4 and 6 years of age; they appear as tiny red nodules over the nose and cheeks and are sometimes confused with acne. Later, they enlarge, coalesce, and assume a fleshy appearance.

Periungual fibroma are small fibromas or nodules of skin, which form around fingernails or toenails in some adolescent patients

Confetti skin lesions are seen less commonly as a minor feature of tuberous sclerosis.

questions.text: A patient is brought to the trauma unit following a severe road traffic accident. Which of the following should essentially be avoided during initial assessment for cervical spine injury?

choices.text: Removing c-collar and palpating the c-spine
Keeping the backboard for more than an hour
Passively moving head to assess pain & instability
Not requesting c-spine films if there is no neck pain

questions.solution:
During initial assessment for cervical spinal injury, passive movement of the neck should never be done to assess pain and stability because it will worsen if there is any pre-existing spinal injury. We should always ask the patient whether he/she can move his/her neck without any pain.

If can move actively without any pain, cervical collar need not be placed again. But if cannot actively move or if there is any pain, cervical collar should be placed to ensure immobilization.

Other options :

Option A : Removal of the cervical collar and palpating the cervical spine can be done even in suspected cervical spinal injury. If there is any pain or tenderness, cervical collar should be replaced and immediate imaging should be done.

Option B : Keeping the spinal longboard on the back is allowed upto 2 hours, but not more than that as it increases the risk of pressure sore formation

Option D : Clinical tools like Canadian c-spine rule and NEXUS can be used to determine whether radiological imaging is needed or not. Cervical radiography is mandatory under the following circumstances

  • Inability to move neck
  • Pain or tenderness over the cervical spine
  • Presence of paraplegia or quadriplegia

If these films are normal, the c-collar may be removed to obtain flexion and extension views. A qualified clinician may obtain lateral cervical spine films with the patient voluntarily flexing and extending his or her neck. If the films show no subluxation, the patient’s c-spine can be cleared and the c-collar removed. However, if any of these films are suspicious or unclear, replace the collar and consult with a spine specialist.

Related Pearl: ATLS Primary Survey

The steps in the ATLS (Advanced Trauma Life Support) include:

  • Primary survey with simultaneous resuscitation – identify and treat what is killing the patient
  • Secondary survey – proceed to identify all other injuries
  • Definitive care – develop a definitive management plan

Primary Survey: ABCDEs of trauma care:

  • Airway assessment and protection (maintain cervical spine stabilization when appropriate) - If airway obstruction is identified, jaw thrust in cervical injury patients or chin lift is performed.
  • Breathing and ventilation assessment - maintain adequate oxygenation, consider non-invasive or invasive ventilation when indicated
  • Circulation assessment (control hemorrhage, maintain circulating volume and adequate end-organ perfusion) - Two wide-bore (14G to 16G) cannulae are inserted for intravenous fluid resuscitation.
  • Disability assessment - perform a basic neurologic evaluation (AVPU/GCS-P), blood glucose levels
  • Exposure with environmental control - undress the patient and examine thoroughly for possible injuries, prevent hypothermia

Adjuncts to the primary survey:

  • Blood collection - CBC, urea and electrolytes, clotting screen, glucose, toxicology, cross-match
  • ECG, pulse oximetry, ventilatory rate, capnography, ABG analysis
  • Urinary and gastric catheters
  • Radiographs of the chest and pelvis are done as a part of the primary survey preferably with a portable x-ray unit. When required, all these x-rays must also be done on pregnant women.
  • (e)FAST

Other more specialized forms of imaging, such as ultrasound, computerized tomography, angiography, and diagnostic peritoneal lavage, should be considered after the secondary survey and only when the patient is stable after initial resuscitation.

questions.text: For years, a gold standard test (green curves) is being used for the diagnosis of the disease. Recently, a new test (purple curves) has been discovered and the researcher claims it to be a better test. Compared to the gold standard test, the new test has:
questions.solution:
The new test (purple curves) has higher sensitivity and higher specificity.

In the new test (purple curves), both false positives (FP) and false negatives (FN) have reduced.  

Sensitivity = TP/(TP + FN)

  • Sensitivity is inversely related to FN.
  • Therefore, reducing FN would increase the sensitivity.

Specificity = TN/(TN + FP)

  • Specificity is inversely related to FP.
  • Therefore, reducing FP would increase the specificity.

Related Pearl: Cut-off points in diagnostic tests

  • Highly sensitive test, when negative, rules out a disease. (Screening test)
  • Highly specific test, when positive, rules in a disease. (Confirmatory test)

Sensitivity (True-positive rate): High sensitivity indicates low false-negative rate.

Specificity (True-negative rate): High specificity indicates low false-positive rate.

questions.text: A woman comes to you for a medical fitness certificate. You notice a nevus on her skin and think it is a melanoma. The cells responsible for this cancer are derived from which of following?
questions.solution:
Melanocytes are derived from neural crest cells (NCCs). 

During neurulation, when the neural folds elevate and fuse, the cells at the lateral border (the neural crest) of the neuroectoderm dissociate from their neighbouring cells (see image). These neural crest cells then migrate to the underlying mesoderm.

NCCs contribute to many organs and tissues and are sometimes referred to as the fourth germ layer:

  • In the trunk region, they form melanocytes, sensory ganglia, sympathetic and enteric neurons, Schwann cells, and adrenal medulla cells.
  • In the cranial region, they contribute to the craniofacial skeleton, neurons for cranial ganglia, satellite glial cells, and melanocytes.

Related Pearl: Neural crest derivatives

Neural

Mesenchymal

All ganglions

Connective tissue and bones of the face and skull 

All enteric plexus

Dermis of the head and face

Schwann cells and Satellite glial cells

Odontoblasts (Dentine)

Adrenal Medulla

Arachnoid and Piamater 

Parafolliular C cells of Thyroid

Conotruncal septum in the heart

Melanoblast/Melanocytes (except Retinal Pigment Epithelium)

questions.text: During ward rounds, a third year resident is asked about markers of acute kidney injury. Which of the following would be an incorrect answer?
questions.solution:
Micro RNA 122 is not a marker of acute kidney injury. It is an example of tissue specific miRNA, highly expressed in liver.

Biomarkers of AKI
 Biomarker types    Biomarkers
Functional markers Serum Creatinine, plasma serum cystatin C
Up regulated proteins NGAL, KIM -1, LFAB ,and IL-18
Low molecular weight proteins Urine cystatin C
Enzymes NAG, GGT

Cystatin C is freely filtered by the glomerulus, reabsorbed and catabolised, but not secreted by tubules. Serum cys-c is sensitive serum marker of GFR. It is a stronger predictor than serum creatinine for risk of death and cardiovascular events in older patients.

Neutrophil Gelatinase-Associated Lipocalin (NGAL) is an emerging biomarker in urine and plasma for early prediction of AKI. It is used to know prognosis of AKI in several common clinical conditions.    

Kidney Injury Molecule-1 (KIM-1) is a transmembrane protein that is specifically upregulated in dedifferentiated proximal tubule cells after nephrotoxic AKI. An extracellular domain of KIM-1 is detectable in the urine soon after AKI.

questions.text: An elderly woman was brought with worsening memory for the past 4 years. Recently, she has not been able to carry out her daily chores and lost her way at the supermarket. There is no evidence of personality changes, rigidity, or gait disturbances. Which of the following are the main neurotransmitters involved in this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette is suggestive of Alzheimer's disease, and the neurotransmitters that are most often implicated in its pathogenesis are acetylcholine and norepinephrine.

Main neurotransmitters involved:

  • Degeneration of the cholinergic neurons in the nucleus basalis of Meynert - Reduced acetylcholine
  • Degeneration of the locus ceruleus - Reduced norepinephrine
  • Degeneration of dorsal raphe -Reduced serotonin

Two other neurotransmitters implicated in the pathophysiology of Alzheimer's disease are somatostatin and corticotropin, which show decreased levels.

Alzheimer's disease is the most common cause of dementia in the elderly. It begins with memory impairment, which later progresses to language and visuospatial deficits. Later, the patient has difficulty in keeping track of finances, following instructions, driving, shopping, and housekeeping. In severe impairment, the patient easily gets lost and confused.

Language deficits appear as impairment in naming, comprehension, and finally fluency. Visuospatial defects include difficulty dressing, eating, copying geometric figures, and reading the clock. Risk factors for the development of Alzheimer's disease include:

  • Age >70 years.
  • Positive family history.
  • Female gender.
  • Apo ε4 allele.
  • Diabetes (increase the risk threefold).
  • Hypertension.
  • Elevated homocysteine and cholesterol levels.
  • Diminished intake of folic acid, fruits, vegetables, and red wine.
  • Low levels of exercise.
  • Down syndrome.
  • Mutation in presenilin 1 and presenilin 2 genes.

Protective factors are nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs and Apo ε2. 

Treatment: Cholinesterase inhibitors like donepezil, galantamine, rivastigmine, and NMDA receptor antagonist like memantine.

Related Pearl: Synucleinopathies and tauopathies

Synucleinopathies:
  • Parkinson’s disease
  • Dementia with Lewy bodies
  • Multiple system atrophy
  • REM behavioral disorder
  • Pure autonomic failure 
Tauopathies:
  • Alzheimer’s disease
  • Down syndrome
  • Progressive supranuclear palsy
  • Corticobasal degeneration
  • Pick’s disease/frontotemporal dementia
  • Chronic traumatic encephalopathy/punch drunk syndrome/dementia pugilistica
  • Postencephalitic parkinsonism
  • Pantothenate kinase-associated degeneration
  • Niemann Pick disease type C
  • Subacute sclerosing panencephalitis

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman presented with painful swelling of the right calf muscle. On examination, the test shown below is positive. She has a past history of deep vein thrombosis. What is the minimum Wells score for pulmonary embolism in this patient based on the given information?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette describes a case of deep venous thrombosis (DVT). The most common clinical presentation of DVT is pain and tenderness in the calf. The given image shows the method of eliciting Moses sign, which is calf pain/tenderness on applying direct pressure over calf muscles seen in deep venous thrombosis (DVT). The minimum Well's score in this patient from the information given is 4.5.

Calculation of minimum Modified Wells score in this case:

Note: To calculate the final score, All the other components are needed. The question asks about the minimum score based on the information given only. 

Signs/symptoms Score
Clinical signs of DVT 3
Diagnosis other than pulmonary embolism is less likely 3
Heart rate >100 bpm 1.5
Immobilization for >3 days or surgery in the last 4 weeks 1.5
Past history of DVT/pulmonary embolism 1.5
Hemoptysis 1
Malignancy 1

Modified Wells criteria:

  • PE likely >4
  • PE unlikely <or =4

DVT is mostly unilateral, with an unreliable clinical examination. Pulmonary embolism is the most common complication of DVT and may present directly as pulmonary thromboembolism.

Deep vein thrombosis:

Causes:

  • Postoperative thrombosis: (Most common cause)
    • Following childbirth
    • Trauma- to leg, ankle, thigh, pelvis
    • Immobility – Bed-ridden patients, individuals on long-duration air or bus travel (traveller’s thrombosis).
    • Debilitating illness, obesity, immobility, bed rest, pregnancy, puerperium, oral contraceptives, estrogens.

Sites:

  1. Pelvic veins—common
  2. Leg veins—common in femoral and popliteal veins (Common on the left side).

Features of DVT:

  • Fever-commonest
  • Tense, tender, warm, pale/bluish, shiny swelling calf
  • Positive Homans and Moses sign
  • Inverted beer bottle sign/ champagne bottle sign
  • Commonly it is asymptomatic
  • Features of pulmonary embolism

Note:

Moses sign - Squeezing of the relaxed calf muscles from side-to-side is also painful as the thrombosed deep veins in the calf are always tender and this test is known as Moses sign.

Homans sign - Passive forceful dorsiflexion of the foot with the knee extended will elicit tenderness in the calf. Gentle pressure directly on the calf muscles in the relaxed position will also elicit pain. Care must be taken to be gentle in manipulation lest it may dislodge a clot and cause a pulmonary embolism. The image is attached below. 

 

Related Pearl: Two-level deep vein thrombosis (DVT) Wells score

Clinical features Points
Active cancer (treatment ongoing within 6 months or palliative) 1
paralysis, paresis, or recent plaster immobilization of the lower extremities  1
Recently bed ridden for 3 days or more or major surgery within 12 weeks requiring general or regional anaesthesia  1
Localised tenderness along the distribution of deep venous system 1
Entire leg swollen 1
calf swelling atleast 3 cm larger than asymptomatic side  1
Pitting edema confined to the symptomatic leg 1
Collateral superficial veins (Non varicose) 1
Previously documented DVT 1
An alternative diagnosis is atleast as likely as DVT -2
Clinical probability simplified score Points
DVT Likely 2 points or more
DVT Unlikely  1 points or less 

Related Pearl: Clinical prediction for pulmonary embolism: Well’s, Modified Well’s and Pulmonary Embolism Rule out Criteria (PERC)

Signs/symptoms Score
Clinical signs of DVT 3
Diagnosis other than pulmonary embolism is less likely 3
Heart rate >100 bpm 1.5
Immobilization for >3 days or surgery in the last 4 weeks 1.5
Past history of DVT/pulmonary embolism 1.5
Hemoptysis 1
Malignancy 1

Three-level score probability:

Well's criteria Score
Low <2
Moderate 2-6
High >6

Two-level score probability:

Modified Well's criteria Score
Pulmonary embolism unlikely ≤4
Pulmonary embolism likely >4 

 

Pulmonary embolism rule out criteria (PERC):

This is a quick OPD/casualty tool to rule out pulmonary embolism in patients with low clinical probability. It comprises eight clinical variables. If the patient meets all eight criteria, there is no need for further investigations. The variables include: 

  1. Age <50 years
  2. Heart rate <100 bpm
  3. SpO2 ≥95%
  4. No unilateral leg swelling
  5. No hemoptysis
  6. No recent trauma or surgery
  7. No history of venous thromboembolism
  8. No use of hormonal therapy.

Related Pearl: Prophylaxis for DVT

Mechanical prophylaxis
Early ambulation

Acts by activating the calf pump mechanism
Pneumatic compression stocking

Prevents stasis by periodically compressing the calves
Pharmacological prophylaxis

Low molecular weight heparin (LMWH) - Enoxaparin

Fondaparinux

 Prevent thrombus formation by inhibiting factor Xa

Apixaban

Rivaroxaban 

  Oral factor Xa inhibitors

Unfractionated heparin (UFH)

Prevents action of factors VIII - XII and production of thrombin/fibrin.

Used in renal insufficiency

Warfarin

Inhibits hepatic production of factors II, VII, IX and X

questions.text: Which of the following vessels will not be affected due to an embolus originating in the posterior division of the internal iliac artery?
questions.solution:
Inferior gluteal artery is a branch of the anterior division of the internal iliac artery, and hence, would not be affected due to an embolus from the posterior division of internal iliac artery. 

The internal iliac artery is the major artery of the pelvis. At the superior border of the greater sciatic foramen in the pelvis, it divides into anterior and posterior trunks.

Branches of the posterior trunk of the internal iliac artery:

  • Iliolumbar artery
  • Lateral sacral arteries
  • Superior gluteal artery

Branches of the anterior trunk of the internal iliac artery:

  1. Obturator artery
  2. Superior vesical artery
  3. Inferior vesical artery 
  4. Inferior gluteal artery
  5. Middle rectal artery
  6. Vaginal artery (in females)
  7. Uterine artery (in females)
  8. Internal pudendal artery

questions.text: A  female patient presents with complaints of itchy rashes over her knuckles and sun exposed areas of neck and chest as shown below,  worsening over the last 2 months. She admits to difficulty in getting up from chair and using stairs. Which of the following is incorrect with respect to the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The finding shown in the image is Gottron's papules and shawl sign. The given scenario of a patient with proximal muscle weakness and rash is highly suggestive of dermatomyositis. Muscle biopsy done as part of investigation and is associated with perimysial and not endomysial infiltrates (option C)

Patients with dermatomyositis will show one or more of the following autoantibodies : antinuclear antibody (ANA), extractable nuclear antigen (ENA), double‐stranded DNA (dsDNA), lupus anticoagulant, complement levels, anticardiolipin antibodies and β2‐glycoprotein 1 antibodies and anti-P155 antibodies in case of juvenile dermatomyositis (option A), which may be associated with myositis related cancer in the future.

Myositis is the inflammation of the muscle hence the enzyme creatine kinase which presents within muscles will be released, causing elevated levels (option B)

Electromyography to assess muscle function and MRI to detect muscle edema can also be done along with pulmonary function test to look for interstitial lung disease, which is the major cause of mortality in patients with dermatomyositis.

It shows excellent response to corticosteroid therapy (option D) which is the first line along with disease modifying anti-rheumatoid agents (DMARDS). Topical steroids with topical tacrolimus proves beneficial for skin-limited disease.

Dermatomyositis (DM) is an autoimmune disorder predominantly affecting the skin and skeletal muscle. The following are various manifestations of dermatomyositis:

  • Proximal myopathy: Patients have trouble performing everyday activities like climbing stairs, getting up, and lifting their arms above their heads
  • Gottron's papules: Violaceous, erythematous papules overlying the dorsal interphalangeal or metacarpophalangeal, elbow, or knee joints, as shown in the image below.

Shawl sign/V-sign: Fixed macular erythema, across the shoulders and outer arms (Shawl distribution) as shown below

  • Periungual telangiectasias: Dilated capillaries of the nail folds
  • Mechanic's hand: Roughening and cracking of the skin of the tips and sides of the fingers, resulting in irregular, dirty-appearing lines that resemble those of a mechanic or manual laborer
  • Less common manifestations include: Facial swelling, malignancy, erythroderma, lichen planus.

Related Pearl: Inflammatory myopathy

  Dermatomyositis Polymyositis Inclusion Body Myositis
Age of onset Adulthood and childhood >18 years >50 years  
Familial Association No No Yes
Skin Manifestation Yes No No
Muscle involvement

Symmetric

Symmetric

Asymmetric
Histopathological Findings

Perimysial CD4+ cellular infiltrates

Perivascular infiltrates and perifascicular atrophy

Endomysial CD8+ cellular infiltrates 

Perivascular infiltrates  

Endomysial CD8+ cellular infiltrates

Perivascular infiltrates with amyloid inclusion bodies and rimmed vacuoles   
Association with connective tissue disease Scleroderma and mixed connective tissue only Yes Yes
Association with other autoimmune diseases Infrequent Frequent  Infrequent
Association with malignancy Yes (breast, ovarian, lung) and ILD  Yes (incidence much lesser than dermatomyositis)  No
Immunotherapy  Responsive  Responsive  Resistant

Related Pearl: Antibodies in Dermatomyositis

  • Anti-Mi2 antibodies (directed against a helicase implicated in nucleosome remodeling) show a strong association with prominent Gottron papules and heliotrope rash.
  • Anti-Jo1 antibodies (directed against the enzyme histidyl t-RNA synthetase) are associated with interstitial lung disease, nonerosive arthritis, and a skin rash described as “mechanic’s hands.”
  • Anti-P155/P140 antibodies (directed against several transcriptional regulators) are associated with paraneoplastic and juvenile cases of dermatomyositis.

questions.text: A forensic expert is assisting the police in investigating the death of a woman. On further examination, he notices that her eyeballs are soft and flaccid with complete absence of intraocular pressure. What is the minimum time required for this finding to be seen?
questions.solution:
The complete absence of intraocular pressure (IOP) is observed 2 hours after a person's death.

Flaccidity of the eyeballs is a postmortem change that occurs due to a fall in intraocular pressure. The eyes look sunken and become softer as the IOP reduces.

Changes in IOP are as follows:

  • During life- 14 to 25 mmHg
  • Soon after death- <12 mmHg
  • Within half an hour after death- <3 mmHg
  • End of 2 hours- Nil

Other postmortem changes occurring in the eye:

  • Cornea - dull, hazy, opaque, wrinkled.
  • Kevorkian sign - fragmentation of the blood column in the retinal vessels. It appears within minutes after death and lasts for about 1 hour. It can be visualized by using an ophthalmoscope as shown below.
  • Tache Noir: A film of cell debris and mucus forms two brown triangles on the sclera on either side of the cornea, with the base towards the margin of the cornea and the apex towards the medial or lateral canthus of the eye. It appears within 3-4 hours of death.
  • Increase in potassium concentration in vitreous - linear increase up to 100 hours following death. It helps determine the time since death.

questions.text:
A 30-year-old man working in a loud machinery unit came to the OPD with complaints of hearing loss for the past 3 months. He's also complaining of high-pitched tinnitus and is unable to hear in noisy environments. On pure tone audiometry, a downsloping audiogram is seen. Which of the following additional features is seen in the audiogram of this patient?

OPD - outpatient department

choices.text: Dip at 2000 Hz in air conduction
Dip at 2000 Hz in both air and bone conduction
Dip at 4000 Hz in air conduction
Dip at 4000 Hz in both air and bone conduction

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a 30-year-old man with hearing loss and pure tone audiometry showing a downsloping audiogram is suggestive of noise-induced hearing loss. The audiogram will show a dip at 4000 Hz in both air and bone conduction.

Noise-induced hearing loss is a sensorineural hearing loss and is seen in chronic exposure to loud sounds in occupation. It is caused by irreversible damage to the outer hair cells in the organ of Corti. As the duration of noise exposure increases, the notch becomes deeper and wider, involving lower and higher frequencies.

A noise of 90 dB  8 hours per day for 5 days per week is the maximum safe limit as recommended by the Ministry of Labour, Government of India.

PTA showing noise-induced hearing loss as downsloping audiogram:


In otosclerosis, an audiogram shows a typical notch at 2000 Hz in bone conduction only (Cahart's notch). 

The audiogram given below shows Cahart's notch seen in otosclerosis:


Other causes of downsloping PTA are:

Presbycusis is a physiological sensorineural hearing loss occurring in individuals above 65 years of age. Audiometry shows a downsloping graph. Patients can  be helped by giving a hearing aid.

Ototoxicity causes bilateral high-frequency sensorineural hearing loss. Audiometry shows a downsloping audiogram, typically involving frequencies above 8,000 Hz, and progresses to lower speech frequencies. Common drugs causing the same include aminoglycoside antibiotics; loop diuretics (not thiazides), cisplatin.

Related Pearl: Pure tone audiometry (PTA)

A pure tone is the sound of a single frequency. An audiometer is a device that generates pure tones and its frequency can be increased or decreased by 5Hz.

The threshold for air conduction (AC) of sound frequencies from 125-8000 Hz and the threshold for bone conduction (BC) of sound frequencies from 250-4000 Hz is measured and the result is plotted on an audiogram.

Normal thresholds:
  • For AC: 15 dB
  • For BC: 25 dB

Symbols used in pure tone audiometry:

 

Disease Findings in PTA audiogram
Conductive hearing loss AC abnormal, BC normal, air-bone gap present
Sensorineural hearing loss Both AC and BC are abnormal and no air-Bone gap
Mixed hearing loss Both AC and BC abnormal and air-bone gap present
Presbycusis, ototoxicity, noise-induced hearing loss (higher frequencies affected first) Downsloping or descending audiogram 
Early stages of Meniere's disease (lower frequencies affected first) Upsloping or ascending audiogram
Congenital hearing loss and cochlear otosclerosis (mid-frequency hearing loss) U-shaped or trough-shaped or cookie bite shaped audiogram
Early cases of noise-induced hearing loss

Acoustic dip - characteristic dip in both AC and BC at 4000 Hz
Otosclerosis  Carhart's notch- dip at 2000 Hz in BC curve

questions.text: A man who is a chronic alcoholic has abdominal pain, diarrhea, nausea, vomiting, and mucosal ulcers. Stool examination revealed the following. What is the causative organism for the above condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with stool examination showing a large ovoid trophozoite with cilia all over the surface suggests balantidiasis, the causative organism for which is Balantidium coli. 

It is the only ciliated protozoan and is present as a commensal in the large intestine. It is mostly asymptomatic in healthy individuals. However, certain predisposing factors such as malnourishment, alcoholism, concurrent infection with Trichuris trichiura, or bacterial infection can cause clinical infection.

Clinical manifestations include mucosal ulcers, diarrhea, frank dysentery, abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting. 

Diagnosis is by stool examination, showing the presence of trophozoites in diarrheic feces and cysts in formed stools. Trophozoites are large in size, with a macronucleus and rapid-revolving motility, while cysts are round with a macronucleus.

The trophozoite is shown in the image below:

Treatment is with tetracycline 500 mg 4 times a day for 10 days. 

Other options:

Option A: Babesia infection causes babesiosis, which is a disease that resembles malaria. Diagnosis is by the examination of blood smears stained with Leishman or Giemsa stain, where Babesia appears as intraerythrocytic round, pyriform, or ring forms, like Plasmodium falciparum.

Option B: Cyclospora infection causes prolonged diarrhea, abdominal pain, and vomiting which is more severe in immunocompromised individuals. On wet mount, oocysts are seen as red spheres when stained with acid-fast stain.

Option D: Isospora belli infection causes watery diarrhea that is self-limiting. The oocyst is not easily seen on stool-wet mounts. It may be visible after stool concentration and staining with acid-fast stain, as shown below.

questions.text:
A 32-year-old man came with progressive difficulty in swallowing food. Barium study showed marked dilatation of the esophagus proximal to the obstruction. Further investigations reveal incomplete relaxation of the LES in response to swallowing, high resting LES pressure, and absent esophageal peristalsis. Which among the following is responsible for this?

LES- Lower esophageal sphincter
VIP- Vasoactive intestinal peptide
NO- Nitric oxide
ACh- Acetylcholine
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario points to a diagnosis of achalasia cardia. In this condition, VIP and NO are decreased causing failure of the LES to relax.

Achalasia cardia is a condition in which food accumulates in the esophagus. It leads to massive dilatation as a result of increased resting LES tone and incomplete relaxation on swallowing. The myenteric plexus of the esophagus is deficient at the LES and the release of NO and VIP is decreased.

Normally, the tone of the LES is under neural control. The release of acetylcholine from vagal endings causes the intrinsic sphincter to contract, and the release of NO and VIP from interneurons causes it to relax. The crural portion of the diaphragm is innervated by the phrenic nerves. Its contraction is coordinated with respiration and contractions of the chest and abdominal muscles. Thus, the intrinsic and extrinsic sphincters operate together. This permits the orderly flow of food into the stomach and prevents reflux of gastric contents into the esophagus. 

Related Pearl: Mechanism of peristalsis

questions.text: A middle-aged woman presents with progressive atrophy and weakness in her hands and forearms. On examination, she is found to have spasticity of the legs and a brisk jaw jerk.  Which of the following clinical findings would eliminate amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) as a differential diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Impaired bowel and bladder function are not associated with amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS). Even in the late stages of the disease, bowel and bladder functions are preserved.

Sensory, bowel and bladder, ocular motility, and cognitive functions are preserved even in the later stages of ALS. Spontaneous fasciculations and progressive asymmetrical distal weakness are found early on in this disease. Degeneration of corticobulbar projections causes the pseudobulbar effect resulting in inappropriate laughing, crying, or yawning. 

ALS is the most common progressive motor neuron disease. The pathologic hallmark of ALS includes the involvement of lower motor neurons of the ventral/ anterior horn of the spinal cord, cranial nerves innervating the bulbar muscles, and the afferent corticospinal upper motor neurons in layer five of the motor cortex.

Clinical features of ALS include:

  • Lower motor neuron level - 
    • Fasciculations
    • Muscle cramps
    • Distal weakness and atrophy
    • Bulbar palsy - dysarthria, dysphagia, respiratory compromise
  • Upper motor neuron level - 
    • Spasticity
    • Increased reflexes
    • Flexor spasms
    • Pseudobulbar affect - inappropriate laughing, crying, yawning
  • Others - 
    • Split-hand syndrome - thenar hand intrinsic muscles are affected with relative sparing of the hypothenar muscles
    • Dropped head syndrome - due to severe neck extensor weakness
    • Frontotemporal dementia

The diagnosis of ALS is usually clinical. Presence of upper motor neuron and lower motor neuron signs, along with normal CSF, blood, and urine analysis. Electrodiagnostic studies like electromyography may show fibrillation, and positive sharp waves indicative of active denervation. Neuroimaging shows an increased signal in the corticospinal tracts on T2-weighted MRI. The newer Awaji criteria are used for the diagnosis of ALS by using electrophysiological findings in addition to the clinical findings.

The image given below shows an MRI with an increased T2 signal within the posterior part of the internal capsule, consistent with the clinical diagnosis of ALS. 


The treatment is not curative but aids in lengthening survival.

  • Riluzole reduces excitotoxicity by diminishing glutamate release and improving survival.
  • Edaravone is a novel scavenger of oxygen radicals, capable of slowing down ALS progression and improving survival. It is an adjuvant to riluzole.
  • Symptomatic treatment of spasticity - 
    • GABA receptor agonists like baclofen
    • Alpha-2 receptor agonists like tizanidine
    • Other agents - benzodiazepines like clonazepam are used in early ALS without respiratory compromise.

questions.text: An elderly man presenting with bladder outlet obstruction undergoes an extensive workup. PSA levels are 25 ng/ml. Adenocarcinoma of the prostate was confirmed on biopsy. This condition commonly arises from which zone of the gland?
questions.solution:
Prostatic carcinoma arises from the peripheral zone (B) of the gland.

The prostate has three distinct zones as follows:

ZONE STRUCTURES ENCLOSED CLINICAL SIGNIFICANCE
Transitional zone Urethra  The common site for BPH (benign prostatic hyperplasia)
Central zone Ejaculatory ducts Rarely diseased
Peripheral zone

Central transitional zone

Pre-prostatic urethra

 The common site for prostatic carcinoma

Benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) arises from the transitional zone.

Carcinoma of the prostate is the most common malignant tumor in men over the age of 65 years  They may range from indolent lesions that cause no harm to aggressive metastatic tumors. Most cancers are clinically silent and are detected on routine rectal examination or PSA measurements.

Grossly, malignant tissue is gritty and firm in consistency (in contrast to the spongy appearance of benign tissue) and thus more readily palpable on digital rectal examination. 

Only advanced disease gives rise to symptoms:

  • Bladder outlet obstruction
  • Pelvic pain and haematuria
  • Bone pain, arthritis
  • Anemia or pancytopenia
  • Renal failure

PSA (prostate specific antigen) is a glycoprotein peptidase that facilitates the liquefaction of semen. It is useful for screening and for monitoring response to therapy but is neither specific nor sensitive to the condition as it can be elevated due to old age and benign conditions such as prostatitis and BPH. A PSA >10ng/ mL is suggestive of cancer and >35 ng/ml is almost diagnostic of advanced prostate cancer. Following radical prostatectomy, the serum PSA should fall to undetectable levels

A prostate biopsy using an automated gun is used to confirm the diagnosis. Around 12 systematic biopsy cores are obtained. This procedure can be done by transrectal or transperineal approach.

Gleason grading may be used after the biopsy to evaluate the stage of the histopathological specimen. Gleason scores range from 6 to 10 where 6 is a low risk for prostate cancer while 10 is a high risk.

Staging of prostate carcinoma
Tx Primary tumor cannot be assessed
T0 No evidence of primary tumor
T1 Clinically inapparent tumor. Neither palpable nor visible on imaging
T1a Incidental histologic findings in 5% or less of tissue resected
T1b Incidental histologic findings in more than 5% of tissue resected
T1c Tumors identified by needle biopsy (for example, because of elevated PSA)
T2

Tumor confined within the prostate
T2a

A tumor involves one-half of one lobe or less
T2b

Tumor involves more than one-half of one lobe but not both lobes
T2c

Tumor involves both lobes
T3

Tumors extend through the prostate capsule
T3a The extracapsular extension (unilateral or bilateral)
T3b

Tumor invades seminal vesicle(s)
T4 Tumor is fixed or invades adjacent structures other than seminal vesicles, such as the external sphincter, rectum, bladder, levator muscles, and/or pelvic wall

Management of prostatic carcinoma:

Management of prostatic carcinoma   
Stage of cancer Age>70 or Gleason score=6  Age<70 or Gleason score>6    
Early prostate cancer: T1, T2A Active surveillance Radical prostatectomy   
Locally advanced prostate cancer: T2B, T2C, T3, T4, N1 Brachytherapy + Androgen deprivation therapy Brachytherapy + Radical prostatectomy
Metastatic prostate cancer   

Androgen deprivation therapy

Chemotherapy and radiotherapy (hormone-resistant  tumor)

Radiopharmaceutical therapy (hormone-resistant bony metastasis) 

Active surveillance is done when there is:

  • Gleason's score of 6
  • Early-stage disease (T1c)
  • Small volume disease on biopsy
  • Low PSA (< 10 ng/ml)

Active surveillance protocols include a digital rectal examination and PSA monitoring every 3 to 6 months, with TRUS-guided prostate biopsies every 1 to 3 years.

questions.text: A 50-year-old diabetic patient came with complaints of a lesion over his foot, as shown below. Which of the following substances may be least effective in removing the infested organism?
questions.solution:
The above image shows a diabetic foot ulcer in a patient infested with maggots. Povidone iodine is the least effective in removing maggots. 

Substances such as silver sulfadiazine, zinc oxide, turpentine oil, hydrogen peroxide, and antibiotics such as ivermectin and clindamycin have been proven effective in killing maggot-infested ulcers. However, povidone-iodine has been ineffective in studies evaluating the efficacy of substances that kill maggots. 

The invasion of human tissue by fly larvae is known as myiasis. It first appears as a pink papule that itches, then as a tortuous line that grows 1–30 cm daily. Wound debridement and precise dissection of the callus tissue to promote the formation of granulation tissue are the main treatments for ulcers infested with maggots.

Disposing of the maggots is also essential to stop further infestations inside the medical facility.

questions.text:
A 65 year old male has been admitted with a diagnosis of infective endocarditis of the aortic valve and has been started on empirical antibiotics.Which of the following scenarios would warrant a surgical intervention for an optimal treatment outcome?

1. Unresolving fever despite 5 days of antibiotic therapy

2. Blood culture growing methicillin resistant Staphylococcus aureus

3. Appearance of PR prolongation on ECG tracing

4. Valvular incompetence causing moderate heart failure

5. Large vegetation with a history of embolus
questions.solution:
Among the given statements, 3, 4, and 5 (option C) represent the indications for surgery in infective endocarditis.

Infective endocarditis is the infection of the heart valves, usually treated with a prolonged course of antibiotics. The indications for surgery are as follows:

  • Moderate or severe congestive heart failure or shock due to valve dysfunction (Statement 4)
  • Paravalvular extension of infection with abscess, fistula, or heart block 
  • Persistent bacteremia without an extracardiac cause despite 7–10 days of optimal antimicrobial therapy 
  • Lack of effective antimicrobial therapy 
  • Partially dehisced unstable prosthetic valve
  • Paravalvular extension of infection with abscess, fistula, or heart block
  • Staphylococcus aureus infection with intracardiac complications 
  • Relapse after optimal antimicrobial therapy 
  • Large (>10 mm) hypermobile vegetation, particularly with prior systemic embolus and significant valve dysfunction (Statement 5)
  • Persistent unexplained fever (≥10 days) in blood culture-negative endocarditis (Statement 1)

Appearance of PR prolongation on ECG signifies AV block due to perivalvular extension of the infection (due to close proximity of AV node to the aortic valve root) that can lead to complete heart block if not intervened at the earliest. (Statement 3)

MRSA infection in itself, without intracardiac complications, is not an indication for surgery and can be managed with antibiotics. (Statement 2)

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy presents with features of diabetic ketoacidosis. After initial management, you ask the nurse to give insulin infusion, who mistakenly administers the insulin as a bolus dose. Following this, you notice a few ECG changes on the monitor. What is the most likely ECG finding in this event?
questions.solution:
Administering insulin bolus will result in hypokalemia, leading to the appearance of U waves on ECG.

A bolus dose of intravenous insulin causes hypokalemia by activating sodium-potassium ATPase in the cell membranes, thereby driving the serum potassium into the cells. The resulting hypokalemia is responsible for certain ECG findings like U waves, flat T waves, ST segment depression, and QT prolongation.

Hypokalemia is defined as a plasma concentration of K+ <3.5 meq/L. Common causes include: 

  • Metabolic alkalosis
  • Insulin infusions
  • Diarrhea
  • Use of diuretics
  • Starvation
  • β2-agonists
  • Magnesium deficiency
  • Primary hyperaldosteronism

Option B - ST depression, and not elevation, is seen in hypokalemia. ST elevation is seen in several other conditions like acute myocardial infarction, acute pericarditis, pulmonary embolism, myocarditis, Brugada syndrome and some cases of hyperkalemia.

Option C - Prolonged QT interval is a finding in hypokalemia. Shortened QT interval is seen in hypercalcemia.

Option D - Tall T waves are a finding in hyperkalemia and not hypokalemia.

questions.text:
A 50-year-old chronic smoker presenting with hoarseness of voice was found to have an ulceroproliferative growth on both vocal cords that appear fixed. CT scan reveals its extension into the thyroid cartilage, without any neck node involvement. PET CT is unremarkable. What is the management of the patient according to its TNM staging?

CT- Computed Tomography
PET- Positron Emission Tomography
questions.solution:
This clinical vignette with laryngoscopy showing ulceroproliferative growth on both vocal cords which is extending into thyroid cartilage with no neck involvement suggests T4a, N0, M0. Management at this stage would be total laryngectomy followed by radiotherapy.

In total laryngectomy, the entire larynx, including the hyoid bone, pre-epiglottic space, strap muscles, and one or more rings of trachea, are removed. The pharyngeal wall is repaired, and the tracheal stump is sutured to the skin to allow respiration. 

The indications of total laryngectomy are as follows:

  • T3 lesions
  • All T4 lesions
  • Invasion of thyroid or cricoid cartilage
  • Bilateral arytenoid cartilage involvement
  • Lesions of the posterior commissure 
  • Failure after radiotherapy or conservation surgery
  • Transglottic cancers with cord fixation

It is contraindicated in patients with distant metastasis.

Larynx is divided into three regions - supraglottis, glottis, and subglottis. In the TNM system: T indicates the extent of the tumor, N indicates lymph node involvement, and M indicates distant metastasis.

TNM classification of glottic carcinoma (American Joint Committee on Cancer, 2002)

Stage Description
T1 Tumour limited to the vocal cord(s) with normal mobility
T1a Tumour limited to one vocal cord
T1b Tumour involves both vocal cords
T2a Tumour extends to supraglottis and/or subglottis, with normal vocal cord mobility
T2b Tumour extends to supraglottis and/or subglottis, with impaired vocal cord mobility
T3 Tumour limited to the larynx with vocal cord fixation and/or invades paraglottic space and / or minor thyroid cartilage erosion
T4a Tumour invades thyroid cartilage and/or invades tissue beyond the larynx
T4b Tumour invades prevertebral space, encases carotid artery or invades mediastinal structures


Treatment of laryngeal cancers :

T stage Treatment 
T1a TLM > RT
T1b RT/TLM > OPL
T2a RT/TLM > OPL
T2b RT ± CT > TLM
T3 CRT
T4a TL> RT
T4b Palliative management

TLM: Transoral laser microsurgery; RT: Radiotherapy; OPL: Open partial laryngectomy; CT: Chemotherapy; CRT: Chemoradiotherapy, TL: Total laryngectomy.

questions.text: An intern while putting the catheter forgot to pull the prepuce back which led to paraphimosis. The head of the department was held liable for the intern’s negligence. What is this called?
questions.solution:
The senior doctor is responsible for the negligent act of a junior doctor, resident, intern, or assistant working under him by the principle respondeat superior(vicarious liability).

Vicarious liability is by which the employer is responsible for his employees’ negligence if such an act occurs in the course of the employment and within its scope. It is by the principle of 'respondeat superior' (let the superior answer).

When two doctors practice as partners, they are both responsible for each other's negligent acts. When 2 or more doctors independently attend to a patient, each may be held liable for the negligence of others that he observes or in the ordinary course should have observed and allowed it to continue without objection.

Other options:

Option A: When an employee is being borrowed, the lending employer temporarily loses his control over this worker and the borrowing employer assumes control. This is known as the borrowed servant doctrine.

Option B: Res ipsa loquitur means 'the thing speaks for itself'. It is used as supportive evidence of negligence on the part of the doctor. Say leaving behind a scalpel or scissors whilst operating leading to sepsis/peritonitis speaks for itself.

Option C: Res indicata-A suit for damages for negligence should be filed against the doctor within two years from the date of alleged negligence. A suit filed after two years will be dismissed.

questions.text:
Which of the following are contrast agents used in MRI?
  1. Gastrografin 
  2. Gadolinium 
  3. Levovist
  4. Iohexol
  5. USPIO
questions.solution:
The correct answer is Option B: 2,5 

MRI uses magnetic properties. The contrast agents used for MRI are gadolinium and USPIO (Ultra-Small Superparamagnetic Iron Oxide) which are paramagnetic substances which can change the local magnetic field. 

Gadolinium acts by reducing both T1 and T2 relaxation time of the tissue. The predominant effect is on T1, so post-contrast is a T1 weighted image. Since free gadolinium ion is toxic, Gd-DTPA (Gadolinium diethylenetriamine penta-acetic acid) is used. Gadolinium does not cross the blood-brain barrier unless the barrier is disrupted. 

Contraindications for Gadolinium:

  • Renal failure - Gd-DTPA is predominantly excreted through the kidney. Hence, in renal failure, it gets accumulated in the body and releases gadolinium ions. Since the ion is toxic, the body tries to contain it by fibrosis resulting in multisystem painful fibrosis called nephrogenic systemic fibrosis. As a result, gadolinium-containing contrast is contraindicated in patients with an estimated GFR under 60 ml/min and especially under 30 ml/min.
  • Pregnancy - Due to the risk of teratogenicity

Gadobutrol (gadolinium-based contrast agent) is the first and only contrast agent approved by the FDA for the use of cardiac MRI in adult patients with known or suspected coronary artery disease.

USPIO is a T2 agent and is usually taken by cells of the reticuloendothelial system.

Gastrografin and Iohexol are iodinated contrast agents. They cannot be used for MRI as iodine does not have magnetic or paramagnetic properties. Iohexol is used as an intravascular contrast medium for radiography such as CT scans and in the diagnostic work-up of esophageal perforation. Gastrografin is used for radiographic examination of the gastrointestinal tract. It is taken orally or administered as an enema. 

Levovist is an ultrasound contrast agent. Ultrasound contrast agents are gas-filled microbubbles that are administered intravenously to the systemic circulation.

questions.text:

1. Valproate
2. Rifampicin

questions.solution:
Contraceptive failure in patients on the oral contraceptive pill is likely to occur with rifampicin, phenytoin, and phenobarbitone.

Rifampicin, phenytoin, and phenobarbitone are enzyme inducers and can cause increased metabolism of OCPs leading to contraceptive failure.

Valproate does not cause contraceptive failure. It is an enzyme inhibitor that inhibits the degradation of OCPs and increases their duration of action.

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy presents with left knee swelling following a trivial injury. His platelet count and bleeding time are normal. His aPTT is prolonged and factor VIII levels are decreased. Which of the following can be used in the management of his condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a child presenting with left knee swelling, likely due to hemarthrosis, prolonged aPTT and low factor VIII levels are suggestive of hemophilia A. Emicizumab can be used in the management of his condition. 

Hemophilia A is an X-linked recessive disorder that occurs due to a deficiency of clotting factor VIII. Symptoms include easy bruising, intramuscular hematomas, hemarthrosis, hematuria, and bleeding from minor traumatic lacerations. Retroperitoneal hemorrhages can accumulate large volumes of blood and may cause a hypovolemic shock.

Laboratory findings in hemophilia A include:

  • Reduced Factor VIII
  • Prolonged Activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT)
  • Normal platelet count
  • Normal bleeding time
  • Normal prothrombin time
  • The mixing of normal plasma with patient plasma results in the correction of the aPTT value

Based on the percent activity of specific clotting factors, hemophilia is classified into:

Severity The activity of a specific clotting factor
Severe <1%
Moderate 1-5%
Mild >5%

 

Mild cases of hemophilia are treated by administration of desmopressin acetate. Moderate to severe cases need the replacement of deficient clotting factors (factor VIII in hemophilia A and factor IX in hemophilia B).

Emicizumab is a bispecific, humanized monoclonal antibody that can bridge activated factor IX and factor X, thus restoring functional activated factor VIII activity in patients with hemophilia.

Other options:

Option B: Voxeletor is a hemoglobin polymerization inhibitor used in the treatment of sickle cell anemia.

Option C: Luspatarcept is a fusion protein recently approved for the treatment of transfusion-dependent thalassemia.

Option D: Ruxolitinib is a non-specific JAK2 inhibitor used in the treatment of polycythemia vera and myelofibrosis.

questions.text:
As an intern posted in pediatric department, you are asked to check for capillary blood glucose value in a term neonate born to a diabetic mother. Which of the following are true regarding the procedure?

1. Prewarming the infant's heel is important
2. Alternate squeeze of calf muscle to increase blood flow and yield
3. The central portion of the heel is preferred
4. Usage of alcohol swab can result in false high glucose values
questions.solution:
The true statements are 1, 2, and 4 (Option B). The procedure that is done to check for capillary blood glucose in a neonate is the heel-prick test.

Technique of heel-prick test: It is important that the heel is pre-warmed with a cotton wad or towel soaked in sterile warm water at 40oC to increase the blood flow to the heel before pricking for adequate blood sample collection. The peripheral portion of the heel is the appropiate prick-site and the central portion of the heel is avoided as it might injure the underlying calcaneum bone. After pricking, the blood sample is collected by alternate squeezing and releasing of the calf muscles.

Complications /pitfalls of heel-prick test:

  • Puncture of the calcaneum leading to necrotizing chondritis or osteomyelitis.
  • Calcified nodules of the heel
  • Mechanical trauma leading to increased hemolysis in the sample - falsely elevated bilirubin values or increased K+ values. 
  • Falsely high glucose estimation if a alcohol swab is used for sterilization before prick.
  • Inaccurate pCO2 and pO2 values due to poor blood flow to the heel.

questions.text: A child who presented with acute right iliac fossa pain and vomiting was suspected to have acute appendicitis. While ruling out the differential diagnoses of this condition in the child, a resident looks for colicky pain and cervical lymphadenopathy. Which condition is she trying to rule out?
questions.solution:
By looking for colicky pain and cervical lymphadenopathy, the resident is trying to rule out mesenteric lymphadenitis.

Differential diagnosis of acute appendicitis:

Children

  • Mesenteric lymphadenitis- colicky pain and enlarged cervical lymph nodes may be present
  • Meckel's diverticulitis- signs will be central or left-sided/ History of lower GI bleeding might be present
  • Henoch-Schonlein purpura- often preceded by sore throat/ ecchymotic rashes on the extensors of limbs/ buttocks/microscopic hematuria will be present
  • Intussusception- common around 18 months of age, whereas appendicitis is uncommon before 2 years of age
  • Lobar pneumonia and pleurisy-marked fever/pleural friction rub on auscultation  
  • Gastroenteritis- fever might be common 

Adult

  • Regional enteritis (Yersinia enterocolitica induced) 
  • Ureteric colic
  • Perforated peptic ulcer
  • Testicular torsion
  • Acute pancreatitis

Adult female

  • Mittelschmerz syndrome
  • Pelvic inflammatory disease
  • Pyelonephritis
  • Ectopic pregnancy
  • Endometriosis
  • Torsion/ rupture of ovarian cyst

Elderly

  • Diverticulitis
  • Intestinal obstruction
  • Colon carcinoma
  • Mesenteric infarction
  • Leaking aortic aneurysm
