questions.text:
Which of the following structures are ensheathed by the investing layer of deep cervical fascia?
  1. Trapezius muscle
  2. Scalenus anterior muscle
  3. Thyroid gland
  4. Submandibular gland
  5. Esophagus
questions.solution:
Among the following structures, trapezius muscle and submandibular gland are enveloped by the superficial or investing layer of deep cervical fascia. 

Deep cervical fascia is subdivided into three sheets - superficial/investing, middle and deep layers. The investing layer forms the roof of the anterior and posterior triangle. The investing layer of deep cervical fascia splits to enclose :

  • Muscles: Trapezius and sternocleidomastoid
  • Salivary glands: Parotid and submandibular 
  • Spaces: Suprasternal and supraclavicular

The prevertebral fascia is closely related to the vertebral bodies. It extends from the base of the skull to the superior mediastinum. Here it blends with the anterior longitudinal ligament. It encloses the following muscles:

  • Longus colli and longus capitis
  • Scalene muscles
  • Splenius capitis
  • Levator scapulae

The pretracheal layer of fascia is situated in the anterior neck. It is present between the hyoid bone superiorly and the thorax inferiorly. The trachea, oesophagus, thyroid gland and infrahyoid muscles are enclosed by the pretracheal fascia. 

Related Pearl: Modifications of Deep cervical fascia

The deep fascia in the neck is condensed to form the following layers:

Investing layer - It forms the roof of the posterior triangle and splits to enclose:

  • Parotid gland
  • Submandibular gland

Pretracheal fascia - It splits to enclose the thyroid gland to form its false capsule. This capsule is thickened posteriorly and on either side forms the suspensory ligament which is known as the ligament of Berry.

Carotid sheath - is formed anteriorly by pre tracheal fascia and posteriorly by the prevertebral fascia. It encloses:

  • Common carotid artery
  • Internal carotid artery
  • Internal jugular vein
  • Vagus nerve 

Prevertebral fascia - It forms the floor of the posterior triangle and the axillary sheath. Inferiorly, it blends with the anterior longitudinal ligament.

Buccopharyngeal fascia - It covers the outer surface of the pharyngeal constrictors and the buccinator. Posteriorly, it's separated from the prevertebral fascia by the retropharyngeal space.

Pharyngobasilar fascia - It fills the gap between superior constrictor and base of the skull.

questions.text: A man who has had lung cancer underwent treatment for the same. Following his recovery, he donated his money and opened a cancer hospital for the treatment of cancer patients and worked in NGOs dealing closely with people with health-related problems. What defense mechanism is displayed by him?
questions.solution:
Altruism as a defense mechanism is displayed by him in this scenario.

Altruism: It refers to a phenomenon where a person puts another person's needs before their own needs and finds value in helping others. 

Example: A person who is recovering from substance use might volunteer to help others in recovery as a way to deal with drug cravings.

Other options

Option B: Displacement is a neurotic defense mechanism. In displacement, the person carries out purposeful, unconscious shifting of impulses from one object or person to another. Although the object is changed, the instinctual nature of the impulse and its aim remain unchanged and this differentiates it from sublimation where the end goal is changed to a socially acceptable one

Example: A person may be angry towards their boss for reprimanding him and wants to abuse his boss by using foul language. Here, the person displaces his anger by being rude and using foul language to his parents at home.

Option C: Sublimation is a mature defense mechanism. It means to gratify an impulse by changing the end goal from a socially objectionable one to a socially valued one. For example, a person who is experiencing extreme anger might take up kickboxing as a means to vent out his frustration

Option D: Projection is an immature defense mechanism. On a nonpsychotic level, projection involves attributing one's own unacknowledged feelings to others. At higher levels, it may include misinterpreting motives, attitudes, feelings, or intentions of others.

Example: A man wishes to cheat on his wife, instead he says that he is sure his wife is cheating on him. Here, he is projecting his own unacknowledged feelings on his wife. 

Related Pearl: Defense mechanisms

Narcissistic-psychotic defenses

Denial: Used to avoid becoming aware of some painful aspects of reality.

  • Eg: I know I do not have cancer.

Distortion: Grossly reshaping the experience of external reality to suit inner needs.

  • Eg: I possess special powers and abilities and am superior to others.

Projection (psychotic): Attributing your own wishes, thoughts, or feelings onto someone else.

  • Eg: I’m sure my wife is cheating on me.

Splitting: External objects are divided into all good or all bad.

  • Eg: The morning staff is perfect, the evening staff is terrible.

 

Immature defenses

Acting out: Behavioral or emotional outburst.

  • Eg: My 10-year-old started getting into trouble right after his mother and I got divorced.

Blocking: Temporary block in thinking.

  • Eg: I have known him for years but can never seem to remember his name.

Hypochondriasis: A defense style in which people say that no one understands their pain.

  • Eg: No one understands the depth of my pain.

Introjection: Features of the external world are taken and made part of the self.

  • Eg: The resident physician dresses like the attending whom he admires.

Passive-aggressive behavior: Aggressive intent is cloaked by a passive method.

  • Eg: Procrastinating at work for not getting the promotion.

Projection (non-psychotic): Unwanted feelings are displaced onto another person.

  • Eg: A man who has been unfaithful to his wife but accuses his wife of cheating on him.

Regression: Return to an earlier stage of development, most immature.

  • Eg: Ever since my divorce, my 5-year-old has begun to wet the bed.

Schizoid fantasy: Tendency to retreat into fantasy in order to resolve inner and outer conflicts.

  • Eg: Adolescents day dreaming on pornographic materials.

Somatization: Psychic derivatives are converted into bodily symptoms.

  • Eg: Just thinking of the exam I get butterflies in my stomach.

 

Neurotic defenses

Externalization: Perceiving one’s personality, impulses, moods and attitudes in the external world.

  • Eg: An argumentative person perceives the doctor as argumentative whilst believing himself to be blameless.

Displacement: Shifting emotions about one object/ individual onto another object/ individual.

  • Eg: Getting angry at your parents because you had a bad day at work.

Inhibition: conscious or unconscious constraint of a process or behavior.

  • Eg: A desire to eat dessert versus the desire to lose weight.

Intellectualization: Excessive use of intellectual processes to avoid affective expression or experience.

  • Eg: It is interesting to note the specific skin lesions which seem to arise as a consequence of my end-stage disease.

Isolation: Separation of an idea from the affect that accompanies it.

  • Eg: As she arrived at the station to identify the body, she appeared to show no emotion.

Rationalization: Rational explanations are used to justify unacceptable attitudes, beliefs, or behaviors.

  • Eg: I did not pass the test because it was harder this year than ever before.

Reaction formation: An unacceptable impulse is transformed into its opposite; results in the formation of character traits.

  • Eg: Listen to him tell his family he was not afraid when I saw him crying.

Repression: An idea or feeling is withheld from consciousness; unconscious forgetting.

  • Eg: I do not remember having had a dog.

Sexualization: Endowing an object or function with sexual significance.

Undoing: Acting out the reverse of unacceptable behavior; consists of an act.

  • Eg: I need to wash my hands whenever I have these thoughts.

Retroflexion: Self-destruction due to rage.

  • Eg: A person cutting his wrist because he is angry with himself.

 

Mature defenses

Altruism: Getting pleasure from giving to others what the individual would have liked to receive.

  • Eg:  A former alcoholic funding a rehabilitation center.

Anticipation: Realistically planning or anticipating future inner discomfort.

  • Eg: Moderate amount of anxiety before surgery.

Asceticism: Gratification derived from renunciation.

Humor: Permits the expression of feelings and thoughts without personal discomfort.

  • Eg: Before execution, firing squad leader offers the man a cigarette. He replies "no thanks I'm trying to quit".

Sublimation: Impulse gratification has been achieved, but the aim or object has been changed from unacceptable to acceptable; allows instincts to be channeled. Most mature of the defenses.

  • Eg: Jack the Ripper becomes a surgeon.

Suppression: Conscious forgetting. The only conscious defense mechanism.

  • Eg: I would rather talk about my operation after the party is over.

questions.text: A woman with a tumor in the left cerebral hemisphere underwent surgery, chemotherapy, and radiation therapy. Biopsy of the tumor specimen showed a circumscribed, gelatinous, gray mass with calcification. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario (tumor in the cerebral hemisphere) and the gross pathology (circumscribed, gelatinous, gray mass with calcification) of the tumor in a female is most likely oligodendroglioma.

Oligodendrogliomas account for 5 to 15% of all gliomas and most commonly are detected in the fourth and fifth decades of life. Patients may have had several years of antecedent neurologic complaints, often including seizures. The lesions are found mostly in the cerebral hemispheres, mainly in the frontal or temporal lobes.

The tumors are composed of sheets of regular cells with spherical nuclei containing finely granular chromatin (similar to normal oligodendrocytes) surrounded by a clear halo of vacuolated cytoplasm giving a fried egg appearance. Tumor cells infiltrating the cerebral cortex often collect around neurons (perineuronal satellitosis).

The image below shows the fried egg appearance on histopathology:


The combination of surgery, chemotherapy, and radiotherapy yields an average survival of 10 to 20 years for well-differentiated (WHO grade II) oligodendroglioma or 5 to 10 years for anaplastic (WHO grade III) oligodendroglioma.

Other options:

Option A: Meningiomas are non-glial in origin and arise from the meningocytes or arachnoid cap cells of the meninges, mostly seen outside the brain parenchyma, and can occur anywhere meninges are found.

Option B: Ependymomas most often arise next to the ependyma-lined ventricular system, including the central canal of the spinal cord. In the first 2 decades of life, they typically occur near the fourth ventricle and constitute 5% to 10% of the primary brain tumors in this age group. In adults, the spinal cord is their most common location; tumors in this site are particularly frequent in the setting of neurofibromatosis type 2.

Option D: Pilocytic astrocytoma is a low-grade tumor. It is the most common type of astrocytoma in children. It typi­cally occurs in children and young adults. The classic sites of pilocytic astrocytoma are the cerebellum (infratentorial) and optic pathway region.

questions.text: A patient with complaints of excessive thirst and increased frequency of urination is evaluated with a water deprivation test. The  findings are as shown in the graph below. What does this indicate?
questions.solution:
The given graph represents the urine and serum osmolality after conducting the water deprivation test and suggests central diabetes insipidus.  

This graph indicates that on withholding water there is no response but on administration of vasopressin, there is an increase in the serum and urine osmolality. This shows that the kidneys respond to antidiuretic hormone, hence this curve indicates central diabetes insipidus.

Diabetes insipidus can be of two types - central or peripheral (nephrogenic). Central DI occurs due to a deficiency of ADH. 

Central diabetes insipidus (DI) is a disorder of the posterior pituitary. It is characterized by decreased ADH leading to large volumes of urine production. Patients present with excessive thirst, nocturia, and urinary frequency. The urine is dilute with an osmolarity of < 300 mOsm/L. The 24-hour urine volume is >40 ml/kg and the basal plasma ADH is <1 pg/ml.

Central DI occurs due to damage to the neurohypophysis in the posterior pituitary. It can be congenital or acquired.

Central DI can be treated with desmopressin, an ADH analogue. Nephrogenic DI requires treatment with a thiazide diuretic, amiloride, low sodium diet, and indomethacin. 

Primary polydipsia can be caused either by compulsory water drinking(dipsogenic polydipsia) or psychogenic polydipsia. Here while the body is still physiologically normal, the responses to water deprivation and vasopressin isn't as robust as a normal individual. 

nephrogenic diabetes insipidus has no response to water-deprivation test.

Related Pearl: Water Deprivation test in Diabetes Insipidus

Procedure: Start the test at 4 am by checking the baseline urine osmolality. Deprive the patient of water till 12 pm (8 hours), and then re-check urine osmolality. 

  Urine osmolality before water deprivation Urine osmolality after water deprivation Urine osmolality after desmopressin administration
Normal  Normal  Increases No change
Central DI Low No change >50% increase from baseline
Nephrogenic DI Low No change <10% increase from baseline
Primary polydipsia Low Increases No change


Note: Normal urine osmolality- 500-850 mOsm/L

Related Pearl: Causes of Central Diabetes insipidus

  • Neoplasms: 
    • Pituitary adenomas (most common)
    • Meningioma
    • Metastasis from lung and breast cancers
  • Infiltrative: 
    • Sarcoidosis
    • Langerhans cell histiocytosis
  • Genetic: 
    • Wolfram syndrome
    • Hand-Schuller-Christian disease 
  • Infections: 
    • Chronic meningitis
    • Viral encephalitis
    • Toxoplasmosis
  •  Inflammatory:
    • Granulomatosis with polyangiitis
    • Lupus erythematosus
    • Scleroderma
  •  Vascular:
    • Sheehan’s syndrome
    • Aneurysm (internal carotid)
  • Head injury (closed and penetrating) including pituitary surgery
  • Snakebite
  • Lymphocytic hypophysitis

questions.text:
A patient presents with severe chest pain, shortness of breath, fever, fatigue, and palpitations. He suffered from a flu-like illness 1 week ago. On auscultation, the lungs are clear and heart sounds are normal with no murmurs. ECG is unremarkable. An endomyocardial biopsy is shown below. Which of the following criteria is used for the diagnosis of this condition?

ECG - electrocardiogram
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of a patient presenting with a history of sudden severe chest pain, with a flu-like illness in the past week, and a biopsy showing lymphocytic infiltration in myocardial tissue is suggestive of myocarditis. The Dallas criteria is used for the diagnosis of myocarditis, based on endomyocardial biopsy. Myocyte necrosis and a lymphocytic infiltrate are two of the Dallas criteria for myocarditis. 

Myocarditis refers to inflammation of the myocardium. It is usually asymptomatic or can present with fatigue, dyspnea, palpitations, precordial discomfort, and fever. Clinical signs of myocarditis can mimic an acute myocardial infection.

Viruses (Coxsackie A and B, enteroviruses) are the most common causes among infectious causes of myocarditis. A few other less frequent etiologic agents are influenza, HIV, and CMV. Nonviral causes include Chagas disease (Trypanosoma cruzi), trichinosis (Trichinella spiralis), toxoplasmosis, as well as bacterial illnesses like diphtheria and Lyme disease. 

Endomyocardial biopsy is the gold standard for the diagnosis and it shows diffuse, mononuclear, lymphocytic infiltration as shown below:


Other options:

Option A: Truelove–Witts criteria is used to define acute severe colitis.

Option B: McDonald’s criteria is used in the diagnosis of multiple sclerosis.

Option C: The King's College Hospital Criteria is a prognostic tool for patients with acute liver failure (ALF).

questions.text: A baby is brought to the outpatient department for the facial defect shown in the given image. The soft and the hard palate are intact. Which of the following is not included in Millard's criteria to undertake surgical repair of this condition?

choices.text: Child's age should not exceed 10 months
Child should be minimum 10 weeks old

questions.solution:
The given clinical image is that of a child with a cleft lip on the left side. 

Millard Criteria (Rule of 10) is used to undertake surgery for a cleft lip:

  • 10 pounds in weight
  • 10 weeks old
  • 10 g% Hemoglobin

Millard cleft lip repair is done by rotating the local nasolabial flaps. Cleft lip repair is preferably done between 3 to 6 months of age.

A cleft lip is due to the failure of the fusion of maxillary prominence with medial nasal prominence. It can be unilateral or bilateral. It can vary in severity from a small notch in the upper lip to a double cleft extending into both nostrils. There is also associated underdevelopment of the part of the maxilla that bears the incisors. 

A cleft palate can occur in the primary palate (anterior cleft) or in the secondary palate (posterior palate). A Complete cleft palate involves both the primary and secondary palate. An incomplete cleft palate involves only the secondary palate.  

In the bilateral complete cleft palate, a Y-shaped cleft is seen with gaps between the primary and secondary palate and between the two halves of the secondary palate. In addition, there is a bilateral cleft upper lip. 

 The different types of facial clefts are shown below:

  1. Unilateral cleft lip with alveolar involvement
  2. Bilateral cleft lip with alveolar involvement
  3. Unilateral cleft lip associated with cleft palate
  4. Bilateral cleft lip and palate
  5. Cleft palate only 
 
 

Related Pearl: Timing of primary cleft lip and palate procedures:

Cleft lip alone

  • Unilateral (one side) - One operation at 3–6 months
  • Bilateral (both sides) - One operation at 4–5 months

Cleft palate alone

  • Soft palate - Only one operation at 6 months
  • Soft and hard palate - Two operations
    • Soft palate at 6 months
    • Hard palate at 15–18 months

Cleft lip and palate

  • Unilateral - Two operations
    • Cleft lip and soft palate at 5–6 months
    • Hard palate and gum pad with or without lip revision at 15–18 months
  • Bilateral - Two operations
    • Cleft lip and soft palate at 4–5 months
    • Hard palate and gum pad with or without lip revision at 15–18 months

Secondary management

  • Hearing, Prophylactic myringotomy, Regular audiological testing - 6–12 months

  • Speech, Velopharyngeal surgery, Speech and language therapy - 18 months

  • Orthodontic management

    - Mixed dentition - 8–10 years
    - Permanent dentition - 14-18 years

  • Excision of maxillary arch, Rhinoplasty - 16+ years

questions.text:
A 40-year-old patient presents with dizziness and chest pain. The ECG of the patient is given below. What is the pathophysiology involved in this condition?

ECG: electrocardiogram

choices.text: Conduction from atrium to ventricle with no AV nodal delay
Conduction from the atrium to the ventricle and reentry to the atrium
Autonomous functioning of the AV node
Retrograde conduction from ventricle to atrium

questions.solution:
The clinical scenario and the ECG finding with delta waves suggest a diagnosis of Wolff-Parkinson-White syndrome (WPW). The main pathophysiology involved in this condition is conduction from the atrium to the ventricle with no AV nodal delay. This is due to an abnormal accessory electrical conduction pathway called the Bundle of Kent between the atria and ventricles.

Other options:

Option B: Conduction from the atrium to the ventricle and reentry to the atrium is the main pathophysiology involved in atrioventricular reentrant tachycardia (AVRT).

Option C: Autonomous functioning of the AV node is the main pathophysiology involved in junctional tachycardia.

Option D: Retrograde conduction from the ventricle to the atrium is the main pathophysiology involved in antidromic AV reciprocating tachycardia.

Related Pearl: Wolff Parkinson White Syndrome

Wolff Parkinson White Syndrome (WPW) is characterized by an abnormal accessory pathway in the heart leading to arrhythmias.

Pathology- Born with an accessory pathway, the bundle of Kent which connects the atria and ventricle. The electrical impulses from the SA node reach the ventricles earlier via the accessory pathway as there is no AV nodal delay in this pathway. This leads to the preexcitation of the ventricle and initiation of ventricular contraction. This ventricular contraction is prolonged when the impulse via the AV nodal pathway reaches the ventricles.

Most common location of the accessory pathway- between the left atrium and free wall of the left ventricle

ECG changes:

Shortened PR interval- because of the early initiation of ventricular depolarization

Prolonged QRS duration- because of the AV nodal impulse reaching the ventricles after the aberrant impulse.

Delta waves- slurred upstroke of QRS complex

The given ECG shows delta waves marked with red arrows:

Treatment:

  • Catheter ablation is the treatment of choice.
  • Anti-arrhythmic drugs like procainamide, amiodarone, quinidine, propafenone, dofetilide are used in slowing conduction in the accessory pathway (prolong refractory period).
  • IV procainamide is the drug of choice in a hemodynamically stable WPW presenting with atrial fibrillation.
  • DC cardioversion is done in hemodynamically unstable patients.

questions.text: Which of the following is a limitation for a proper sessions court?

choices.text: Can pass death sentence but has to be confirmed by the High Court
Can pass a sentence of imprisonment for 10 years only
Can pass a sentence of imprisonment for 7 years only

questions.solution:
Sessions court can pass a death sentence but it has to be confirmed by the high court.

Sessions Court is the highest judicial tribunal for the district and is located in the district headquarters. The court is presided over by the Sessions Judge, appointed by the High Court. High Court may also appoint Additional Sessions Judges and Assistant Sessions Judges to exercise jurisdiction in the court of sessions. It takes up only the cases of criminal offenses referred by Magistrate’s courts.

Other options -

Options B and C: Courts that cannot pass a death sentence include District courts that deal with civil cases only, Assistant Sessions Court that can pass a sentence of imprisonment up to 10 years and an unlimited fine; and Magistrate courts.

Option D: Magistrate’s courts are criminal courts presided over by the Judicial/ Metropolitan Magistrates. In every district, the State Government after consultation with the High Court may establish as many Courts of Judicial Magistrate as it may consider necessary. There are three classes of Magistrate courts. 

Type of Magistrate Court  Maximum Imprisonment  Maximum Fine
Chief Judicial Magistrate Upto 7 years Unlimited 
First Class Judicial Magistrate Upto 3 years Rs.50,000
Second Class Judicial Magistrate Upto 1 year  Rs. 10,000

questions.text: Which of the following is the site of replication for the virus shown in the image below ?
questions.solution:
The image depicts a bullet-shaped enveloped virus, with nonsegmented single-stranded RNA suggestive of the rabies viruses belonging to the family Rhabdoviridae. Once central nervous system (CNS) infection is established, the virus spreads centrifugally along the nerve trunks to the acinar cells of the salivary glands where it multiplies and is shed in saliva.

Rabies is a vaccine-preventable, zoonotic, disease transmitted by the bite of rabid animals (bats, dogs, other mammals). Spread of rabies is initially centripetal via retrograde fast axonal transport (3 mm per hour) from axons to neuronal cell bodies. It infects neurons primarily, but may rarely infect astrocytes. Once CNS infection is established, the virus spreads centrifugally through the autonomic and sensory nerves to reach the salivary glands where it replicates.

Clinical features of rabies can be categorized into a prodromal phase (malaise, anorexia, headache, and irritability), encephalitic phase (abnormal behavior seizures, hydrophobia, aerophobia) ultimately progressing to coma and death. Once clinical manifestations appear it is almost always fatal. 

Antemortem diagnosis can be done with direct immunofluorescence on corneal scrapings, saliva, or skin biopsy. Other methods used in the diagnosis are intracerebral inoculation in the mice, tissue culture, ELISA (enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay), and PCR (polymerase chain reaction).

Demonstration of Negri bodies is pathognomonic, and they are seen in the pyramidal neurons of the hippocampus and Purkinje cells of the cerebellum, but is always post-mortem. 

Other options : 

Though the virus spreads through the peripheral nerves and can also affect the cerebellum, these are not the sites for replication. 

The virus spreads through nerves and not blood.

Related Pearl: Rabies vaccines and immunoglobulins schedules

According to the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare, Government of India:

WHO category II or III exposures should receive post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP) immediately.

One intradermal (ID) dose is 0.1 mL of vaccine and one intramuscular (IM) dose is an entire vial of vaccine, irrespective of the vial size.

Should a vaccine dose be delayed for any reason, the PEP schedule should be resumed (not restarted).

Rabies Immunoglobulin(RIG): 

  • Passive immunization
  • Single-dose; after initiation of PEP and not beyond 7 days after the first dose of vaccine
  • Max dose: hRIG - 20IU/kg , eRIG - 40IU/kg body weight
  • Vaccines should never be withheld regardless of the availability of RIG.
  • Alternatives for RIG- WHO recommends monoclonal antibodies (mAb) as a 'cocktail' containing at least two antibodies against the rabies virus.

Administration of RIG:

  • RIG should be administered into or around the wound site or sites.
  • The remaining RIG, if any, should be injected IM at a site distant from the site of vaccine administration.
  • RIG may be diluted to a volume sufficient for all wounds to be effectively and safely infiltrated.

Prioritization of RIG allocation (numbered according to priority order):

  1. Multiple bites
  2. Deep wounds
  3. Bites to head, neck, and hands
  4. Patients with severe immunodeficiency
  5. Confirmed/probable rabies in biting animal
  6. Bites, scratches, and exposure of mucous membranes caused by a bat

Pre-exposure prophylaxis (PrEP)

PrEP is considered in the following conditions:

  • High-risk groups- laboratory staff, wildlife wardens, veterinarians, animal handlers, and travelers to endemic regions.
  • Remote, rabies-endemic areas where access to PEP is difficult
  • Areas where dog bite incidence is >5% per year
  • Areas where vampire bat rabies is known to be present.

Pre-exposure rabies vaccination consists of 3 intramuscular (IM) or 3 intradermal (ID) doses. These are given on days 0, 7 and 21 or 28.

  • Adults - the vaccine should always be administered in the deltoid area of the arm
  • Young children (under 1 year of age)- Administration into the anterolateral area of the thigh is recommended.
  • Rabies vaccine should never be administered in the gluteal area. Administration in this manner will result in lower neutralizing antibody titers.

For exposed or re-exposed patients who can document previous completion of PEP or PrEP the following guidelines would be applicable:

  • Proper wound management should be done.
  • There is no need for the administration of RIG.
  • One site ID or IM vaccine administration on days 0 and 3.

Only adequate wound washing would be required in case of re-exposure where the animal bite victim has documented proof of complete PEP within the last three months.

The following cases are treated as fresh cases and given full PEP:

  • Those who have previously received full post-exposure treatment with neural tissue vaccines (NTV) or vaccines of unproven potency
  • Those who cannot document complete PEP or PrEP treatment

questions.text:
Match the following eponymous features of mercury poisoning:
           Conditions  Characteristic features
1. Erethism a. Anterior capsule of the lens discoloration
2. Acrodynia b. Mental retardation
3. Minamata disease c. Personality changes
4. Mercuria lentis d. Pink-colored rashes
questions.solution:
The correct matching is 1-c,2-d,3-b,4-a.

Condition Characteristic feature
1. Erethism c. Personality changes
2. Acrodynia d. Pink-colored rashes
3. Minamata disease b. Mental retardation
4. Mercuria lentis a. Anterior capsule of the lens discoloration


Features of mercury poisoning:

Erethism: These are psychological symptoms due to mercury toxicity, which is seen among persons working in mirror manufacturing firms. It is characterised by personality changes which include shyness, timidity, irritability, loss of confidence, mental depression, loss of memory, and insomnia.

Pink disease or acrodynia occurs due to an idiosyncratic hypersensitivity reaction resulting from chronic mercury exposure and is seen particularly in children. The onset is insidious with anorexia, sweating, pink-colored skin rash, insomnia, and photophobia. Hands and feet become puffy, pinkish, and painful. Associated joint pain, paresthesia, shedding of teeth, and skin peeling are also seen.

Minamata disease: This is caused by the eating of fish poisoned by mercury. The industrial discharges of mercury into Minamata Bay in Japan became biomethylated to form methyl mercury, which then accumulated in fish. Mental retardation, dysarthria, cerebellar symptoms (such as ataxia), limb deformity, primitive reflexes (grasping, sucking, etc.), hypersalivation, and stunted body growth are the most common manifestations.

Mercuria lentis: This term refers to the peculiar eye change seen due to exposure to mercury vapour. It appears as brownish deposits of mercury on the anterior lens capsule.

Danbury tremors are coarse, intentional tremors. The advanced condition is called Hatter's shakes/Glass blower's shakes.

questions.text: Actalycabtagene autoleucel was recently approved in India to treat B cell lymphoma. It works by modifying the patient’s own immune cells using a viral vector and reinfusing them to specifically target cancer cells. What is the name of this therapy?
questions.solution:
Actalycabtagene autoleucel, is a form of chimeric antigen receptor (CAR) T-cell therapy that has been recently approved in India as NexCAR19 to treat B-cell lymphoma and B-acute lymphoblastic leukaemia. 

In this treatment, a patient's own T-cells are genetically modified using a viral vector to express a chimeric antigen receptor that specifically targets cancer cells. These modified T-cells are then reinfused into the patient, where they can recognize and destroy cancer cells expressing the target antigen. CAR T-cell therapy has shown promising results in treating certain types of B cell lymphoma by harnessing the patient's own immune system to fight cancer.

Other options: 

Option A: Checkpoint inhibitor therapy, involves the use of drugs that block immune checkpoints to enhance the immune system's ability to recognize and attack cancer cells. 

Option B: Bispecific T-cell engager (BiTE) therapy, utilizes synthetic antibodies to redirect a patient's T-cells to target cancer cells. While BiTE therapy is another form of immunotherapy, it does not involve the modification of a patient's own T-cells.

Option D: Oncolytic virus therapy, uses genetically modified viruses to selectively infect and destroy cancer cells.

questions.text:
What would you advise regarding the vaccination against pneumococcal infection for a child who is HIV positive?

PCV - Pneumococcal conjugate vaccine

choices.text: The national schedule for PCV should be followed as usual
The vaccine is administered if the CD4 count > 800
A single dose primary vaccination should be administered
Pneumococcal vaccines should not be administered

questions.solution:
Even in children with HIV infection, the national schedule for PCV should be followed as usual.

Regardless of the presence of underlying medical conditions (e.g., children with HIV infection, sickle cell disease, or who are otherwise immunocompromised), PCV should be given according to the national schedule. PCV is safe and well-tolerated among HIV-infected children. Children with HIV infection require a booster dose to sustain protection.

Pneumococcal vaccines include:

  • Pneumococcal conjugate vaccines (PCV): 10-valent (PCV10) and 13-valent (PCV13)
  • Pneumococcal polysaccharide vaccine (PPSV): 23-valent polysaccharide vaccine (PPSV23)

The Pneumococcal conjugate vaccine (PCV) 13: It includes purified capsular polysaccharides of 13 serotypes of Streptococcus pneumoniae conjugated to a nontoxic variant of diphtheria toxin. Both PCV10 and PCV13 are preservative-free and their recommended storage temperature is 2-8°C. The vaccine must not be frozen.

WHO recommends 3 primary doses or 2 primary doses plus one booster of the PCV vaccine. In India, 2 primary doses at 6 and 14 weeks and 1 booster is given at 9-12 months.

Pneumococcal polysaccharide vaccine - PPSV23: It contains polysaccharide antigen from 23 types of pneumococcal bacteria and is available for adults and children over 2 years of age. Children under 2 years of age and immunocompromised individuals do not respond well to the vaccine. It is recommended for selected groups such as:

  • Post splenectomy
  • Sickle-cell disease
  • Chronic diseases of heart, lung, liver, or kidney
  • Generalized malignancies
  • Organ transplants

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with a hard and irregular lump in the upper outer quadrant of the breast. Histopathological appearance of the specimen is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The histopathological image shows discohesive infiltrating tumor cells, signet-ring cells containing intracytoplasmic mucin droplets, and the Indian file appearance which is suggestive of lobular carcinoma of the breast.

Lobular Carcinoma is usually bilateral, multicentric, and presents as hard irregular masses. It can have a diffuse infiltrative pattern with minimal desmoplasia. It is the most common type of breast carcinoma to present as an occult primary.

It is associated with a mutation in the CDH-1 gene which encodes for cadherin. Loss of E-cadherin leads to small, monomorphic discohesive cells arranged one after another. This arrangement is called an Indian file/ Single file appearance. Desmoplasia is minimal or absent in this type.

They are Luminal-A type and have an excellent prognosis.


Note: Mutation in CDH-1 also poses a high risk for gastric signet ring cell carcinoma.

Other options:

Option B: Papillary carcinoma consists of true papillae with a leaf-like arrangement of fibrovascular tissue, lined by the tumor cells.

The image below shows histopathology findings of papillary carcinoma of the breast:


Option C: Medullary carcinoma of the breast shows sheets of highly pleomorphic cells with mitotic figures, lymphoplasmacytic infiltrates, and pushing border.

The image below shows histopathology findings of medullary carcinoma of the breast:


Option D: Colloidal carcinoma is an invasive breast carcinoma, which shows intra and extracellular mucin deposition. Extracellular type shows tumor cells with faint nuclei arranged in clusters floating in pools/lakes of mucin on histopathological examination. In the intracellular type, nuclei are pushed to the peripherally to form a signet ring appearance.

questions.text: A patient is being administered flumazenil to reverse benzodiazepine anesthesia. Which of the following is the most appropriate way to administer this drug?
questions.solution:
Continuous infusion of flumazenil is needed to reverse benzodiazepine anesthesia. This is because flumazenil has a short half-life of 1 hour.

Flumazenil is a competitive antagonist at the benzodiazepine binding site of the GABAA receptor. It antagonizes both the agonist (benzodiazepines) and inverse-agonist (beta-carbolines) of this receptor.

To maintain a constant therapeutic blood level over a prolonged time, either repeated administration or a continuous infusion is necessary.

The duration of clinical effects usually is only 30–60 min. It is absorbed rapidly after oral administration, less than a quarter of the drug reaches the systemic circulation. This is due to the extensive first-pass hepatic metabolism. Flumazenil is eliminated almost entirely by hepatic metabolism to inactive products with a t1/2 of about 1 hour.

It is primarily indicated for the management of benzodiazepine overdose and the reversal of benzodiazepine anesthesia.

Flumazenil is only available for intravenous administration. It reliably reverses the sedation, respiratory depression, and amnesia caused by benzodiazepines.

It can also be used to diagnose benzodiazepine dependence. It has also been used successfully to reverse the effects of chloral hydrate and cannabis intoxication in children, carbamazepine and alcohol overdose, and antihistamines overdose.

In patients using large doses of benzodiazepines over long periods, the administration of flumazenil may precipitate the symptoms of benzodiazepine withdrawal, including seizures.

questions.text: An infant was brought with a history of recurrent pneumonia and copious, adherent secretions. The history also was suggestive of chronic malabsorption with fatty stools and poor weight gain. Blood examination shows high levels of immunoreactive trypsinogen. What is the most common gene mutation in this condition?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis in the given scenario is cystic fibrosis (CF). The most common gene mutation in CF is the F508del mutation.  

F508del mutation is a deletion of a phenylalanine residue at the CFTR position 508, which results in endoplasmic reticulum–associated degradation. At least 90% of patients with CF have this mutation. A mutation affecting protein degradation is termed a class II defect.

There are 6 classes of defects involving the CFTR gene:

Class Defect
Class I Absence of synthesis e.g., W1282X, G542X
Class II Defective protein maturation and premature degradation e.g., F508 deletion
Class III Disordered gating/regulation, e.g. G551D mutation
Class IV Defective conductance through the ion-channel pore
Class V Promoter or splicing abnormality leading to reduced CFTR transcripts
Class VI Accelerated turnover from the cell surface

Cystic fibrosis is an autosomal recessive disorder that affects fluid secretion in the exocrine glands and in the epithelial lining. It is primarily caused by a mutation in the CFTR gene, which codes for an anion channel in the apical membranes of epithelial cells. This leads to abnormally viscous secretions that obstruct organ passages, resulting in recurrent infections, pancreatic insufficiency, steatorrhea, malnutrition, hepatic cirrhosis, intestinal obstruction, and male infertility.

Diagnosis of CF is made at the time of newborn screening. Sweat electrolyte levels are measured after pilocarpine iontophoresis. In these patients, the chloride level is high. It is then confirmed through genetic testing with one of the 20–140 CFTR variants. 

The diagnosis of CF is confirmed if both of the following criteria are met:

  • Presence of
    • Clinical symptoms affecting at least one organ system (respiratory, gastrointestinal, or genitourinary) or
    • Positive newborn screening or
    • A sibling with cystic fibrosis
  • Evidence of dysfunction of the CFTR gene in the form of
    • Two positive sweat chloride test results obtained on separate days or
    • Identification of two CFTR mutations by genetic testing or
    • An abnormal measurement of nasal potential difference

Management of cystic fibrosis requires a multidisciplinary approach:

  • Mucus accumulation - chest physiotherapy, aerosolized dornase alfa (recombinant DNase), N-acetylcysteine, albuterol, corticosteroids, and hypertonic saline
  • Respiratory infections - antibiotics (oral for Staphylococcus and aerosolized for Pseudomonas)
  • Pancreatic insufficiency - pancreatic enzyme supplements
  • Malabsorption - nutritional supplementation along with fat-soluble vitamins (K, E, D, and A) and minerals 

Other options: 

Option A: In a G551D mutation, there is a glycine to aspartic acid replacement at the 551st position, which leads to the disruption in HCO3- and Cl- transportation. This is a class III defect. 

Option C: W1282X is the most common defect amongst Ashkenazi Jews. It is a class I defect. 

Option D: G542X is another class I defect that is not very common.

questions.text: As an intern in the community medicine department , you are asked to study about the various graphical representation of data. What is the following graph best used for ?

choices.text: Correlating risk factors of a disease
Studying the periodic trends of disease over time

questions.solution:
The graph depicted is a Kaplan-Meier plot, and the graph is used for survival time analysis.

Survival time analysis includes the study of:

  • What is the survival time of patients with a given disease
  • How does this survival time compare between two groups of patients given different treatments for the same disease
  • Among those who survive up to a certain time, at what time or rate can they be expected to die
  • What factors, such as risk factors or treatments, affect the survival time

Despite its name, survival analysis can be used to help answer questions of this kind about any kind of event, not just death—such as how long it takes before a hip replacement fails, how long it takes before a patient has a second heart attack, or how long it takes for coronary stents to become re-stenosed.

Other options:

Option A and C - Scatter diagrams correlate risk factors of a disease and present as a positive correlation, negative correlation, or no correlation. The line of best fit is used to express a relationship in a scatter plot of different data points as a straight line rather than multiple dots. It is an output of regression analysis and can be used as a prediction tool.

Option D - Line diagram is used to study the periodic trends of a disease over time.

Related Pearl: Graphical Representation of Data

1. Histogram

  • A histogram, by definition, is a graphical representation of frequency distribution that contains rectangles and shows the underlying frequency of a set of continuous, quantitative data.
  • The X or horizontal axis is called the abscissa which usually has the group scores or class intervals of the variables/data and the Y or vertical axis is called the ordinate which usually shows the frequencies at which these variables appear.
  • The following image shows a histogram.

2. Bar Chart

  • It is also called a bar graph.
  • It is used mainly for nominal or ordinal scale data as they are not quantitative and usually qualitative.
  • The difference between a bar graph and a histogram is that the rectangles are separated by spaces representing data that forms discrete categories instead of continuous groups.
  • Bar graphs can be simple, multiple or component bar graphs.

3. Pie Charts

  • Pie charts are also used for nominal or ordinal data.
  • The categorical data are represented as segments of a circle.

4. Frequency polygons

  • Frequency polygons are used for mainly ratio and interval scale data.
  • In a frequency polygon, the mid-points of each class interval are joined together by straight lines.

5. Ogive

  • A frequency polygon which is drawn to represent cumulative frequency distributions form a typical S-shaped curve which is called an ogive. It referred to as a cumulative frequency diagram.

6. Line chart

  • It is also called a line diagram or line graph.
  • Its best use is to show the trend of events or change over passage of time.

questions.text: A 17-year-old female patient presented with primary amenorrhea. On examination, she is found to have normally developed breasts and swelling in the right inguinal region and female-type external genitalia. Ultrasound of the abdomen and pelvis did not reveal the uterus or cervix. The karyotype is 46XY. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical findings in the question are seen in androgen insensitivity syndrome/ testicular feminizing syndrome. In this syndrome, the affected individual has testes producing the androgens, but the response of the androgen receptors to androgens is defective.

The findings of the given case can be explained as follows:

  • Primary amenorrhea - Due to the absence of uterus and cervix.
  • Normally developed breasts - Due to the conversion of the excessive androgens into estrogen.
  • Swelling in the inguinal region - Suggestive of an underdeveloped ectopic testis, due to loss of action of testosterone on its receptor.
  • Absence of uterus and cervix - Due to the production of mullerian inhibiting substance from the sertoli cells of the testis.
  • The XY karyotype indicates that the patient is a genotypic male.

Option A - Swyer's syndrome : although the karyotype is 46XY, the testes are dysgenetic and do not produce androgens. As a result the external genitalia resemble that of a female. The Mullerian system is preserved as the dysgenetic gonads fail to produce anti Mullerian hormone.

Option C - Mullerian agenesis is another cause of primary amenorrhea characterised by absent uterus, fallopian tubes, cervix and upper vagina. The secondary sexual characteristics are preserved due to the presence of estrogen producing ovaries. However the karyotype is 46XX.

Option D - Turner's syndrome is the most common cause of primary amenorrhea. Karyotyping reveals 45XO and the individual has streak ovaries and absent secondary sexual features.

questions.text:
Arrange the following corrections for the management of congenital talipes equinovarus in the right order according to Ponseti's method.

1. Elevation of 1st metatarsal 
2. Dorsiflexion at the ankle joint 
3. Abduction of the forefoot in the plane of metatarsals
questions.solution:
The correct order of correction in congenital talipes equino varus (CTEV) based on Ponseti's method is 1-3-2 (Option D). The order of correction of CTEV is the order of the deformity present which is cavus followed by adduction, then varus, and lastly equinus (CAVE).

The order of correction according to Ponseti's method is as follows:

Elevation of 1st metatarsal  - This brings the medial longitudinal border of the foot flat hence correcting the cavus.

Forefoot is abducted in the plane of metatarsals - This rotates and everts the hindfoot and corrects the supination of the forefoot hence correcting the adduction and varus components.

Dorsiflexion at ankle joint - corrects the equinus.

The following table shows the differences between Ponseti's and Kite's methods of CTEV management.

  Ponseti's method Kite's method
Treatment starts at Within the first week of life Around 1 month
Order of correction cavus - adduction - varus - equinus adduction - inversion - equinus
Fulcrum while manipulating Head of the talus Calcaneocuboid joint
POP type Above knee cast Below knee cast

Related Pearl: Age wise management of CTEV

Initial treatment starts with Ponseti's POP cast as early as possible, but within 1 year of age.

If deformity gets corrected:

  • Dennis Brown splint is used till 1 year of age
  • After 1 year upto 5 years CTEV shoes are used in day, and Dennis Brown splint is used at night

If deformity is not corrected or untreated previously:

  • 1-3 years: Posteromedial soft tissue release (PMSTR) 
  • 3-5 years: Dillwyn Evans procedure
  • 5-8 years: Dwyer osteotomy
  • 8-10 years: Wedge tarsectomy
  • >10 years: Triple arthrodesis, external fixators

questions.text:
An infant presents with poor feeding. He has tachycardia and tachypnoea along with enlarged tongue, hypotonia, skeletal muscle weakness, and hepatomegaly. Laboratory investigations reveal elevated serum CK, AST, ALT, LDH, and urine glucose tetrasaccharide. Chest X-ray is done later as shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?

CK-creatine kinase ; AST-aspartate aminotransferase ; ALT-alanine aminotransferase ; LDH-lactate dehydrogenase
questions.solution:
From the above-given clinical scenario and the radiograph showing cardiomegaly (tachycardia and tachypnoea), Pompe's disease is the most likely diagnosis. The clinical symptoms of Pompe disease are hypotonia (floppy infant), skeletal muscle weakness, hepatomegaly, hypertrophic cardiomyopathy and macroglossia. 

Pompe's disease (Type 2 glycogen storage disease) is an autosomal recessive disorder that occurs due to α-1,4-glucosidase (acid maltase) deficiencyleading to lysosomal glycogen accumulation in cardiac, skeletal, and smooth muscle cells. It can appear within weeks or months after birth (infantile Pompe disease) or may appear late in juvenile, childhood, or adulthood disease (late-onset Pompe disease).

Laboratory findings will show elevated levels of serum creatine kinase (CK), aspartate transaminase (AST), alanine transaminase (ALT), and lactate dehydrogenase (LDH). Urine glucose tetrasaccharide, a glycogen breakdown metabolite, is a reliable biomarker for disease severity and treatment response.

Muscle biopsy shows the presence of vacuoles that stain positively for glycogen. It is diagnosed by detecting the decreased activity of the enzyme, α-1,4-glucosidase in the dried blood spots, leukocytes, blood mononuclear cells, muscle, or cultured skin fibroblasts.

Other options

Option A- Von Gierke disease occurs due to a deficiency of glucose-6-phosphatase. Patients present commonly in 3-4 months of age with hypoglycemia, lactic acidosis, hepatomegaly, growth retardation, hyperuricemia, and hyperlipidemia.

Option C- McArdle disease occurs due to myophosphorylase deficiency leading to reduced ATP generation. The typical manifestations are myoglobinuria (secondary to rhabdomyolysis), muscle pain and cramps after heavy exercise. This pain may reduce after a brief period of rest and the patient may be able to perform an exercise. This is called the second wind phenomenon. Cardiomyopathy is not seen in this condition.

Option D- Tarui disease (Type VII glycogen storage disorder) occurs due to the deficiency of muscle phosphofructokinase. The main clinical features are exercise intolerance, cramps, hemolytic anemia, and myoglobinuria. There is no hypertrophic cardiomyopathy.

1)SIDA  c) Supply of X ray units 
2)DANIDA  a)Services of NBCP
3)Colombo Plan  b)Supplying cobalt therapy units 
4) Ford foundation  d)Calcutta water supply and drainage scheme

SIDA - Swedish International Development Agency provides assistance to India in the procurement of supplies like x-ray units, microscopes, and drugs for tuberculosis under the National Tuberculosis Elimination Program. 

DANIDA: The Danish International Development Agency provides assistance for the development of services under the National Blindness Control Program.

Colombo Plan - It was a meeting of the commonwealth Foreign Ministers at Colombo in January 1950, a programme for cooperative economic development in South and South East Asia. Under the programme , New Zealand contributed in setting up of the All India Institute of Medical Sciences at New Delhi and Canada contributed by supplying cobalt therapy units.

Ford foundation - It is a non-governmental organisation whose contributions include setting up National Institute of Health Administration Education(NIHAE) at Delhi and prepared the master plan for water supply and drainage for the city of Calcutta.

questions.text: A patient with glaucoma is identified to have Roenne’s central nasal step on visual field testing. Which among the following images represents the finding?
questions.solution:
Image 4 shows Roenne’s central nasal step. It is a late visual field change seen in glaucoma, which occurs when two arcuate scotomas run in different arcs and meet to form a sharp 90-degree defect at the horizontal meridian. The image is given below:


In the given set of images:

  • 1 represents paracentral scotomas which are the earliest clinically significant defects
  • 2 represents arcuate scotoma (Bjerrum scotoma)
  • 3 represents Seidel's scotoma

Progression of visual field changes seen in glaucoma:

Early non-specific changes

Isopter contraction

Baring of a blind spot: Exclusion of blind spot from the central field
Early significant changes

Peripheral nasal step (may be early or late)

Paracentral scotoma in Bjerrum's area.

Siedel’s  scotoma: Paracentral scotoma joins the blind spot
Late significant changes

Arcuate or Bjerrum scotoma

Ring or Double arcuate scotoma: When 2 arcuate scotomas join together

Roenne’s central nasal step
Advanced glaucomatous field defects

Tubular vision

No light perception: Complete visual field defect

questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient was rapidly administered a muscle relaxant, which resulted in erythema of the face, neck, and upper torso, associated with a fall in arterial pressure and an increase in heart rate were noted. Which of the following is most commonly implicated?
questions.solution:
The above clinical signs and symptoms caused by the rapid administration of muscle relaxant are attributed to histamine release. The side effect of histamine release is most often noted following the administration of the benzylisoquinoline class of muscle relaxants, mainly by d-tubocurarine.

Clinical features associated with histamine release include erythema of the face, neck, and upper torso, as well as a brief decrease in arterial pressure with a slight to moderate increase in heart rate. The serosal mast cells, located near the blood vessels and nerves in the skin and connective tissue are principally involved in the degranulation process.

Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (e.g., aspirin), in addition to anti-histamines, help prevent the development of hypotension with the administration of d-Tubocurarine. Slower injection rates have been shown to reduce the incidence of this side effect.

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding a bipolar cautery ?

choices.text: Used for both cutting and coagulation

questions.solution:
A bipolar cautery acts by the spread of current from one blade to the other, thus completing the circuit. Hence, there will not be any lateral spread of the energy or current through the body as with monopolar cautery, making it preferrable in those patients with cardiac pacemakers.

In monopolar cautery, there will be lateral spread of current because of a single blade and hence the energy has to travel through the body to complete the circuit. This will interfere with the conduction of pacemakers. Also, the heart will be shocked repeatedly by the pacemaker because of the abnormal rhythm caused by the cautery. Hence, monopolar cautery is avoided in such cases.

Other options :

Option B : Bipolar cautery can only be used for coagulation as opposed to monopolar cautery, which can be used for both cutting and coagulation

Option C : The current in bipolar cautery starts from the machine and travels from one blade to another while coagulating to finally renter the machine, thus closing the circuit. Hence, a seperate cautery pad is not needed. But in a monopolar cautery, it is mandatory becuase the current starts from the machine, reaches the tip (pencil/bovie) to cut/coagulate, travels through the body to reach the cautery pad and finally reenters the machine to close the circuit.

Option D : Monopolar cautery has a narrow pedicle, hence energy given through it will cause channeling of current to the base causing burns at the base. Hence, in surgeries where there are end arteries (ear lobule) or in circumcision/penile surgeries monopolar cautery is avoided
